TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

This Bill is an Omnibus Bill amending 3 Acts administered within the Transport and Communications portfolio. While none of the proposed amendments involve significant policy changes, they are important for the general administration of the Transport and Communications portfolio. Details of the amendments are as follows.
Air Navigation Act 1920

Part 2 of this Bill proposes a number of miscellaneous amendments to the Air Navigation Act 1920. Many of these changes make the law in relation to international aircraft movements clearer to the aviation industry both in Australia and overseas. They provide for consistency in the area of aircraft operations and clarity in relation to offences committed under the Act. The changes also remove ambiguities which exist at the moment between provisions in the Act and provisions in the Regulations. These changes do not impact adversely on industry as there is no proposed tightening of regulatory powers in this area.
The amendments do, however:
replace the existing general offence provision with specific offence provisions and penalties;
clarify the provisions relating to international airline licences, permissions and approvals; and
enable regulations to be made providing for on-the-spot fines for specific offences and remove the power to prescribe a term of imprisonment in regulations.
I will address each of these amendments in turn.

Section 22 of the Act currently contains a general offence provision which sets a single penalty in respect of each of the offences contained in the Act. General offence provisions of this kind have been criticised by the Courts for failing to provide any indication of the relative seriousness of each of the offences contained in the Act and therefore providing no guidance in the exercise of the discretion of a sentencing Court. They have also been criticised as being unhelpful in determining whether an offence has actually been committed, that is, determining whether a particular provision creates an obligation with criminal sanctions or is purely administrative.

The offences are now stated in the Act itself. That is, the amendments contained in the present Bill describe each of the offences in the Act and allocate an appropriate penalty. Section 22 is repealed.

The second group of amendments concern the licensing provisions of the Act. At present, the Act deals specifically with the grant of international airline licences, permissions and approvals to foreign aircraft. Complementary provisions in relation to Australian aircraft are contained mostly in the Regulations. The amendments will transfer and amalgamate these provisions into the Act so that powers for the regulation of Australian aircraft operating scheduled and non-scheduled flights are co-located and provide similarly to those for foreign aircraft.

Finally, the Bill amends the power to make regulations in section 26 of the Act. In accordance with Commonwealth criminal law policy, serious offences warranting a penalty of imprisonment will be contained in the Act rather than the Regulations. Secondly, the Regulations will enable a person who is alleged to have contravened a specified provision of the Regulations to pay an on-the-spot fine as an alternative to prosecution. The level of the fine would not exceed one-fifth of the maximum penalty payable by a person who is prosecuted for a breach of the specified regulation. I emphasise that the payment of an on-the-spot fine is an alternative to prosecution which is not intended to deprive a person from seeking to defend the matter should he or she choose to do so.

Except in the provision of a stronger deterrent for unlicensed scheduled operations, the Bill does not introduce any new regulatory powers. The new provisions of subsections 13A(3), 14(3A), 15(2C) and 17(1B) specify certain categories of flights which may be exempt from the requirement to obtain prior permission. This Government has deregulated many areas of the aviation industry as part of its micro-economic reform program. This Bill introduces, in a small way, some further opportunities for administrative savings for both the industry and my Department.

I am advised by my Department that it has already begun to exempt certain categories of flights in accordance with guidelines issued by the Government for certain categories of charter flights. The provisions in this Bill make the legislative base for doing this very clear. Such measures mean less contact by aircraft operators with Government bureaucracy and reduced public service surveillance and expenditure.
Broadcasting Act 1942
Part 3 of the Bill contains measures to correct drafting anomalies arising from amendments to the Broadcasting Act 1942 contained in the Broadcasting Amendment Act (No. 2) 1991.

Firstly, the Bill will make minor changes to the definitions of `AM commercial radio licence' and `non-metropolitan FM commercial radio licence' contained in the Broadcasting Act. Subsection 89D(5A) of the Broadcasting Act enables the holder of a non-metropolitan AM commercial radio licence to seek to convert to FM by applying to vary the technical conditions of the licence warrant. However, the existing definition of an AM commercial radio licence excludes those licences where the warrant includes an FM translator, even though the main service may be on AM. The amendment will clarify that the Minister may convert such non-metropolitan AM commercial radio licences to FM by changing the technical conditions of the licence warrant.
Secondly, the Bill will amend subsection 80B(2) of the Broadcasting Act to clarify a minor drafting inconsistency between paragraph (a) and paragraph (b) of that subsection.
Radio Licence Fees Act 1964

Part 4 of the Bill corrects a drafting oversight in the Radio Licence Fees Amendment Act 1991. This concerns the level of licence fees to be paid under paragraph 6(2A)(e) of the Radio Licence Fees Act 1964. The current licence fee ceiling of 6.5% for licensees with revenues greater than $10m contained in paragraph 6(2A)(e) should have been reduced by 50% by the 1991 Amendment Act. The current 6.5% licence fee ceiling will be reduced to 3.25% by this Bill to give effect to the original intention of the 1991 amendments.

The reduced ceiling of 3.25% will take effect retrospectively from 1 January 1992. The amendment is retrospective in effect as it is beneficial to affected licensees and ensures that the changes in fees apply to all fees payable in 1992. A mechanism has been included to require the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to refund the difference between the amount of licence fees paid by affected licensees as calculated under the existing formula (with the 6.5% ceiling), and the amount that would have been payable under the amended formula.

Two commercial radio licences are in force under the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942, as in force immediately before 1 January 1986, and are known as old system licences. Old system licences are subject to licence fees under the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Act 1964, which has continued application by virtue of section 11 of the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendment Act 1985. Transitional provisions have been included in this Bill to apply the 50% licence fee reduction in the Radio Licence Fees Amendment Act 1991 to those two remaining commercial radio licensees operating under old system licences.
Financial Impact

The amendments of the Broadcasting Act 1942 and the Radio Licence Fees Act 1964 correct anomalies arising from amendments in the Broadcasting Amendment Act (No. 2) 1991 and the Radio Licence Fees Amendment Act 1991. Accordingly, the amendments will ensure that the financial impact identified for those bills will be achieved. In particular, the amendments to the Radio Licence Fees Act will ensure that the expected financial impact (a decrease in Commonwealth revenue of $8 million in the 1991-92 financial year) for the halving of annual licence fees for commercial, supplementary and remote licences occurs.
The other amendments will have no significant effect on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
COARSE GRAINS LEVY (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: This Bill is complementary to the Coarse Grains Levy Bill 1992 which I have just introduced. Its purpose is to enact certain consequential amendments to related legislation, to repeal two existing levy Acts and to provide for other necessary transitional arrangements to enable the continuing collection of industry levies to fund barley and triticale research.

The levies to be imposed by the Coarse Grains Levy Bill 1992 will be collected under the provisions of the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991. This Bill extends the definition in that Act of producer, which presently applies to producers of barley and triticale, to producers of other leviable coarse grain. Provision is also made for the Coarse Grains Levy Bill 1992, when enacted, to be included as an associated Act listed in the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991.

As the levies for barley and triticale research will, in future be imposed under a new single Act, this Bill provides for the repeal of the existing Acts imposing levies on these grains. A transitional provision ensures the continuing collection of these levies.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1992. This cosmetic and selective reduction of Labor's biggest consumption tax, the wholesale sales tax, is typical of the shallow and dishonest approach of the Keating `One Job' package which was delivered on 26 February this year. A fifth level of sales tax has now been created in what is nothing more than a vote buying exercise. If it were something more than a vote buying exercise, something more radical would have been done and this tax reduction would have been extended to many other areas.

PARA.TAB: This Bill clearly shows the Liberal and National parties' commitment to thoroughly reform the tax system. It also shows our commitment to complete reform that will not only benefit the individual consumer but also strengthen the entire economy, and a Government out to buy a few votes while refusing to contemplate reform is what we are faced with today.

It is very obvious that this Bill is intended as an electoral sweetener, nothing more and nothing less, as it is purely and simply confined strictly to passenger motor vehicles. If the Government were serious about this, it would have extended it to other vehicles, and particularly vehicles which produce income for this country. Passenger vehicles will now attract a new 15 per cent sales tax level while trucks, delivery vans, utilities and motor cycles will continue to attract the 20 per cent level. Why is there the discrimination between the two?

Herein lies the great difference between what this Government is doing and what the Liberal and National parties are suggesting. We will make sure that the whole of this wholesale sales tax is removed from those business motor vehicles and that the goods and services tax will be fully refunded as a business input. The Government benefit is aimed squarely at the private consumer with the carrot of an $800 reduction on a six-cylinder sedan. Why has the Government not extended that to the businesses and the wealth producing sectors of this country?

Vehicles used in earning income as an essential part of business do not share the benefit because there are no votes in it. It would be too much to expect the Keating Labor Government to take action to reduce the cost of business inputs for the good of the national economy.It is purely and simply designed to grab a vote wherever it can.

The cost of sales tax revenue for 1992-93, we are told, will be $185m. This represents less than 2 per cent of the $10 billion that is likely to be raised by this hidden consumption tax next year. It represents 8 per cent of nearly $2.3 billion in sales tax that was levied on vehicles, tyres, oil and batteries in 1990-91, and herein lies another difference. All of those items, once again, will have the wholesale sales tax taken off them and the goods and services tax fully refunded under a Liberal and National government. Why has this Government not taken that lead?

All this huge tax rip-off amounts to is a fairly minor concession and a reduction in a massive consumption tax levied upon one of our most essential business inputs. When one stops to think of how transport, fuel, parts and all other associated transport costs impact on the price of every product going right down through the manufacturing and retail chain, then one starts to realise the huge burden that Australian consumers are carrying today.

No-one really needs an economics degree to realise that the added purchase and running costs of commercial vehicles impact right across the production chain and add to the cost of every consumer item that is packaged, shelved and delivered by a vehicle. Once again, we can ask the question: why has the Government walked away from providing real and tangible tax relief to those areas of the community?

One of the worst features of sales tax is its complexity—my colleague Senator Short referred to that a moment ago—which is so often the result of political manipulation rather than any kind of economic necessity. Twelve months ago sales tax was levied at zero, 10 per cent, 20 per cent and 30 per cent, with a special, politically driven 50 per cent impost applying to so-called luxury vehicles. Once again, there was no rhyme or reason why that 50 per cent tax had to be put on luxury vehicles. It was nothing to do with the actual features of the vehicle; it all had to do with price. There was some magical price at which a vehicle suddenly attracted a 50 per cent tax. No justification has ever been offered by this Government as to why whole ranges of items should attract tax at 20 per cent rather than 10 per cent, or 30 per cent rather than 20 per cent.

Twelve months ago the then Hawke-Keating Government had to acknowledge the failure of its artificial envy tax rate on luxury vehicles. The Government had to withdraw it because it was having an enormous impact right across the board. It was actually losing revenue and driving imported vehicle dealers to the wall. But then again, when there are a million people unemployed, what is a few more? The Government does not seem to worry. Having regained a slight measure of simplicity, we are now back to five levels of consumption tax because this Government is out to buy some votes.

It is nonsense for this Government to maintain that it does not have a form of consumption tax. Certainly it is better for this Government to play politics by lowering a tax rather than raising it, as occurred in 1990, but the Labor principle is the same—economic sense comes last, and a very poor last at that.

Simplicity in indirect taxation is not an ideal merely to achieve tidiness. The simpler a system is, the better it is understood by the business proprietor and the consumer, and the harder it is for governments to manipulate it. I remind the Senate that back in 1983, prior to this Government coming to office, Mr Keating promised a simplified tax system. Yet we have another almost 20,000 pages of tax laws, regulations and alterations somewhere along the line. If that is not a nightmare for businesses to deal with, what is? If it is not a nightmare for businesses to deal with five levels of hidden consumption tax, what is? This Government keeps on saying that it does not have a consumption tax. Because of the complexity of sales tax, which is hidden from the consumer, it has been very easy for this Labor Government to increase its overall level by extending it to a greater range of items.

Under this Labor Government, the sales tax burden per head of population, even adjusted for inflation, has risen from $480 to $760 per head—a rise of 60 per cent for which not 1c of compensation has been given. Once again, it is absolute nonsense for this Government to maintain that its taxation is not regressive; it is. To increase hidden consumption taxes by 60 per cent and not give anyone another cent in his or her pay packet is absolute, downright stealth.

Labor cannot deny that it has maintained and greatly increased what is now a 5.4 per cent tax on final consumption right across the board. The problem is that this amounts to an 8.1 per cent tax on transport, a 7.4 per cent tax on housing expenditure, a 5.9 per cent tax on personal care and a 3.3 per cent tax on food and beverages—which Labor pretends will be taxed for the first time under the goods and services tax—and even a 1.3 per cent tax on medical services. All these taxes mount up and go right across the board.

It is only fair to comment that the goods and services tax will in no way increase the cost of medical services as it will be zero rated, with the goods and services tax refunded for all the inputs into the delivery of the service, but the patient will pay no goods and services tax. I wish I had a dollar for every time I have heard the Labor Party—and, of course, its acolytes—bleating around the traps that we are going to tax health and education. That is simply not true. They know it not to be true, yet it does not stop them repeating it ad nauseam.

Making family cars cheaper for a while does not alter the fact that, under this Labor Government, sales tax has become a true consumption tax and one that, unlike the goods and services tax, is very regressive. It is a fact that the poorest 10 per cent of Australian families with children pay 4.2 per cent of their income in sales tax while families in the highest 10 per cent income range pay 2.9 per cent of their income. Who is this Government favouring? It is certainly favouring the higher income earners, not the lower ones. Yet it keeps on bleating that we are supposedly providing a tax system for the wealthy to penalise the poor. It is not true. Every fiddling, deceitful piece of sales tax legislation put up by this Government means a continuation of an illogical, regressive system that hits the consumer and poisons the economy.

This Keating Labor Government expects the applause of farmers because $10m has been made available for crop planting assistance. But what recognition is the rural sector getting in this Bill? Not one cent. Farmers will continue to pay $170m each year on such essential business items as trucks and utilities because Labor has failed to include those items in the new 15 per cent sales tax rate. Therein, once again, lies the difference. The Government has refused to take one cent of sales tax away from the rural sector with regard to vehicles. We are going to take it all away from the rural sector so that it can get back to being productive. Farmers, certainly, will continue to be the group with the highest incidence of sales tax, at a rate of 6.8 per cent.

It is claimed that we are a weird mob, and one could only agree. To place the biggest tax consumption burden on battling exporters who are not free to pass on the costs is absolutely ludicrous, and that is what this Government is doing to the farmers. I suppose it would be more true to say that we have a weird government, prepared to perpetuate such a situation with the average broadacre farm losing $27,500 in 1992-93. Labor can only misrepresent and vilify the honest, practical alternatives that the Liberal and National parties are proposing to the damaging, outworn, hidden consumption tax that is being rejigged in this Bill. The Government does not want to hear the truth about a consistent, visible 15 per cent goods and services tax that will be refundable as a business input and will thus end the present distorting and cascading effect.

I would like for a moment to focus on the claim by the Labor Party that food and clothing are not taxed at the moment. That statement is absolutely wrong, wrong, wrong. Any product on the supermarket shelf generally has four stages of production: the farmer, the manufacturer, the wholesaler and the supermarket. This is a product, for example, that the Government is now saying is untaxed. Let us look at it. The box is taxed, the printing on the box is taxed, an inserter in the box is taxed, the shelf the box sits on is taxed, the carton in which the box comes is taxed, the printing on the carton is taxed, the pallet on which the carton sits is taxed, the label on the shelf is taxed, the floor covering in the supermarket is taxed, the light globe to see your way around the supermarket is taxed, the cash register is taxed, the scanner is taxed—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the fork-lift.

—The fork-lift is taxed, the shopping trolley is taxed, the scales are taxed and the refrigeration is taxed. All of those taxes apply right throughout the supermarket. The price labelling gun is taxed. Absolutely everything is taxed. Of course, the supermarket then has to pay payroll tax as well. To say that groups such as Coles and Woolworths do not pay payroll tax is just absurd. The Labor Party says that small businesses do not pay sales tax. Why does not the Government be honest for a change and say that it picks up the payroll tax that is paid by large businesses and passed on to small businesses?

PARA.TAB: Before we leave the supermarket, let us remember that the product had to get to the supermarket; it was transported on a truck that was taxed, which had tyres that were taxed, a battery that is taxed and fuel that is taxed at 26c a litre. All the other parts are taxed. Yet the Government has the audacity to say that that product sitting on the supermarket shelf is not taxed.

Let us go back to the wholesaler. The shelving is taxed. Once again, the fork-lift is taxed, the labels are taxed, the cash registers are taxed, the computers are taxed, the light globes are taxed, the trucks, the tyres and everything else is taxed. Fuel is taxed at 26c a litre. The invoices are taxed, the printing of the invoices is taxed and the list goes on. These are two levels at which the Government claims this one item sitting on the supermarket shelf is not taxed.

Then we go to the manufacturer. All the items that are used in the production chain—all the production equipment—are taxed. Once again, the computers are taxed and the trucks, the parts, the fuel and the tyres are taxed. The light globes are taxed and the invoices and the printing by the manufacturers are taxed. But let us remember that, according to Labor, food is not taxed. This is what is happening to one product sitting on the supermarket shelf.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about payroll tax?

—As my colleague Senator Walters says, `What about payroll tax'? Payroll tax impacts all the way along the line as well, from the manufacturer who has to pay the tax. I was in Karratha the other day talking to a fellow who was operating a business up there. He quite deliberately does not employ too many people because he is on the borderline of paying payroll tax. He can afford to have more people to do the work but he cannot afford to pay the payroll tax. So we are stopping people from being employed.

PARA.TAB: Let us come back to our little product sitting on the supermarket shelf. Let us go back to the farmer. Say, for example, that there is a box of weeties sitting on the shelf. The header that cuts the wheat is taxed. The tyres are taxed. All of those sorts of things are taxed. We have a problem right the way down the chain because many of those things are taxed.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got two out of two wrong. How are you going now?

—The Parliamentary Secretary says that I have got two wrong. I ask him: two out of how many? Does he want me to run through the list relating to the supermarket again? Seeing that he is deaf, we will go right through the list again. The box, the printing, the carton, the inserter, the shelves, the labels, the floor coverings, the cash register, the scanner, the trucks, the tyres, the parts, the fuel and the oil—absolutely everything—are taxed. They are all taxed. The manufacturer is taxed. Yet the Government is saying to me that this food item in the supermarket is not taxed. What nonsense!

PARA.TAB: The difference, of course, is that we are going to abolish all of those taxes right the way down the line and the goods and services tax will be fully refunded. It is simply dishonest in the extreme to say that food is not taxed at the moment. The same, of course, applies to clothing. The coat-hangers that the clothes hang on, the shelves, the racks, the floor coverings, the cash registers, the security systems and everything else are taxed. The only thing that is not taxed at the point of sale is the little bit of material that goes into the clothes.

What nonsense it is to say that clothing is not taxed. If one goes all the way back through the production chain, one will see that it is taxed, taxed, taxed. It starts with the person who gets the wool or the cotton or whatever by motor vehicle or some form of transport; that is taxed. The material has to go to the manufacturer; once again, the transport is taxed and the cost passed on to the next person. It then goes to the wholesaler. The transport is again taxed and the cost passed on to the next person. It goes to the retailer, transport is again taxed and the cost passed on again to whom? The consumer. Yet the Government says that clothing is not taxed.
The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has come a long way from 12 May 1985, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the cost of not beginning a substantial reform program is now unacceptably high.

Why will he not accept a reform program that is fair not only on businesses but on all Australians to start making us competitive? It is absolutely absurd that he will simply bury his head in the sand and tell the people of Australia that for the first time they will have a tax on food and clothing. Nonsense; they already have it.

PARA.TAB: On 5 June, the Prime Minister stated that tax reform `will allow a more rational indirect tax system than the current anomaly-ridden wholesale sales tax, which has multiple rates, numerous exemptions, and fails to tax the services sector'. How he changed his tune from 5 June 1985 to 26 February 1992, when he would not make the alterations that are necessary because his political master, the ACTU, would not let him. But that does not stop this Government going out and rabbiting on non-stop in the most dishonest way about there being no taxes on certain items at the moment.

The Prime Minister also said that `our existing tax system impairs economic growth'. What has changed? The only thing that has changed since 1985 is that things have become worse. We now have a million-plus people out of work and we have so many people facing the real fact of probably never getting a job again. That has to be reversed, and it will be reversed only by providing a tax structure that gives business incentive to operate.

I return to the situation of the operator backup at Karratha. If payroll tax were abolished today, the employer there would employ more people tomorrow. Why will this Government not do anything about it? Because its political master, the ACTU, will not let it. The ACTU wants more wage increases, and hang the consequence of that. The mere fact that businesses cannot pay any more and that giving a lot of employees more wage increases at the moment will push more people into higher payroll tax levels, higher training guarantee levels and higher taxation generally does not matter. The Government is quite happy not to remove these taxes and instead pushes them on further and further. What we have to look at is the fact that this Government does not want to make change, does not want to create jobs, does not want to provide a structure in this country whereby we can become competitive.

In short, I suppose that the Prime Minister has admitted every proposition on which the Liberal and National parties are proceeding on the path of indirect tax reform. He has agreed to it all in the past. The sad part is that he will not agree to it now. He knows the benefits of replacing sales tax with a goods and services tax because he was the original promoter of such a tax. But through political opportunism and sheer cowardice, this Government is not prepared to let Australia endure a proper tax system. It wants it to endure an unjust system of a hidden indirect tax: the Labor Party's consumption tax. The sweetener contained in this Bill only underscores the need to abolish sales tax. Why is this being done so selectively here to benefit so few people and not the country as a whole?

PARA.TAB: I am highlighting the ridiculous situation of the stupidity and the inconsistencies of the present wholesale sales tax which is just riddled with so many different fiddles around legal definitions of medications, marketing and advertising. TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody listening to Senator Tambling's contribution would have realised that the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1992 is actually about reducing the price of cars to Australian consumers.
—But not to business.

—Senator Walters is incompetent. Of course, if business buys cars—they do, Senator Walters knows they do and they spend millions on them—they benefit from the reduced prices. Business thinks that it is great and that is why the Opposition is so upset. This Bill will also help the motor vehicle industry; it likes it and that is why the Opposition is so upset. This Bill will improve the quality of the Australian car fleet, increasing motor vehicle efficiency and reducing pollution. The Australian people like it and that is why the Opposition is so upset. I am not surprised that this has been such a passionate debate—it has been delightful to see. There have been absurd propositions and erroneous assertions. The real problem is that the Opposition has suddenly realised that the Australian people have a choice, that they do not like its GST and are rejecting it. That is quite clear.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza interjecting—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! Senator Panizza can interject from his seat only with the tolerance of the Chair. He will not interject from the aisles. There is too much interjection at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has to tell the truth.
—Order! Senator Walters, I indicated that there were too many interjections. When I finish, there is no need for you to interject again. I call the Minister.

—It is quite interesting to see this enhanced sensitivity. It is not hard to work out why. We need only read recent copies of any newspaper or magazine in Australia, particularly Time or the Bulletin, to see why the Opposition is so concerned.

PARA.TAB: The GST is very different from the wholesale sales tax in a number of ways. Anyone who pretended that there were no indirect taxes in Australia would be misleading the people. But no-one has ever pretended that. There is an indirect tax that raises about $9 billion; it does not raise $27 billion. That is the significant difference. The wholesale sales tax operates differently from the GST: it raises less money, it is less regressive, the redistributive consequences are not as bad. A change from the wholesale sales tax to the GST would be regressive, unfair and undesirable. That is why the GST is being rejected by the people.

It is also true that the wholesale sales tax distinguishes a different tax rate for different products—so does the GST, but it has less capacity to distinguish, particularly in the way in which the Opposition proposes to introduce it. The Opposition will have zero-rated exemption and 15 per cent. There are differences, but it is much more broad brushed—the 15 per cent applies to many things to which the wholesale sales tax does not directly apply.

Notwithstanding the passionate invocation, sometimes incorrect, of all the taxes that apply but fall on products on supermarket shelves, it is true—no-one could deny it—that income tax, wholesale sales tax and every other tax have an impact on the price of every good produced. That is true. It is true that income tax affects the price of products. That is true—it always will be. What is fundamentally true and what everybody knows is that the goods and services tax, as the Opposition proposes, will put up the price of food and clothing. That is what the Opposition is concerned about.

SPEECH.PARA: Those opposite know that that is true; their document says that the price of food and clothing will go up.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not say that.

—Of course, those opposite say that; their document makes it absolutely clear. The Opposition cannot possibly raise $27 billion without the price of anything going up. Dr Hewson at least has the honesty to acknowledge that these prices will go up. We are now having an argument about how much they will go up. At least we have got over that silly hurdle that prices will not go up—of course they will go up. The price of food will go up.
—The Treasury says 3.7.

—Order! Senator Walters, I have spoken to you before about interjections. There were four people interjecting on the Minister. Minister, it would be better if you spoke through the Chair. I do not think you would then invite as many interjections.

—I will certainly direct my remarks through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I doubt that it will reduce the number of interjections. Those opposite do not like what I am saying; that is causing the concern, rather than to whom I am saying it. It is absolutely clear that those prices will go up. I have put into the Hansard record before the extent to which various products will go up—now is not the time to do it again. Prices will go up.
—What will go down?

—Maseratis, Ferraris—all of those things will go down. The family car will go up and the Maserati will go down. That is unquestionably true. If a 15 per cent wholesale sales tax is replaced by a 15 per cent GST, the price will go up. The arithmetic is obvious. There will be an increase in the price of food and clothing. It is as straightforward as that. That is what the Opposition is concerned about and it is what the Australian people are concerned about.

PARA.TAB: A few other interesting things have been said in this debate. Senator Tambling came in and tried to make a great point about how bad it was to have a wholesale sales tax on an item. But, unfortunately, he had to acknowledge that the item would probably be more expensive under the GST because it will apply to that product as well. That was a very short contribution.

We then had the argument that the GST has no cascading effect. We have had this debate in here before; I am not going to go over it all again. It is quite clearly untrue. The industry most adversely affected by the cascading effect through the exemptions in GST is the tourist industry—the one industry that we should not be hitting.

The Opposition talked about reducing the cost to business of taxes. We have 70,000 businesses paying wholesale sales tax; 1.5 million businesses would pay GST. There are in excess of 1.4 million companies, for whom every minute compliance cost of this GST is an extra cost on those businesses. Many of those small businesses cannot and will not be able to afford that. All of the evidence from New Zealand makes that absolutely clear. The articles that have been written by accountants and others on the cost to business of running those taxes makes it clear. I know that those opposite do not like to hear it, but it is nevertheless absolutely true, as you would be only too well aware, Mr Acting Deputy President.

Just in case anybody has forgotten—because I have been responding to what was said in the second reading debate—we are actually talking about a Bill to reduce the tax on cars to improve the motor vehicle industry and to improve the quality of our motor vehicle fleet by replacement, which will improve transport efficiency and reduce pollution. For that reason, we are of course pleased to be introducing this legislation. I know that there has to be some delay in the committee stage because of a drafting problem with the Opposition amendment. I am not seeking to score a point because what the Opposition is trying to do is a complex matter. Although I do not envisage, on anything I have seen to this time, that we will be supporting the Opposition's amendment, I do not wish to proceed on the basis of just a drafting problem. Let us defer a little to try to get what is before us correct and then deal with it on its merits, rather than deal just with methods of drafting, et cetera.

That is essentially the second reading debate as we see it. It is a plus for the consumer; it is a plus for the manufacturer; it is a plus for the nation; therefore it must be supported, and we will worry about the committee stage when it arises later today. I commend the Bill to the House for its innate merit and because it indicates once again that flexibility and capacity to distinguish and to be used as an effective implement which the wholesale sales tax has and which the goods and services tax does not have.
