SPEECH.PARA: My colleague Dr Woods, in the House of Representatives, outlined the Opposition's position regarding the original Senate amendments made on 11 December. As the new amendments moved by the Government cover Senate amendments Nos 1 to 5, we are not unhappy to accept the change in the wording that is being put forward. Basically, the Government's amendments achieve the same purpose outlined in Senate amendments 1 to 5, except that the groups to be represented on the board are not named specifically.

PARA.TAB: However, the amendments passed in the House of Representatives do not meet all the concerns of the Opposition. We do not believe that they deal adequately with the issue of representation on the board of the Institute by the Australian Medical Association, the Australian Private Hospitals Association or the Australian Hospital Association. The Opposition firmly believes that there should be a clear and defined opportunity for these bodies to have a representative on the board. The amendments passed by the House of Representatives provide for a nominee to be a person with knowledge of the needs of consumers of health services, a person with knowledge of the needs of consumers of welfare services, and a person with knowledge of the needs of consumers of housing assistance services. The final position provided for in the amendments is for a person with expertise in research into public health issues.

It could be argued by some that nominees from the AMA, the APHA or the AHA would not fit into the first three categories of persons and so would be competing with each other and the Public Health Association of Australia to be represented in that final position. In fact, the Opposition has some doubts that the AMA, the APHA and the AHA would fit into the fourth category. We believe that it is appropriate for these bodies to be represented on the board.

The AMA served on the interim board. It was not invited to serve on the first board, nor was it consulted. Given the fact that doctors are in control of $4 billion worth of Commonwealth funds and are involved in a whole range of issues, including statistical analysis, one would think that they would be an appropriate group to be represented in this institute. The APHA or the AHA also should have the opportunity of being represented. In 1987, the Minister was requested to include someone from the hospital sector on the board. In 1991, when the terms of the first board members expired, he said that he would consider the matter. Obviously, it looks like he has not done so.

Hospitals account for almost half of the total health expenditure in Australia. In the committee stage of the Australian Institute of Health Amendment Bill in December we indicated the relevance and importance of having a representative from the hospital sector here. This is not only so that hospitals can have input but also, if the Institute of Health is to gather the statistics that it needs in the hospital area, it really ought to have the health providers on side. They can provide figures when asked for them, or they can provide figures in a very cooperative and proactive way. I am sure that if they were recognised by being on this board, they would be more inclined to cooperate with the Institute of Health than they would otherwise be, given the fact that they have no input to that board. For the sake of having a good working relationship with the hospital sector, they ought to be represented.

I believe that the amendments as they now stand do not adequately address the issue of having the health providers—the doctors and/or the hospitals—on the board. I thought Senator Tate was going to be here in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is coming.

—I thought my glasses were so dirty that I could not see him. I had hoped that Senator Tate would give some assurance that those groups would be considered. They are listed in the schedule, but how on earth they would fit into the categories that now exist leaves much to the imagination. I doubt very much whether, when we see that board in its final form, it will include them. I ask the Minister to look at that and see whether there is any way of including them. To have four consumer groups and no providers is a nonsense—an absolute nonsense.

PARA.TAB: I do not know what happened over Christmas, but Senator Lees had a great turnaround in her views. The Opposition put up some amendments and the Democrats put up some amendments. We agreed with their amendments. We were not all that happy to have that many consumers but we believed, in the interests of the consumers and in the interests of the hospitals, that we would go the way we did in agreeing to those amendments. What did Senator Lees say about our amendments which included the hospitals and the doctors? She said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Australian Democrats will be supporting these amendments. We believe that these two organisations will offer a valuable range of views, expertise, knowledge and experience. Therefore, we will be supporting the amendments.

Senator Lees has had her mind changed since then, because the Government got at her. What did the Government do? It came back—it was a very smart little move—with amendments that suited the Democrats, and it omitted the ones that we wanted to amend. So what do the Democrats do? They cave in. Typical.

PARA.TAB: I was very disillusioned with Senator Lees, and I said that to her. She did a deal with the Government, she got her way, and then she said, `Well, bad luck to the hospitals. Bad luck to the AMA. We've got our consumers on and that's all we care'. The Government was smart; I will admit that. Somebody in the Department said, `We'll trick them. We'll fix it. We'll give them an amendment the Democrats agree with and then we'll omit the coalition'—which is supporting the inclusion of doctors and the inclusion of hospitals, because we think it would make a better Institute of Health—`and that will all be fine'.

The Democrats have changed their mind. Senator Lees is saying, `We believe that these two organisations will offer a valuable range of views, expertise, knowledge and experience'. Somehow that view has changed, and it has changed because the Government has given the Democrats the amendments they want. It is all very well to have a change of mind over Christmas, but we will see what happens to this Institute of Health and see how well some of the policies of the Democrats go. They have put out some interesting policies on health: the fact that we will no longer have private nursing homes or hostels. We can see from that what attitude they have towards the private health system. I suppose that is another reason for their sea change.

I believe that the amendments, as they now exist, do not address the needs of the Institute of Health as it should be constituted. It is a furphy for the Minister to say that 17 people are too many; that two more will make the Committee unworkable. That is a nonsense. I believe that the inclusion of those two groups, those two health care providers—the Australian Medical Association and/or the Australian Private Hospitals' Association—would have meant that we would have had a much better Institute of Health.

What we are on about is delivering a better health service to the nation. To have the two groups that are the greatest spenders of government money on health not included in the Institute of Health is an absolute nonsense.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —To start with, let us go back into history and look at how all of this began. It was, in fact, the Democrats who realised late last year that, under the new legislation that we have before us, consumer groups had been excluded from the board of the Australian Institute of Health, and I should add that that was without any consultation with the groups themselves, not even any consultation with those groups who were on the original board. They were simply omitted. Certainly, there was no consultation with the groups which one would have thought would have been considered, such as the Australian Council of Social Service—ACOSS.

PARA.TAB: After talking to the groups concerned we put up a series of amendments to include on the board the Consumers Health Forum, the Australian Council of Social Service and National Shelter. Let us not forget that we are endeavouring to expand the role of the board, to collect not just health statistics and information but to go out and collect information on general welfare issues and housing issues in the hope that we can get a far broader picture of the overall well-being of Australians, and then, hopefully, assist government itself in making far more effective decisions as to what policies it should be pursuing.

The Opposition amendments would include the AMA, the Australian Public Health Association and a representative from either the Australian Hospitals Association or the Australian Private Hospitals Association. I stand by my comments that I made at that time that, yes, they will be valuable, would be valuable, could be valuable, members of the board. This is why we refused to take the changes that were made in the House of Representatives, because we believe that we had to have listed in the schedule specific organisations, including all of those organisations I have just mentioned. It was with considerable difficulty that we finally got the Government to agree with our point of view. I must note here that we also managed to get the Brotherhood of St Laurence listed as another organisation that can nominate members for consideration for inclusion on the board.

After the amendments went through last year, the Bill went back to the House of Representatives and we assumed that we would hear no more about it. Up until a week ago we thought that at least we were going to come to some reasonable arrangement. However, it was very evident when we began to listen to some comments from the Department that the Government was simply not going to take all our amendments on board.

TALK.START.PARA: —They tricked you.

—The bottom line is that, if we pass this back again to the House of Representatives, we will end up with the board we have now. In other words, we will have a board that is still looking only at issues relating to health.

PARA.TAB: While some of the organisations, one in particular, have already told us they are happy with that, the Democrats are certainly not happy to see go by the board the extended role that we now have a real possibility of achieving, namely, statistics collection from welfare and housing groups. The Minister told us very clearly that he was simply not prepared to wear the amendments that we had pursued.

Looking at the amendments that we now have, I think we must focus on the issue—not who moved what amendment when, but what really will be in the best long term interests of the people whom we are supposedly here to represent. We believe that we have reached a compromise position, though not perhaps what all of us in this place would want.

Some people are still obviously very intent on having some additional people further encouraged. But I wish to read through, for the purposes of this discussion, the list detailing the organisations able to nominate: the Australian Council of Social Service; the Australian Hospitals Association; the Australian Medical Association; the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation; the Australian Private Hospitals Association; the Brotherhood of St Laurence; the Catholic Social Welfare Commission; the Consumers Health Forum of Australia; National Shelter; and the Public Health Association of Australia.

It apparently is indeed the intention of some of these groups to work together to collectively nominate either an individual for the Minister's consideration or two or three people for consideration. So I would recommend that Senator Patterson rethink her strong stand. I hope that, to give some credit to the Minister, he will indeed select the best possible people for the board.

I wish to spell out that no deal has been done. I do not get anything out of agreeing with the Minister on this point. In fact, I do not like an awful lot of things that sometimes come out of the Department, but I do not have a closed mind when it comes to reaching a reasonable agreed position. I am not prepared to ditch all of this because we will not get what we initially decided was our point of view.

In this instance, I have accepted what the Minister is saying about the composition of the board. The Government amendments achieve what was always the main aim of the Democrats, that is, to maintain adequate consumer representation on the board, and for that reason we will be supporting the Government amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am absolutely appalled at the naivety of the Democrats. Let me make it very clear—and I hope Senator Lees will listen—that the schedule refers to bodies that `may' nominate board members. Senator Lees read out the list. The Australian Council of Social Service is one group on the list; it will fit in. It is definitely nominated because the Government wants it in.
—No, it will not.

—Yes, it will; it can come under the category of a body representing consumers of welfare services. The Australian Hospital Association is not included in the amendments the Government wants put forward. The Australian Council of Social Service is, but not the hospitals. The Australian Medical Association is not included in the list that the Government wants. The Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation could come under the social welfare category if it wanted to. The Australian Private Hospitals Association is not listed.

PARA.TAB: The Brotherhood of St Laurence comes under the heading of a representative of consumers of welfare services. The Catholic Social Welfare Commission also comes under that heading. One could not say that the AMA or the hospitals come under that heading. Then we have the Consumers Health Forum of Australia. Again, that group comes under the category of a representative of consumers of health services. National Shelter comes under the category of representative of consumers of housing assistance services. The Public Health Association comes under the heading of a peak body promoting research into public health issues.

The AMA may be able to put someone up for membership, but the Government has said that it objects very strongly to having the AMA involved and that it will not go ahead with these amendments if the Democrats support us. The Government has said that it will revert to the original amendments. If the Democrats insist on the AMA and the hospitals being included, what likelihood is there that the Minister will accept the AMA's and the hospitals' inclusion?

Let us not forget the original debate on this matter. You were in here, Senator Lees, when Senator Crowley said that the AMA should not be included and had no right to be included. You are being naive when you say that the AMA can put up a member. Senator Crowley made it very clear. Indeed, she said that the AMA should not be there and why should the Doctors Reform Society be there? You remember that, do you not?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Doctors Reform Society is not listed.
—You remember that.
—Order! Senator Walters, it would help if you directed your remarks through the chair.

—Senator Crowley made it extremely clear that she believed that there should be no doctor representation on the board. Let us not be naive. The Government has doctor bashed forever. Mr Duncan Kerr, the member for Denison, in Tasmania, has been doctor bashing ever since he was elected. Senator Tate will remember the inaccurate and false figures Mr Duncan Kerr put out on doctors bulkbilling in his electorate of Denison. He will remember how doctor bashing went on in that electorate for so long. Last week Mr Howe was in Tasmania. Mr Duncan Kerr had sent all the doctors in Denison an invitation to come to a dinner and listen to the Minister.
—For a price.

—Yes, for a price. And what happened? He had to plead, `I cannot get the doctors to come. We only have a couple of doctors coming.' Mr Duncan Kerr was told that he had built his career on doctor bashing and, for heaven's sake, what did he expect? Do honourable senators know how many doctors turned up? Twelve doctors out of the whole of Denison turned up, and they only turned up because they were so hostile. Mr Howe had a very uncomfortable meeting with them. There were not only 12 members of the medical profession there—all the departmental officers were told they had better turn up to make up the numbers.
—Did the Department pay for them?

—I do not know whether the Department paid for their dinner, but they were certainly told that they had to turn up. I do not know who paid for them. They may have been forced to pay for themselves. I have no idea. As I said, they were told that they had to turn up to make up the numbers.

PARA.TAB: Because the questions at the dinner were so hostile to the Minister after he had come all the way down to Tasmania, Mr Duncan Kerr tried to allow only four questions to be asked. He said he had a secret agenda; he wanted to get home. The questions to the Minister and to the member for Denison were so hostile that only four questions were permitted. Mr Duncan Kerr gave his vote of thanks and the questions started rolling in again. As the Minister could hardly walk out, further questions were asked and answered.

It is a disgrace that this Government has decried doctors all over Australia to such an extent that it will not even allow—for the good of Australia, for the good of health care consumers and for the good of every Australian—medical practitioners, the AMA, to be represented on the board of the Australian Institute.

Can Senator Lees tell me how the health care consumers, who are to be represented on the board of this Institute, can understand what the AMA is putting forward? Likewise, how can the AMA understand the consumers' point of view if it is not there to listen? Consumers may come up with all sorts of statistics, as Senator Lees has said, but the AMA is not permitted to be there to hear them. They may come up with all sorts of complaints, but the Government will not allow the AMA to be there to listen to them. Consumer groups may come up with all sorts of complaints about hospitals, about the treatment by hospitals or about the enormous waiting lists that this Government uses as price control. No hospital representatives will be there to listen to them because the Government will not permit the doctors or the hospitals to be represented on the board of the Australian Institute of Health.

How can we have an Australian Institute of Health when the doctors and the hospitals are forbidden to have representatives on the board? How can we possibly have an Australian Institute of Health when we have only consumer groups, social welfare groups, housing assistance groups, consumers of health services and peak research bodies on the board? If it were not for the Government's bigotry and, I suppose, philosophy against the doctors, it could be done.

The Government has mucked up Medicare to such an extent that the previous Prime Minister would not use it. It was not good enough for his health or for his wife's health. It is not good enough for me. I take the trouble to privately insure—and so do thousands of pensioners. They struggle like mad to pay for private insurance because they know that if they do not they will end up on the end of the waiting lists. The Government knows that the figures are correct.

The Minister, Mr Howe, on a talkback program, was told, `Medicare could not be all that good if the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and his wife would not use it'. Mr Howe said, `It is good enough for me. The last time I went into hospital, I went into a public hospital'. He did not add that he was a private patient. Medicare is not good enough for the Government and its Ministers, but the Government insists that it is good enough for ordinary Australians. It will not allow people to privately insure for the cost of their doctors' bills. Its viciousness leads it to being so opposed to the AMA and the hospitals that it will not even permit them to have representation on the board of the Australian Institute of Health.

Senator Lees has been extremely naive. Senator Lees told us that she believes the AMA and the hospitals should be on the board. As Senator Patterson said, she agreed with us. We got together and we said, `Okay, we believe that these are the two groups that should be on the board. There should be representation from the consumer groups but the AMA, the doctors and the hospitals should also be represented so that there is an interchange of views and so that they can listen to each other'. Senator Lees agreed with us.

Then the Government got at Senator Lees and said, `If you insist upon this, we will not go ahead with this legislation and we will revert to the original legislation'. Senator Lees said, `Well, we can't do that'. As the Democrats so often do, she has fallen for the Government's trap. The Democrats have gone back on their word. They say, `Well, I suppose bad legislation is preferable to none'. It is the worst of two evils and Senator Lees is nodding in agreement.

We on this side of the chamber will not go for that. We want the best legislation possible. We still say to Senator Lees that we cannot have an Institute of Health without full representation of consumer groups, the medical profession and the hospitals. If we do not have that full representation then, for heaven's sake, we may as well not proceed with the Institute and get the Australian Bureau of Statistics to do the job for us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will contribute briefly. I wish to ask the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) a particular question and hope that he will answer it for me. We are at the committee stage of the Australian Institute of Health Amendment Bill. It does seem remarkable that the Government should pretend to be seeking to establish an institute of any value to this community without doctors and hospitals being represented on it.

PARA.TAB: Having listened to the debate and having read the material that the Government has put out, I can only conclude that this is a little politicking exercise to please some of the groups in the community that it has a special relationship with. There is no real regard, of course, for the consumers of health care; there is no real regard, of course, for those who are supplying and are responsible for health care. I am particularly disappointed at the attitude of the Australian Democrats, particularly when we think of the language they normally use in terms of their concern for people. As they have backed away from their original position, one can only ask what their agenda is as well.

I wish to refer in particular to a letter written to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) by the Australian Council on the Ageing. I ask the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs to tell us why the Council is not included in the list of bodies which may nominate. The letter says:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Howe,

PARA.TAB: The Australian Council on the Ageing was perturbed to read Schedule 1 to the Australian Institute of Health Amendment Bill 1991 in which are listed bodies that may nominate Institute Board members. The Australian Council on the Ageing has been omitted. It was announced in the 1991 Federal Budget that the Australian Institute of Health was to have an enhanced role in the collation, analysis and publishing of social welfare data (including that for older people).

Prior to the amending Bill, the Australian Council on the Ageing had provided the nomination for the Consumers' Health Forum to the Australian Institute of Health Board. This reflects the commitment of this Council to the Institute's work and the confidence the Consumers' Health Forum of Australia has in this Council.

The Australian Council on the Ageing has a long history in undertaking and reviewing research relevant to older people and has numerous individuals who can be called upon to advise in ageing research activities.
The Council would seek your support in correcting the omission through an amendment to the Schedule to the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The letter is dated 17 March 1992 and is signed by Kath Bourke, the eminent President of the Council. I hope that the Minister will be able to explain why this important group has been left out.

PARA.TAB: I think the Minister would know that the population of Australia is ageing and that health is of vital importance, not only to those who are ageing but also to those who are paying for the enormous cost that the health system currently places upon taxpayers in this country. To leave out the Australian Council on the Ageing, the one group which is dedicated and committed to health care for the ageing, seems quite extraordinary to me.

The list of those who are included has been mentioned this morning during the debate. I did not hear of one that is exclusively committed to the health of the ageing in the way that this group is. As this letter has stated, the Council has been involved. I hope that the Minister will be able to say what Mr Howe has said in answer to the letter and why it is that this group is not included in the list of bodies which may nominate Institute members. I can only question the Government's motives. As I have said, perhaps the Council on the Ageing is just not one of those groups that appeal to Mr Howe. He certainly has not put forward a list that can give any confidence to anybody that the Government's real agenda is quality health care.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In replying to comments made by honourable senators during this committee stage debate on the Australian Institute of Health Amendment Bill 1991, I certainly will not rise to the bait that has been thrown into the chamber by Senator Walters in her particular contribution, because she ranged outside the concerns of this Bill. Her remarks concerning the Australian Democrats were very patronising—`matronising', I suppose—in relation to the fact that the Democrats have come to an agreement with the Government over the way in which the membership of the board of this very important Institute ought be constituted.

PARA.TAB: It is necessary, though, to say that I believe Senator Walters was presuming too much in her statements—for example, that doctors and hospitals would be `forbidden to be on the board'; that was her expression.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are excluded.

—I do not believe that that is the case. The fact is that the nominations that may come forward from the 10 groups were listed in a schedule which included the Australian Medical Association and the Australian Hospital Association. It can be expected that nominations will come forward from those bodies. It is outrageous to make a presumption in the terms that Senator Walters did about the response of the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) to the list of names that will come forward from those organisations. As I say, I believe that Senator Walters's fears have been stated in an exaggerated form and in the context of a much wider argument about her view of the Government's dealing with general practitioners, in particular, and perhaps the medical profession generally.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the bodies which have been nominated represent a very good span of those who have such knowledge as would enable them to put forward persons of eminence who are able to assist the Institute in conducting its various functions. The Australian Council of Social Service, the Australian Hospital Association, the Australian Medical Association, the Australian Pensioners' and Superannuants' Federation, the Australian Private Hospitals Association, the Brotherhood of St Laurence, the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission, the Consumers Health Forum of Australia, the National Shelter and the Public Health Association of Australia Inc. can all put forward various names to the Minister.

The object of the exercise to start with was to move the Institute into areas such as housing. For that reason, there needed to be an expansion. This list of bodies that may nominate board members is a sensible way to deal with the expansion of the board. Senator Reid has properly asked whether those who have a particular concern with the interests of the aged in our community and their receiving of health care are properly represented. I suppose it is possible to list two, three, four, five or more organisations as nominating bodies in this respect. I imagine that bodies such as the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, the Catholic Social Welfare Commission, the Consumers Health Forum of Australia, perhaps the Australian Council of Social Service, although not as specifically, will have elements within them who would be able to understand the sorts of concerns that might otherwise be put by other bodies. I am quite sure that the interests of the aged in the operations of this Institute, in so far as it may have impact on the provision of health care to that sector of the population, can be adequately dealt with by the nominations coming forward from those bodies listed in the schedule.

I believe that the nomination process is a reasonable compromise—I think that is a term that has been used. It has sufficient merit to be regarded as a proper process and not simply as some sort of lowest common denominator result of exhaustion on the part of the Labor Party, the Minister's office and the Democrats, as has been portrayed. It is a sensible arrangement that will enable the Institute to undertake its extended task to focus on welfare and housing statistics, which it is being asked to be involved in. It is an important extension. The board needs to reflect that extension. This process allows that to take place. I believe that the proposal put by the Government ought to be supported and the Opposition amendment, for that reason, rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two questions I would like to ask Senator Tate. The first is in relation to clause 6(4)(c), as it will stand according to the Government's amendments. Will Senator Tate tell me which of those paragraphs would cover the Australian Medical Association and/or the Australian Private Hospitals Association and the Australian Hospital Association. Secondly, given all that Senator Tate has just said about the importance of having consumers of health services, consumers of welfare services, consumers of housing assistance services and a nominee who has expertise in research into public health issues, does he agree with Senator Lees' comment that if the Democrats were not to agree with the Government's amendments and agreed with ours, the Minister would revert to the situation as it now is—that is, that the status quo would exist? If the Minister has said that, every word of what Senator Tate has just said has been negated. I want to know, on the record, whether, if the Democrats support our amendment, the Government will say, `It is not on. We will revert to the Institute as it now stands.' That is the answer we want in the chamber now.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first question raised by Senator Patterson, it is clear to me on a cursory look at the proposed Government amendment that the Australian Medical Association and the providers of hospital care in the community would obviously have an opportunity to fall within categories such as those who have knowledge of the needs of consumers of health services—that seems to me to be very apparent—and those who have expertise in research into public health issues. I am quite sure that within the AMA and the various hospital associations, including private hospital associations, there would be great expertise about the needs of consumers of health services and knowledge of public health issues.
—Is that a legal interpretation of the Act?

—It would seem to me to be extraordinary if the AMA claimed that it could not speak sensibly about consumer health issues or about public health issues. I would imagine that it can and does. If it does, as I expect it does, obviously a member of the AMA, if that is what we are talking about—
—A representative.
—No, a member of the AMA would be able to be nominated by one of the nominating bodies. I do not see why that is precluded by that particular language.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, I came late into the chamber because the Bill was brought on quickly and I missed some interchange between Senator Lees and Senator Patterson on these matters. As I have made very clear, I do not believe that this is some lowest common denominator compromise brought about by exhaustion. I believe that it is a sensible proposal which obviously has had sufficient merit to be attractive to the Democrats as a proposal in its own right. I do not believe that taking up a fall back position if this Government amendment is rejected is a proper way to look at this situation. The Government puts this forward in good faith as a sensible proposal. The Democrats put it forward and have given their support to it as a sensible proposal. I believe that for that reason it will have the support of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the question I asked. I asked whether, if we were to agree with the Government's amendments and the Democrats were to support our amendments, which is what they are inclined to do, the threat that was made to the Democrats if they supported our amendments would be carried out—that is, that the status quo would exist. That is what the Democrats have been told. That is what Senator Lees told us in her speech. They are quite happy to support our amendments if the Government is not going to revert to the original Institute formation. I want the public record to show whether that is going to happen or not. We can go on here in the committee stage of the Bill until I get the answer to that question. Senate Lees wants the answer to that question, no doubt. I think she is quite interested in this little interchange we are having now.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was discussing this issue with the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) and not with Senator Tate, perhaps I could fill the Committee in. The Minister basically expressed the view to us that what the Senate had ended up with last year had far too much medical bias and was, in effect, again going to be looking at just medical issues as opposed to broadening the Institute out by looking at welfare and housing issues. He also was very concerned at the size of board we had ended up with. He did, however, concede the value of consumer representation. I add that we wish that this had been a part of the discussions last year; but it was not.

PARA.TAB: However, he argued very strongly that we not go beyond 15 and that we not get back to a situation where we would have medical bias as opposed to broad representation, where other groups were able to have their place on the board, providing a reasonable balance. We tried to negotiate for an additional number of people on the board at that stage. The comment was made to us: `We might as well stay where we are because we now have a board dealing with health issues. The board the Senate has set up is very heavily weighted towards looking at health again'.

I also agree with the way Senator Tate put it. We have reached a reasonable compromise and the board we will now be looking at has four possibilities for consumer representation. I really cannot understand this continuing argument that somehow the AMA will not be considered. It depends on who it puts forward. It may, indeed, decide to talk to such organisations as the Public Health Association.

Other organisations in the past have worked together to nominate someone for the board, and I think that was mentioned in the letter read out by Senator Reid. I cannot understand how we are automatically excluding health people. Obviously, two still are wanted, but not four. This is where we have come to an understanding and where the Government has finally agreed that the body should actually be listed. The big difference between where we were last year and where we are now is that then the Government would not agree at all that anyone should actually be listed in the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Patterson has said, Senator Tate has not answered the question which she put to him. In her speech, Senator Lees said very clearly that the Democrats had been told that if they insisted upon the amendments going through as the Senate originally sent them down to the House of Representatives, the Government would revert to its original legislation and would not accept those additional Democrat amendments. Senator Patterson and I, and certainly the members of the Opposition, are very keen to know whether it is true that that was the threat that the Minister issued to the Democrats. Senator Lees put it very clearly in her speech.

PARA.TAB: I think it is essential that the Senate understands and is aware of what threats were made by the Minister to the Democrats. It is not only Senator Lees and the Opposition who are concerned about the threat that has been made but it is also the members of the AMA, the Australian Hospitals Association and the Private Hospitals Association. They are all interested to know why the Minister made that threat and, indeed, whether the Minister made that threat. If the Minister does not know, it would be very simple for him to send out one of his officers present to phone the Minister—

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't need to be told by you how to do the job.
—I do not want to be told by the Minister that he does not know.
—I don't say that.

—Good, I am glad of that, because it would be very easy for Senator Tate to phone the Minister and establish whether, indeed, he used that threat. I ask Senator Tate not to try to tell me how to conduct my speech.
—You are telling me how to conduct myself.

—No, I am not. I said that if the Minister tells us he does not know, then all he has to do is send out one of the officers to phone the Minister and find out whether he did make that threat. It is very important to this Senate that we know just how the Minister is behaving.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I absolutely deny that the Minister made any threat. That heavily loaded word is being bandied around this chamber, and I am quite sure that Senator Lees would not have characterised any conversation she had as being threatening or involving any sense of heavy blackmail, which is what Senator Walters is trying to portray. Senator Lees would have stormed out, and quite rightly. Instead, as an honourable person, she continued the conversation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees has recounted that conversation to the chamber now, in my presence. She has said that the Minister made a comment along the lines of, `We may as well stay where we are'. That, to my mind, is simply a way of characterising the amendments that are favoured by the Opposition as not really dealing with the problem of too much weight, as he saw it, being given to those with medical expertise. I see it as no stronger a comment than that and certainly not as the one which has been characterised as a threat by Opposition senators. I am sure it was not regarded as such by Senator Lees. I believe that, as it has been explained by Senator Lees, it was expressed in much more moderate terms by the Minister than would deserve that sort of characterisation.

What we need is a board constituted for this Institute which represents those who can assist it in discharging its expanded functions. I believe that we now have a proposal which enables that to be done. I have tried to allay the fears of those who thought like Senator Patterson, with her reading of paragraph C—I am sure in good faith—that perhaps, in Senator Walters's terms, the AMA and the hospitals were being forbidden to hold a place on the board.

That is not the case. In fact, they are amongst the nominating bodies and it would be astonishing to me, quite frankly, if they did not nominate members from the AMA and/or the hospital sector. I would expect them to put such persons forward as their nominees. I can see no reason why the Minister could not regard those as being properly put forward, within paragraphs 1(f) and 1(fc), for possible appointment as persons who have expertise and interest in public health issues and consumer health issues. It seems to me

SPEECH.PARA: quite possible that an appointment could be made from members of the AMA or persons associated with the provision of hospital care in this community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two questions. Would the Minister be astonished—to use his word—if, after the nominations were put forward, there was not a representative of one of the Australian Medical Association, the Australian Hospital Association or the Australian Private Hospitals Association in one of those four groups? Let me tell him, I would not be astonished. I see the Minister smile because I think, in his heart of hearts, he knows I am right.

PARA.TAB: I ask him the question for the third time: if the Democrats were to support our amendments, would that mean that the Government would revert to the original Institute of Health, or would it accept the amendments as they stand coming from the Senate? That is the question to which we want to know the answer. As I have said, we could sit here all day. I do not want to do that, but I want to know the answer. Will the Government revert to the original Institute of Health if the Democrats were to accept our amendments?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already explained, and I find it a bit tedious to have to keep on getting up—and my braces keep on popping off.
—We don't find that tedious.

—I hope Senator Crichton-Browne does not find it exciting. The fact is that I have dealt with the proper characterisation of the conversation reported by Senator Lees to the chamber. I said then that I believed it was just a way of saying that what was proposed did not advance the situation beyond that which was contained in the arrangements for the Institute at the moment. It was of no greater significance than that.

PARA.TAB: Quite clearly—if Senator Patterson would care to listen, this is an important answer to an important question—given the expanded range of functions which the Institute has been asked to undertake, it would be impossible for it to continue to discharge those responsibilities given to it by the Parliament without a board which properly reflected those tasks and new areas of concern. It would be impossible for the Institute to function with those new areas of concern in welfare and housing without a board constituted differently from the present board. It would be impossible to go back to square one.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am reading into the answer the Minister has given me that if the Democrats were to support those amendments, the Government would not revert to the original Australian Institute of Health. As I said right at the beginning, if it did revert, all the comments he made about the importance of the contribution of those groups would be negated.

PARA.TAB: I put it to the Democrats through you, Mr Chairman, that whatever their interpretation is of what the Minister said about reverting, it is not reflected here in what is being said. I ask the Democrats to reconsider this, given the fact that the Minister has said that the Institute would not work without the particular groups referred to in the amendment to clause 6. I ask that the Democrats consider that because I believe it is important to have the providers of health services ensured of at least a position on the Institute.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find this an extraordinary exercise—quite extraordinary. It is a pity that the Minister was not here when Senator Lees made her speech. She made it very clear, although later she did not make it quite as clear—and it is understood, not just by the people in this chamber, but also by members of the AMA, the Australian Hospital Association and the Australian Private Hospitals Association—that if the Democrats supported our amendments, the Government would revert to its original legislation. The Minister has denied that. He has said that is not true. Senator Lees has said—and indeed she stuck by her speech of last December—that the AMA would make a valuable contribution with its expertise, et cetera. She still maintained that that was correct.

PARA.TAB: If the Minister does not like the word `threat', I will leave it out, but if the Minister did not say, `If you do not agree with our amendments and if you support the Opposition's amendments, we will revert to our original one', and Senator Lees has misunderstood, then Senator Lees may well now support our amendments. She said today in this debate that she still believes the AMA would make a very valuable contribution and that the hospital associations would make a very valuable contribution.

As I have already said to Senator Lees, it is not just the people in this chamber, but also the AMA, that believed that was the Government's decision, because that was what Senator Lees said. I am quite sure that if the Government were sincere about members of hospitals and the medical profession being given a position on that board, it would not have deliberately excluded them by not accepting the amendments that the Senate sent down to the House of Representatives in December. But the Government has deliberately excluded them, because the amendments we sent down to the House of Representatives included the hospital associations and the AMA. For the Government to deliberately cross them off cannot be interpreted in any other way but as a deliberate exclusion.

I am asking Senate Tate for an assurance—he seems to be quite sure; he said he would be astonished if they were not put on—that the AMA representatives would be included on the board. The Minister is obviously not going to give me that assurance. If he is sincere, he will give me an assurance that because they were listed on the schedule—as he went to great lengths to point out—we will have representatives from both the AMA and the hospitals on the board.

I repeat: we cannot possibly have an Australian Institute of Health function successfully for the good of all Australians—general health, be it housing or whatever, not just disease—without the medical profession being able to give advice, without the hospitals being able to give advice, and without those bodies being present so that they can listen to the views of the consumer groups that the Government and the Democrats want so badly to be represented on the Institute and which we also agree should be represented on the Institute. I ask the Minister whether he will give me an assurance that, because the AMA and the hospital associations are included on the schedule, they will definitely be accepted if they put up their nominees.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters knows that is a complete non sequitur and she also knows that I am not the Minister; I cannot substitute myself for the Minister—
—So you are not sincere!

—I take objection to that. I have a role to play, though I am not the Minister. The statute vests the power of appointment in the Minister. The Minister will make his decision from the list of nominees coming forward from the nominating bodies in the schedule, including the AMA and the various hospital groups. He will make his decision from that list of nominees.

PARA.TAB: I indicated in answer to Senator Patterson's query why I think those decisions can be properly made. I believe that the Minister will obviously have regard to the expertise of the individual put forward, who may, of course, be a member of the AMA and have received the support of the AMA, or indeed some other groups from that nominating list of bodies. Obviously, I cannot, in this chamber, substitute myself for the Minister at the time; the Minister must make the Executive decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Minister honestly believes that, why is it that the Government deliberately excluded the AMA and the hospital groups from the amendments we sent down to the House of Representatives? —I remind the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade of the agreed statement of the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers on South Africa in London in February 1991 that sanctions should be retained until `fundamental and irreversible change has been secured'. I remind the Minister of his statement of last week that the reform process in South Africa was `now absolutely irreversible'. When did the Australian Government move the goalposts and abandon the irreversible change test and impose as a new test the Keating statement of yesterday that the Australian Government will not lift sanctions until a democratic, non-racial government is established and a non-racial constitution is agreed upon? Is the Keating statement now Government policy or would the Labor Party and the Minister abandon these new conditions if the ANC gave them permission to do so?

—Like the Bourbons of old, it has often been said that the Opposition learns nothing and forgets nothing. There could never have been a clearer demonstration of the utility of the whole sanctions process than the outcome of the recent referendum. The inability and unwillingness of the South African people to go back to a situation where they were the pariahs of the world, where they were denied access to sporting contacts and where everything else that had created that status for them as pariahs was in place, were obviously crucial reasons for the yes vote. The continuation of a kind of policy on sanctions which is embodied in the Commonwealth formula is absolutely crucial, and will go on being crucial, to the future of this process as it has been in the past. The phased relaxation of sanctions reflecting phased developments in the constitutional process in South Africa is our policy, has been our policy and will remain our policy, and nothing the Prime Minister said diverged from that.

PARA.TAB: The question of the irreversibility of the whole process is one that involves, in the way the Opposition puts it, no more than a play on words. It is perfectly possible to make the judgment, as I have for some time now, that the process itself is irreversible, but to take the view simultaneously that the speed at which each particular part of that process falls into place, the facility with which it falls into place and the legitimacy in the sense of the acceptability with which it falls into place, still need the discipline of external sanctions and still need the prospect of some sort of external pressure hanging over the heads of the players. That is the very clear view of the ANC, whose claim to credibility in this respect is clearly the fact that it represents the overwhelming majority of the overwhelming proportion of the South African population.

It is the view, obviously, of all of the other black players in the process, possibly with the exception of the Inkatha—one never knows quite where it is on the question of sanctions at this stage. The process may be set firmly on the course of long term achievement. But we saw all too unhappily last year that the capacity of the National Government to drag its feet, to seek political advantage from the way in which that process actually works in terms of the timing of it and each particular step of it, is always there.

It is very important indeed that there continue to be some kind of disciplined focus on the National Party to ensure that, however much we might have confidence in its overall direction, it does in fact produce the goods. The whole point of the sanctions policy, as we have constantly said, is not to reward rhetoric, it is not to reward good intentions; it is to reward results. The truth of the matter is that the results are not yet firmly and finally on the board.

The next stage of the process is, we all hope, agreement on appropriate transitional mechanisms, using the language of the Commonwealth communique last year. It is everyone's hope that there will be agreement on such transitional mechanisms reached at the next meeting of the CODESA, the Convention for a Democratic South Africa, which is scheduled to take place before the end of April. There is some preliminary skirmishing going on at the moment between different models for what that transition government should be, but there is obviously a rapidly growing convergence between the positions of the respective parties on that.

If that transitional mechanism is agreed between the parties at CODESA next month, then it will be appropriate to lift trade and investment sanctions. If there is further agreement next month, or at any stage thereafter, that all remaining sanctions, or at least financial sanctions, should be lifted, then we will of course, consistent with Commonwealth policy, fall into place on that. There is some indication that it might be possible as early again as the end of next month to be in a position of lifting financial sanctions as well as trade and investment sanctions. We will simply have to see. The position Australia has taken in this respect, which I have articulated, which the Prime Minister has articulated, is no more and no less than the Commonwealth position.

I might say finally that I had a phone call this morning from the Chairman of the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers Committee, the Canadian External Affairs Minister Barbara McDougall, and it was perfectly clear from that conversation that that is the Canadian Government's position—the one that I am articulating at the moment—and it will remain the Commonwealth's position.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. In the light of his comments at Question Time yesterday about the protection of the textile, clothing and footwear industries, can the Minister advise the Senate of the precise levels of protection for these industries? PARA.TAB: At the same time the Government has committed funds to assist companies in restructuring. PARA.TAB: Senator Childs asked what the actual levels of tariff protection are. In 1992 clothing manufacturers enjoy a protection level of 51 per cent. In the year 2000, under the phase-down program, that will be 25 per cent. At that stage it will be at least five times the manufacturing average. By 1996 the level of protection afforded these industries will be 10 times the manufacturing average. The 25 per cent figure at the year 2000 will be the highest level of protection for any industry. Footwear tariffs in 1992 will be 41 per cent, phasing to 15 per cent in the year 2000. Import quotas will end in February or March next year, which will have an effect on the industry, but the tariff figures are the ones that will remain and it is important for people to have these figures in their minds.

The proposals put forward by the Government represent a staged plan of transition for these industries. They contrast with Opposition proposals about a zero tariff in the year 2000 under the Liberals' consumption tax package. That is a very big difference. The Government understands that in a country like Australia, which is trying to compete internationally, it has to nurture and build on the industries which it has. Industries such as TCF and motor vehicles will have a 15 per cent tariff by the year 2000 and no tariff under the Opposition's proposals. It is those sorts of figures that will help these industries restructure and improve their export performance, particularly in the case of motor vehicles.
