Twenty international airlines currently have landing rights at Darwin and choose not to exercise them for commercial reasons. Of the six international airlines that do serve Darwin, five are Asian airlines. For the record, there are 17 international airlines that have landing rights into Cairns that do not exercise them for the same commercial reasons. Six overseas airlines do and three of those are also Asian airlines. Six Asian airlines are currently among those that do not exercise their landing rights for the same commercial reasons. Twenty overseas airlines—the same number as for Darwin—have landing rights at Townsville Airport, but choose not to exercise them, also for commercial airlines reasons. I am pleased to say that we have just successfully negotiated with the Indonesian Government for Garuda to begin services to Townsville.

The new aviation policy will have significant benefits for northern Australia, which is so heavily reliant on our tourism industry. One of the most significant changes—that is, multiple designation—will give additional Australian carriers, as well as Qantas, an opportunity to service northern Australia and the Pacific rim destinations.

The Government has also announced that it will be proceeding to renegotiate bilateral air services with other countries, including our Asian neighbours. That process has already begun and will be aimed at achieving both enhanced route and capacity agreements.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is it the case that importers of cotton fabric for the manufacture of bed linen within Australia pay a duty of 35 per cent on that imported fabric? Is it also the case that exactly comparable manufacturers in New Zealand who import the same material for their business pay no duty? Is this finished bed linen manufactured in New Zealand imported into Australia duty free, thus giving the New Zealand manufacturer an unfair advantage? Is this a level playing field? Is it fair to Australia's bed linen manufacturers? If the Minister agrees that it is not, what remedial action will he take and when will he take it?

—I did see that the Australian Democrats were taking an interest in this matter because it was raised in the course of the Wills by-election. The Democrats seem to think that they have an issue there, which no doubt will be explored at Question Time quite a lot. It is true that the duty on bed linen material is 35 per cent into Australia, and I think it is zero per cent into New Zealand. Sheets produced in New Zealand are, under CER, granted duty free entry into Australia. That is a matter about which we are having discussions with the New Zealand Government at present.

PARA.TAB: The implication of Senator Coulter's question is that he would like the 35 per cent tariff abolished. It has to be understood that there are other manufacturers of products in Australia who want that 35 per cent tariff for very valid reasons in the interests of protecting their own business interests. The tariff is not there just to be nasty. I do not know whether the Democrats want lower tariffs or higher tariffs; they ought to sort that out before the Wills by-election comes on.

So far as the intermediate goods problem, as we call it, is concerned, as I said, we are having discussions with the New Zealand Government about that. I should make the point that the principal exporter of this product from New Zealand to Australia is an Australian company operating in New Zealand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Unfortunately, the Minister again does not seem to have got the import of the question. It is not about whether tariffs should be put on or off; it deals quite specifically with the unfair competition of New Zealand people who are importing the same cloth, manufacturing it, and then bringing it into Australia as manufactured items, as the Minister has identified, and not facing that 35 per cent tariff. The last part of the question is: what remedial action will he take and when will he take it?

—The supplementary question is astute in identifying the problem. I was querying whether Senator Coulter had any understanding of the possible solution to it. The point I make is that we are discussing this issue with the New Zealand Government at present. I am not going to announce any policy or anything else on this issue in the Senate. When those discussions are complete, if it is appropriate we will make an announcement about them.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation. I refer to claims by the National Farmers Federation that the benefits of waterfront reform have yet to be seen by exporters. Can the Minister advise what action has been taken by the Government—
—They've got that right.
—I will repeat my question; it seemed to get the Opposition going.
—Order! The Minister heard the question.
—Can the Minister advise what action has been taken by the Government to ensure that shippers receive the full benefits flowing from the current reform program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's waterfront reform program is continuing to make significant progress in terms of both efficiency and productivity in the stevedoring sector. Currently, our major terminal operators are reporting a 60 per cent improvement in the average container handling rate, and those improved rates are coming forward now—
—What about costs?

—Senator Panizza should wait a minute. The improved rates are now coming forward in the WIRA productivity reports. The work force has currently been cut by 40 per cent and will be cut in half by the end of this year, significantly exceeding the original targets for this program.

PARA.TAB: Ship turnaround times are currently on average 20 to 30 per cent faster because of improved container exchange rates, and truck turnaround times have been reduced to something between 10 and 20 minutes. These achievements are applying pressures to the cost structures of shipping cargo. There is fierce price competition between stevedores, as anyone who reads the trade papers in this industry will know, and current contracts are being negotiated at between 20 and 30 per cent less than the same contracts negotiated last year.

However, as I continue to say in the Senate, other elements in the seagoing transport equation—in particular, port authorities and the linkages with land transport, which are principally State government issues—must be similarly encouraged to lift efficiency. The Government has announced terms of reference for an inquiry into port authority operations—these were given to the Industry Commission—to add impetus to waterfront reform. The Government has also initiated a Prices Surveillance Authority examination of land based charges imposed by the shipping companies aimed at opening out the components of port related costs passed on to shippers. These initiatives were announced by the Prime Minister in the recent One Nation statement.

Ultimately, the reflection of lower waterfront costs—and they are significantly lower—in shipping freight rates is one component amongst the various price and service components that are resolved through commercial negotiations between shipping companies and their customers. I notice that the shadow Minister for shipping, John Sharp, who is riding on the back of the NFF, has been quick to lay the blame on stevedores and the shipping companies for not passing on the benefits of reform. I hope that Mr Sharp is not actually suggesting that we, as the Government, should intrude into that commercial process and try to negotiate cheaper prices on behalf of the customers of the shipping companies.

The Government is determined that the benefits of the reform will be maximised to shippers by ensuring that the competitive environment does not preclude shippers pursuing all avenues and securing cost reductions and improved services. I add that not all organisations are as pessimistic as the National Farmers Federation. Indeed, a spokesperson for the Australian Mining Industry Council in relation to this same issue said:

We will be looking for the benefits to start to flow through in 1992. I think we will get that one way or another—either through direct commercial negotiation with the shipping companies or, if that doesn't work, through the Prices Surveillance Authority and if necessary the Trade Practices Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: I agree.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Is the Minister aware that over 30,000 Australians died of cancer last year and that the Commonwealth Government outlaid $11m for cancer research? Is the Minister also aware that last year 410 people died of AIDS, over 95 per cent being male homosexuals, and that the Commonwealth outlaid $9.2m for AIDS research? Does the Minister agree that these figures support Professor Hollows' contention that government funded AIDS bodies are part of a vested interest industry and that there is an imbalance in government funding of medical research?

—I would have thought it was almost unseemly for a question to be asked which seeks to go to a crude analysis of some figures provided by the Federal Government for research into cancer in general and AIDS in particular and to contrast them without putting them in a context which would perhaps indicate overall expenditure on cancer research within the Australian community. Funds come from many sources. Supplementing, for example, the Federal contributions are State contributions, private foundations' contributions, private hospital contributions, bequests and so on. In other words, I believe that what Senator Herron is indicating would not give a true picture of the overall funds which the Australian community devotes to cancer research, as opposed to research into the AIDS problem, which is, of course, a matter of great concern in this community.

PARA.TAB: I do not believe that the sort of contrast which Senator Herron has put forward would be of sufficient basis to allow me, anybody in the Government or anybody in the community to endorse, therefore, all of the remarks that have been made by Professor Hollows over the last several days. I do not believe that there is any sequence of thought between Senator Herron's question and his request that I endorse Professor Hollows' remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Is the Minister aware of the frequency with which individuals who offer to act as guarantors in loan transactions, usually for close relatives or friends, get into financial difficulties if the loan commitments are not met? Is the Government taking any measures to help ensure that the guarantors fully understand the extent of the commitment and the risk that they are taking and that they have an opportunity to discover the full financial background of the person whose loan they are proposing to guarantee?

—Senator Jones raises a point, which is extremely important in our credit dependent society, about the way in which guarantees are sought by financial institutions. A borrower comes forward and perhaps there is a misgiving or a question mark in the mind of the local bank manager, for example, as to whether the person has the capacity to repay the loan over some time. The institution then seeks, for example, a partner, a spouse, a parent or some other relative or close friend to act as guarantor. In some circles, the expression `sexually transmitted debt' is used. It refers to the fact that a spouse or partner might take on the obligation of a guarantor because of emotional ties rather than a real assessment of the vulnerability to some sort of risk that might be undertaken. Certainly there must be many instances where that is the case.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, I recall last year telling the Senate of a case where an elderly immigrant couple provided a number of personal and business guarantees in relation to a loan offered by the National Bank to their son. This elderly immigrant couple were poorly educated with not much of a grasp of English—certainly not of business matters—and both were pensioners and dependent on the bank manager for financial guidance. The bank manager, it was alleged, knew that the state of the son's business was poor but, nevertheless, did not make this information available to the parents who then acted as guarantors. The TPC instituted proceedings on behalf of the parents against the bank which tried to enforce the guarantee alleging unconscionable conduct. The case was eventually settled and the National Bank introduced new methods of dealing with guarantors in its various branches.

This is a very great problem. Therefore, I have asked the Attorney-General's Department to look at privacy legislation to ensure that there are no impediments to guarantors being made fully aware of the true financial status of the borrower who is seeking the loan and their assistance as a backup. I believe it is very important that that be the case. Indeed, under the Privacy Act at the moment it is quite open to a guarantor to ask the potential borrower to give permission to obtain the credit reference file. That would go a long way towards ensuring that decisions are made without emotions clouding the issue and that people undertake these guarantees—which can of course, if they are enforced, even lead to the loss of a family home—with the fullest information possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Will the Prime Minister give serious consideration to the proposal of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie that the republican question be settled by referendum? Now that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie has stated that he is `watching the Prime Minister like a Hawke', is the Prime Minister prepared to consider Mr Campbell's advice that the whole republican debate is puerile while Australia has 10 per cent unemployment?

—I am sure the Prime Minister is a considerate person and will consider any suggestions made by Mr Graeme Campbell or anybody else. I say he is considerate, as distinct from the Opposition, which is clearly inconsiderate in announcing a program that will produce no improvement in unemployment levels in this country for years to come. That is an inconsiderate act if ever there was one—a very inconsiderate act.

PARA.TAB: In so far as suggesting that the debate about republicanism or Australia's relationships with other countries is puerile, I think that is a puerile suggestion. I think it is an important issue for this country and one which—

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think about Mr Campbell's statement?
—I do not think Mr Campbell said it was puerile; I think that was Senator Knowles.
—He did.
—Well, if Mr Campbell thinks it is puerile, I just do not agree with him. It is a serious matter for discussion for this country and it should be acknowledged as such by the Opposition.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to recent figures published by the Queensland Foreign Ownership Register which indicate that in the past six months unimproved foreign land-holdings in Queensland have increased by $800m—that is, almost $5m per day. I ask the Minister, firstly, whether this Government ever intends to put any limit at all on the amount of Australia which is being sold off to foreign interests. Secondly, why will not the Government simply implement a system of long term leases which would allow genuine investors to make a fair return on their business activities at the same time as eliminating excessive speculation?

—If foreigners buy land in Australia, it is because Australians sell it to them. The land Australians sell to foreigners is presumably owned by Australians and it is their decision whether they sell it. It is not a matter for imposition by governments of leasehold arrangements or anything of the kind. I understand some degree of emotional concern about this issue, but Australia is a capital-short country.
—Yes, but this is not the only way to raise capital.
—The Democrats will no doubt announce some other way at the Wills by-election, together with their policy on tariffs, and the people will be able to judge it then.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. So we will have no limits and no leasehold. I ask the Minister again, because he could not answer this last time: what are the benefits to ordinary Australians of the large scale foreign ownership of this country? What are the benefits in the long term?

—Of course, it depends very much on what use the land is put to. If the land is put to productive use, the benefits to Australia are large. If it is put to useful purposes—for example, tourism—the benefits to Australia are significant. We cannot generalise about this matter. There are considerable benefits involved, I am sure.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation and refers to an answer he gave yesterday to Senator Reynolds. The Minister told the Senate that services supplied by the North Queensland Emergency Response Group were the responsibility of the Queensland Government. While this is in essence true, the CAA pays for many rescue operations. Therefore I ask: can the Minister advise how many times in the last 12 months the CAA has called upon the North Queensland Emergency Response Group to mount rescue operations? Is it true that last week the CAA used the Emergency Response Group to locate the wreckage of a plane that crashed outside Ingham, with the loss of three lives? Is it also true that the Emergency Response Group responded this week to a CAA call when three men went missing in a dinghy and were subsequently found by the Emergency Response Group? How will the Government meet its international rescue obligations in north Queensland if the Emergency Response Group ceases to operate after 30 June this year? Can the Minister advise how the CAA intends to mount these rescue operations when the Emergency Response Group will no longer be operational?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee was clearly not listening to the answer I gave to a question from Senator Reynolds yesterday. I am glad that Senator O'Chee at least has confirmed the first part of my answer as being accurate, that is, that this is a State government responsibility, not a Federal Government responsibility. In an emergency situation the CAA contracts from whoever can provide the available facilities—
—There will not be any facilities.
—That is simply not correct, as I said yesterday. The responsible Queensland Minister, Mr Warburton, has advised me that the group is in some financial difficulty.
—That is not true.
—Senator Boswell says that that is not true. I have here a transcript from 4QN radio news of today's date quoting Mr Terry Bolger, who is an officer of the organisation. He says about the board:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . agreed to sever their operational ties with the State Government on April seventeenth but will keep operating until the end of June or a new Operator takes over.

The Board considered that this was the most appropriate way of winding up its operations so that it could pay the community of Townsville all the moneys owed, the government all moneys owed and to the staff all commitments and money owed and have a small surplus.
Mr Bolger continues:
We've all seen what's happened to the Company directors of Compass and the Board feels that this is the best way. . . the most professional way to wind the thing up.

Yesterday Mr Warburton said that a six figure sum was asked for by the organisation to enable it to continue operating. It will be financed by the State Government out of the Budget to operate until June. The Queensland State Government has assured me that tenders for a replacement emergency service will then be called for and there will be absolutely no period when emergency services are not available where they are required in north Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In his answer Senator Collins said, `The CAA contracts with whoever can provide these facilities'. Perhaps Senator Collins would enlighten the Senate by telling us who else can provide these facilities in north Queensland. While he is at it he might also confirm whether it is correct that the reason the Emergency Response Group has had its funding cut back is the preference of the State and Federal governments for a lot of the transfer work to be done by the Royal Flying Doctor Service at unlimited cost to the Federal Government.

—Mr President, I will draw Senator O'Chee a picture and send it to him after Question Time. I have answered this question three times. The Queensland emergency service is an emergency service which is the responsibility of the Queensland State Government. The responsible Queensland Minister—with whom I am continuing to liaise—has assured me that, as well as providing direct financial support from the Queensland Budget for his organisation to continue until June, the Government will then ensure that the services of this organisation are either continued by the organisation itself, if it happens to be the successful tenderer, or some other organisation. I have received an assurance from the State Minister that there will be no cessation of emergency service facilities in north Queensland.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I understand that Telecom will soon be charging for directory information services—the 013 numbers—for local calls. What provisions is the Minister making to ensure that intellectually disabled persons will not be disadvantaged and charged for making such calls, and on what basis and criteria their disability will be determined?

—This proposal has come from AOTC and in accordance with the legislation and I have referred the matter to Austel for inquiry. Once I get a report from Austel I can make a decision one way or the other.

PARA.TAB: Obviously, there is a fair bit of community concern about the issue. I think the proposal was originally put forward in 1987 and then walked away from. It is not only a matter of concern for intellectually disabled people but also for quite a few others who are potentially affected by the proposal. Arthritis sufferers who have difficulty handling telephone books would be one group; those who are visually impaired would be another; and, of course, there are those whose literacy skills are such that this proposal would present an obvious problem if it were introduced.

There are a number of important issues to be considered by Austel. It will report to me and after that I will make a decision. Obviously, the needs of those particularly disadvantaged groups to whom I have referred would be uppermost in my mind whenever that decision comes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation, and it relates to the Australian air traffic control system and the contract let in relation to that system. Is it not a fact that Thomson CSF has an unbroken record of failure in the performance of its Australian contracts—at Perth, Adelaide, the legendary Melbourne fiasco, and now Cairns and Coolangatta—at great cost to the Australian public? Is it not a fact that senior executives of the Civil Aviation Authority came from New Zealand where they had already purchased a Thomson system? Does the Minister agree that, from the outset, these people were openly biased in favour of Thomson? Is it not a fact that the Civil Air operators withdrew from the consultative body because of `unfair practices'? Is it not a fact that Thomson's technology is generations behind that of Hughes and that there is little Australian industry participation in the bid? In the light of these facts, can the Minister tell the Senate why this bid succeeded?

—Senator Lewis has done extremely well with that question—every single thing he said, without exception, was wrong. I preface my answer by advising Senator Lewis that the number of companies that can successfully install this highly sophisticated technology worldwide is very small. However, half a dozen can do it. Despite that, and despite the fierce competition worldwide, it is a matter of fact that Thomson CSF—that single company—supplies 45 per cent of the world market's air traffic control systems outside the North American market. It does not succeed that spectacularly in providing state-of-the-art systems—and that is what they are; having installed 150 air traffic control systems over the last 25 years—without providing a successful product.
—Well, how come we almost hit a Jumbo when we were landing on Saturday at Cairns?

—In terms of that silly interjection from Senator Macdonald, he should have a look at the facts of Cairns radar. One of the problems with the F28 at Cairns—this was raised by Senator O'Chee earlier in the Senate—now appears to have been caused by a faulty transponder on the aircraft itself. Currently, the CAA is checking, with a test flight process, the radar at Cairns to ensure that there are no further problems.

PARA.TAB: Looking at the Melbourne ATCARDS system is indeed very instructive. I regret to say that one of the major teething problems with the ATCARDS system at Melbourne had to do with the decision of the then Department to lump together a whole lot of components from various manufacturers and try to find an in-house solution for providing an air traffic control system. That was a major reason for those teething troubles. While I was Minister a significant amount of additional money was required to correct it.

The facts are that the CAA has a board, that that board runs the CAA, and that it engaged in an exhaustive, and exhausting, process—and it is still engaged in it—of selecting this system. The main criterion—I have to take the blame for this; as I have said before, it rests with me—where it put its priorities, was very simple. I said to the CAA, `Your first priority as far as we are concerned should be the provision of a state-of-the-art air traffic control system which is provided on time, on budget and which works. The second priority is to ensure the maximum amount of Australian participation in that project'. I do not resile from those instructions.

The major purpose of an air traffic control system in the increasingly congested skies—and I hope that for the benefit of our tourism industry they will continue to be congested—is to ensure that aircraft do not run into each other in flight. That will continue to be the major priority for the CAA—to ensure that that does not happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it not a fact that with Melbourne there was a $5.5m overrun in the contract, which was subsequently picked up by the taxpayers, and that they were years late in debugging the software? At Cairns they were 20 months late on commissioning. There have been 23 failures in the six months to 10 January 1992. With Coolangatta they were 18 months late—and there are still failures at Coolangatta. I ask the Minister: is it not a fact that they have never installed a colour Raster screen system and that this will be the first one?
—You would not even know what that is, Senator Lewis.

—I happen to know what that is. Senator Collins should look at my history; he will see that for a long period I have been associated with flying. They have no system for bringing in data from non-radar and oceanic areas. In the light of these matters, I again ask the Minister: why did these people end up with this contract? Are these facts? The Minister has denied them, but are they not facts?
—It is not unusual—and it is happening here again—that when a major—
—The answer is yes.

—The answer is no. When a major contract is let—and this contract is worth somewhere between $250m and $300m—the companies that miss out on the contract become a little disgruntled and upset about it. It always happens. Whether it is a carpeting contract for the international airport at Sydney or a contract for an air traffic control system nationally, the result is the same.

PARA.TAB: The so-called facts alluded to by Senator Lewis are comprehensively wrong. I had already covered what happened in Melbourne. ATCARDS in Melbourne is an instructive exercise for people who think it is a sensible decision for an aviation industry the size of ours—that is, small—to try to develop in-house systems for air traffic control. I can do no more, if Senator Lewis wants some instructive reading, than to recommend the General Accounting Office reports from the United States on the billions and billions of dollars of cost overruns and time delays in preparing home-grown air traffic control systems in a country that has significant sophisticated capacity to do so. We do not have that capacity in Australia. One bad decision with respect to the installation of this air traffic control system could wipe out all of the gains and benefits the Australian travelling public has received from deregulation of the airline industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs seen reports in today's Age describing the failure of a restraint order to protect a woman from being murdered by her ex-husband? Given that this case is just the latest in a long list of such cases, can the Minister say what steps he can take and what steps he will take to offer some protection for women in Australia in similar situations, particularly when those women victims have suffered a history of harassment and threats which they have reported to the police?

—I think Senator Crowley is referring to the incident in which Mrs Case, an electorate officer for Senator Olsen, was murdered in Adelaide a day or so ago. It was a very tragic incident. As I understand it, the police are still carrying out inquiries and it would be improper for me to do anything, except to express condolences in relation to the matter.
—If they had done a proper job she would still be alive. That is outrageous.

—I am simply expressing my deep sympathy for that tragic incident occurring. I do not understand what the problem is. In incidents such as this, criminal violence is perpetrated against a woman, which is absolutely shocking but is not, unfortunately, rare in the Australian community. I point out that almost half of the female homicide victims in Australia are killed by their husbands. Prior incidents of domestic violence and assault had occurred in at least 48 per cent of family homicide cases. In other words, under the euphemism of domestic violence, we have a situation of criminal assault occurring in Australian homes—places where women should have safety and protection but in fact that is not the case, and we have these terrible incidents occurring. I believe that it is incumbent on governments to take what steps they can, particularly to ensure that where—
—The point is that they were not living together. The question is why, in the light of the record of this person, she was not given proper protection.
—I am about to deal with that question.
—I know she was not given proper protection because they came to the wrong place the other day.
—Order! Senator Tate has been asked a question. There is a debate going on in the chamber.

—I am trying to say that in relation to these matters it is incumbent on the Federal and State governments to take steps to ensure that orders which are obtained, for example, in a magistrates court in one jurisdiction are able to be enforced and are transferred and reciprocal enforcement obligations undertaken by the police forces and the courts in other jurisdictions. My understanding is that the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General has made recommendations to that effect. A first draft of a model Bill to achieve that has been sent to all the States and Territories and is expected to be adopted by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in July.

PARA.TAB: It is also the case that the Australian Police Ministers Council, in reliance on recommendations from the National Committee on Violence, has passed a resolution saying that there should be mandatory confiscation of weapons in all those cases where the police are required to attend a domestic violence incident and certainly at the time of service of these protection orders, which can be obtained by women, principally, when they are under threat of physical violence.

That particular recommendation of the Australian Police Ministers Council was adopted and reinforced by all the Premiers. We have set a target date of 1 July this year for the introduction, Australia-wide, of legislation which will require the mandatory confiscation of weapons where a protection order is in place. In fact, some jurisdictions already have that sort of legislation. Senator Bishop must have misunderstood me. I am particularly not speaking to that particular case—

TALK.START.PARA: —We heard you very clearly.
—It was unethical—totally unlike you—totally out of character.

—I do not understand. I am saying, in relation to that particular case, that I express my very deep sympathy. But I believe that it gives rise to proper consideration by governments of the way in which we can protect women who are subject to this homicidal violence and criminal violence in the home. I believe that I have indicated those steps which both the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General and the Police Ministers Council are taking to try to ensure that that is the case Australia-wide.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister ask the Attorneys-General and/or the police Ministers to look at possible measures to be taken when a history of harassment and threats is reported by women who are told repeatedly that nothing can be done in those situations because the law cannot anticipate a crime? What sorts of steps might he ask the Attorneys-General to look at to deal with just that sort of situation?

—I believe that this is a matter of great concern. I understand that many police forces are undertaking special training programs to enable them to respond much better to claims made by women about the threats to which they are subjected, quite often by a spouse and quite often by a spouse in possession of a weapon. These are matters of great difficulty and sensitivity. I believe that the protection order regime which is in place in many States—
—In Queensland.

—Yes, there may be a very good working scheme in Queensland; I do not know. Last year, I launched a video in New South Wales, which tried to encourage women, through exposure to this video in neighbourhood houses and other community network organisations, to be aware of their rights in this regard and to approach the courts for protection. It is not an easy matter; it is fraught with great problems. It is not a matter, of course, simply for the police forces.

PARA.TAB: One has to commend the women's refuge centres which themselves have undertaken tremendous work, in the initial stages in great adversity and against public opinion, to provide safe havens for women who were subjected to these threats of violence. It was not understood in the community to be a threat of criminal violence—it was just under this euphemism, domestic violence.

So there is much to be done in this regard. I believe that we all ought to resolve to take those steps as comprehensively as possible to ensure that that terrible figure that I gave of so many women being subjected to death, let alone injury, harassment and intimidation, should no longer be a feature of Australian society.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that the Minister's office and that of Dr Blewett have claimed consistently that there is no need for the Government to continue subsidising the NOW centre in the electorate of Wills because the Department of Social Security has expanded to fulfil the needs? Is he aware that the NOW centre claims that it now has 200 referrals per month from the Department of Social Security? Can he explain why, despite the fact that the NOW centre faxed an invitation to the Prime Minister's office last week and personally handed an information package to Mr Keating when he made a fleeting appearance in the electorate last Saturday, the Prime Minister treated the organisation with contempt in Question Time yesterday? Will the Government reconsider its heartless attitude to a very deserving community organisation?

—Any claim that the Prime Minister treated the organisation with contempt in Question Time yesterday is absurd. But it is worth looking at the history of this organisation, given that Senator Alston has raised the question. From 1977 to 1988, the Department of Social Security provided some administrative funding to that centre to assist with salaries and running costs.

PARA.TAB: That was part of an agreement between the Department of Social Security and the Community Services Department in Victoria. It was about $60,000 a year, in round figures. The funding agreement expired in June 1988. Funding was continued while there was a review of the situation. As a result of that review, the decision was taken not to continue funding the centre, which is not to say that the centre does not fulfil a very valuable role. Like many other welfare agencies, it receives referrals from Social Security, because there are many needs in the community that cannot be satisfied in a Social Security office. It is customary in every Social Security office every day of the year for referrals to be made to centres of that kind mainly because they fulfil functions that are outside the scope of the Department. As the Department expanded the coverage of that centre from the late 1970s to now, the need for Social Security funding of it became less.

That is not to say that it is not a worthy centre. I have been there myself. It does excellent work. But the functions it covers are mainly those of the State Government. It is always easier to honour a pioneer or a prophet with the benefit of hindsight. I could not help thinking of Jo Vallentine when Senator Giles told the story of Muriel Matters in her excellent opening speech at the `Trust the Women' exhibition, and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Muriel Matters travelled to Britain to join the Women's Freedom League after Australian women achieved the vote in 1902. She was a talented speaker, performed regularly in Hyde Park on Sunday afternoons, and threw herself wholeheartedly into the campaign for women's suffrage. Muriel Matters was imprisoned for her actions. It is obvious that she did not receive a positive response from the Establishment of her time. I believe that people 50 years from now will remember more as a heroine than a heretic the honourable senator who cried out from the gallery `Shame! You promised you'd never do it' to the Prime Minister as he committed Australia to war.

PARA.TAB: History's verdict may well be kinder to Jo Vallentine than to any of the rest of us here. I regard her as a pioneer and feel it a privilege to follow her and build upon the foundation that she laid for me when she became the first senator for the Greens (WA) two years ago. I must stress that unlike Jo, who started her political career as an Independent, I do not regard myself as an Independent, but succeed her in her later role as the first Greens senator here, soon to be followed by a second, a third and so on.

At this point I would like to explain the underlying philosophy of Green politics because, particularly in Australia, the implications of the word `Green' are not fully understood. While it is often limited to leafy trees and furry animals, `Green' has actually become the symbol for a change in perspective that has arisen in different parts of the world in the past 10 to 20 years. Its earliest beginnings were seen as the environment movement, feminism, the anti-nuclear movement and other alternative movements that have emerged and increased in importance since the early 1970s.

Many different paths lead individuals towards a Green political involvement. Jo Vallentine's path came from the peace movement. Other well known figures like Christine Milne and Bob Brown became involved through their deep concern for the environment. My path was the area of social justice. Working for 10 years as a clinical psychologist in a maximum security prison for males was a radicalising experience which forced me to challenge, in the deepest possible way, the sincerity and integrity of my own values and beliefs and those of the society to which I belonged. I believe that experience will also help me when I am in other institutions, and I do not think the example is inappropriate in this place.

On entering the prison system, I assumed that everyone in prison deserved to be there and that law was about truth and justice. To my amazement, I found that many people who were in positions of power deserved to be in prison and prisons were full of the poor and the powerless. I choose one example from a myriad to illustrate my point.

In Western Australia where Aboriginal people constitute 2 per cent of the State population, the 1991 Parliamentary Sub-committee on Parole reported that of all people who were held in police lock-ups in the year preceding the report, 97 per cent were Aboriginal. It also reported that 45 per cent of all of those imprisoned in that year were Aboriginal. Those figures speak for themselves.

I was also surprised to see the connection between justice issues and political and economic processes.Some years ago in a study of worldwide attitudes regarding capital punishment, I read a United Nations publication that was examining the factors influencing death penalty legislation in various countries throughout the world. To my surprise, the most common factor influencing attitudes towards the death penalty was not found to be religious, moral or philosophical, but economic. In countries which had experienced a period of affluence followed by a recession, there was a political shift towards the Right, law and order became more common as an electoral platform and calls for the death penalty increased.

We are seeing signs of this in Australia today. An example is the recent juvenile justice legislation introduced by the Western Australia Government which, as the Premier, Dr Lawrence, stated, now provides the harshest penalties for juveniles in Australia.

While working in Bangladesh in a medical and community development project for three years, I began to see the connection between social equity and the ability to protect the environment. Need and greed are two factors which seriously influence the capacity or will to safeguard the environment we have.

So far I have touched on two of the four pillars of Green politics—peace and social justice. Another, and the most well known, is environmental responsibility. What is less well known is that this is inextricably linked to economics. Central to Green politics is the connection between the economic well-being of a society and an ecologically sustainable plan for future generations.
William Rees points to the need for fundamental changes in a paper recently published in The Ecologist, where he says:

SPEECH.PARA: The evidence suggests. . . that we may be fast approaching absolute limits to material economic growth. We no longer have the luxury of `trading off' ecological damage for economic benefits if we hope to have a sustainable future. The maintenance of global ecological integrity necessarily becomes our highest priority and must be taken account of in every local and regional development decision.
Rees sees this emphasis as requiring:

. . . a profound shift in societal values and attitudes, and a significant restructuring of national and global economies. On the positive side, the attitudinal changes and policy responses. . . have the potential to produce a more politically secure, ecologically stable and economically just global society.

PARA.TAB: The Greens' modus operandi is the antithesis of economic rationalism. It is a holistic perspective that reflects the inter-relatedness and inter-connectedness of the world and all in it. The `externals' of the well-being of the environment and the people and living things in it must be part of the equation when making economic decisions.

The Greens have been accused of putting the environment before people and jobs. Protection of the environment has also been spoken of as a luxury we cannot afford because we desperately need jobs. Not only is this foolish in terms of our long term well-being, it is simply not true. Ian Lowe from Griffith University states in his paper, The politics of long-term issues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the green movement offers the only significant countervailing force to the tyranny of the short-term-
which, he believes, is operating in the political arena.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Conservation Foundation, Greenpeace and the Wilderness Society, among others, have clearly outlined the employment opportunities in ecologically sustainable industry, in particular through the realignment of the timber industry onto a plantation base. Research shows that there are employment opportunities in energy efficiency and that there are more jobs in energy from renewable sources than fossil fuel sources.

While environmental responsibility allows for employment and ecologically sustainable development, the point needs to be made that there is a logical contradiction between the economists' belief in the `market' and concerns for social justice and equity. I again cite Ian Lowe, in his Boyer lecture `Who's Paying the Driver?':

SPEECH.PARA: Economists tend to believe in markets because they think they are the most efficient means of allocating resources between competing interests. Whether this is true or not, even the most besotted admirer of markets would probably not claim that they contain any feature or mechanism which could promote equity, even in principle. Indeed there is a fundamental sense in which markets will always promote inequity. If a market is used to allocate a scarce resource, whether it is beach-front land or a team of accomplished professional footballers, those with large bank accounts will always be able to outbid those with lighter wallets. Thus allocation through a market means those who are rich will get what they want and those who are poor will miss out. Those of us who are not rich are limited to competing for those things which the rich do not want sufficiently to bid the price up out of our reach.

Encouraging further employment, by way of incentives and concessions, in areas like construction and resource development does not make sense economically, socially or environmentally. We end up with large sections of the work force, and much of the available capital, in areas subject to big fluctuations in employment as a result of a dependence on world markets.

PARA.TAB: As well as the environmental cost in terms of depletion of the earth's life-giving resources, there is a great social cost to those under-represented in the labour forces—women, Aboriginal people and young people. For these strategies to benefit those social groups who have large unemployment or a tendency to be concentrated in low wage areas and part time work, their special needs must also be targeted.

I am well aware that there will be senators and members of this Parliament who share a deep concern for at least some of these issues I have mentioned. I am also aware that some present have an impressive history of championing these causes. I look forward with pleasure to working with others of all political persuasions wherever our respective concerns coincide—a very practical and necessary approach considering my solitary position in this Senate. It does not matter who is responsible for an issue being addressed as long as it is addressed.

The common thread that unites all those who come into the political arena as Greens, and which sets us apart from other political parties, is a profound conviction that the structures and old ways of addressing the problems will not be effective. While cynicism and apathy regarding politics and politicians engulf the Australian community, as they have done elsewhere, there is a small but growing minority that has not given up but is seeking a revolutionary change in the political system. This revolution, which may be more appropriately called a transformation because it utilises that which is good from the past, is centred on the political process rather than the issues.

Grassroots participation is the fourth and most crucial pillar of Green politics. One of the advantages of participatory democracy is that it is possible to get input from groups and individuals not usually heard. Decisions can be made and action decided after consideration of a variety of perspectives. Through this process the special needs of groups that are disadvantaged because of the dominance of interests different from their own become heard.

One such group is women. When people talk about equality for women, what they usually mean is that women must become like men so they can compete, receive recognition, and have some say in a world ordered according to values most often associated with men.

Integral to small `l' liberal theory is the notion of individuals as competing with each other for scarce resources. It underlies the dominant ideology of our current society—economic rationalism—and permeates the institutions and structures of public life, which is the realm of the masculine. What the Greens are trying to do is bring those values traditionally associated with women and the private spheres of home and family into the public arena—namely, non-violence, cooperation, nurturing, a respect for all people, all other life-forms and our environment and an acceptance of diversity.

Electoral systems are only one aspect of ensuring community participation in the political process. We also need a commitment of political will towards grassroots consultation. Like all comprehensive proportional representation systems, Hare-Clark more accurately reflects the diversity of political opinion and community expression than other electoral systems. Hare-Clark creates a stable system for political groups to operate under, while providing the electorate with alternative individual representation. It is just one example, but it illustrates the Greens' conviction that the adversarial processes of election and parliamentary debate must be broken down. True community representation, consultation and agreement come out of processes that attempt to take full account of the widest point of view.

Party politics has floated away from the world of ordinary people like Muriel Matters' balloon. Challenging this and returning to responsible, accountable community consultation and grassroots involvement in the political process is the key to Green politics.

Fritjof Capra, in his book Turning Point, suggests that the present civilisation is under challenge from three transitions which shape the very foundation of our lives and will deeply affect our social, economic and political system. The first and most profound is the slow, reluctant but inevitable decline of patriarchy. The second transition is forced on us by the decline of the fossil fuel age, while the third is connected with a shift in cultural values—a profound change in thoughts and perceptions that we need to have away from a mechanistic Newtonian world view to an ecological world view. As Capra says, we are reaching the turning point. These transitions involve not only a crisis of individuals, governments or social institutions; they are all contributing to our global crisis.

In conclusion, I shall read an analysis that Fritjof Capra quotes of Toynbee's account of the rise and fall of civilisation. I would like honourable senators to listen for where I think the Greens are being referred to. Fritjof Capra states:

After civilisations have reached a peak of vitality, they tend to lose their cultural steam and decline. An essential element in this cultural breakdown, according to Toynbee, is a loss of flexibility. When social structures and behaviour patterns have become so rigid that the society can no longer adapt to changing situations, it will be unable to carry on the creative process of cultural evolution. It will break down and, eventually, disintegrate. Whereas growing civilisations display endless variety and versatility, those in the process of disintegration show uniformity and lack of inventiveness. The loss of flexibility in a disintegrating society is accompanied by a general loss of harmony amongst its elements, which inevitably leads to the outbreak of social discord and disruption.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder whether we recognise the current political system or our social milieu at the moment. Capra continues:

PARA.TAB: However, during the painful process of disintegration—

SPEECH.PARA: already, as I have said, based on those three transitions and challenges—

the society's creativity—its ability to respond to challenges—is not completely lost. Although the cultural mainstream has become petrified by clinging to fixed ideas and rigid patterns of behaviour, creative minorities will appear on the scene and carry on the process of challenge-and-response. The dominant social institutions will refuse to hand over their leading roles to these new cultural forces, but they will inevitably go on to decline and disintegrate, and the creative minorities may be able to transform some of the old elements into a new configuration. The process of cultural evolution will then continue, but in new circumstances and with new protagonists.

All of us need to prepare ourselves for this turning point by deeply re-examining the main premises and values of our culture and by rejecting conceptual models that have outlived their usefulness. Such a change must be accompanied by a profound modification of most social relationships and structures, not the least those of the party political system. Each diverse viewpoint can contribute to the transformation which is required. As a Green senator, I am committed to work towards that social transformation and welcome the opportunity to work for it in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the National Companies and Securities Commission deals with its winding up. So I would like to acknowledge the efforts of the two people I have mentioned and also at the same time mention the great reforms that have taken place through the new corporations legislation. That has been a great tribute to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and, may I say, to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), who sits in front of me and who has also done great work in this area. Mr Tony Hartnell, who heads up the ASC, again is doing splendid work. But he and the two Ministers I have mentioned did have a context in which they were able to move forward with great success. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the report of the National Companies and Securities Commission, but in a tone slightly different from that of the previous speaker, Senator Cooney, although I support the thrust of what he said. The Australian economy and business sector, in some parts, went through a period when cowboys thought that the rules of the game were not what was right and what was wrong, rather what one could get away with.

PARA.TAB: Because of the tragic failure of the cooperative system of federalism in respect of national companies and securities legislation, the failure of State governments and the Federal Government to properly fund, resource and show a commitment towards the enforcement of company codes and company law, there was a binge in indulgence of a sort which ultimately reflected very badly on Australia's integrity, particularly internationally, and the capacity of good and decent Australians to do business overseas. That is not to say that the reason for the failure of every business and every entrepreneur that fell over was that the business or entrepreneur had committed a sin.

Having said that, let me raise a word of warning again about what I describe as the cowboy attitude of those in more recent times who have used colourful language in talking about the scalps that they are seeking to nail to the wall. I think it was Mr Bosch who made some outrageous claims in respect of Mr Skase. I make no judgments about Mr Skase one way or another. But Mr Skase is no different from any other Australian: that is, before the law there is a presumption of innocence.

I think Mr Bosch on one occasion—because he did not have the resources for investigation and prosecution—used the process of public statements and press statements as a way of highlighting what he saw as the intrinsic faults in the system. I think it was Mr Hartnell or the ASC that, after exhaustive inquiry into the activities of the Bond Corporation, used words to the effect that senior directors of the Bond Corporation may have committed serious criminal offences and may have committed serious breaches of company law.

Again, it was my understanding that the ASC and the National Companies and Securities Commission approached the law, their task and the directors in the same way as any other body. Frankly, I find it quite sad that we have public utterances which do two things: reverse the onus of proof and cast a judgment of guilt even before charges are laid. So those to whom they refer commence their tribulations, trials and prosecutions with an absolute presumption by these authorities that there is inherent guilt.

If that is to be the norm, there is something fundamentally flawed and wrong with the processes. Perhaps it is because, as with the Costigan royal commission, governments create a level of expectation in the community that the Mr Bigs will be caught, major white collar crimes will be exposed and prosecutions and convictions obtained. Perhaps that is why these bodies feel compelled to speak in a hairy-chested, virile way about those that in some cases they are not prosecuting but, dare I say it, persecuting.

I hope that does not begin to be the norm with respect to any part of law enforcement in Australia. I am pleased that the proper resources are there for the ASC to discharge its responsibilities with competence and diligence. Let us hope that it does so within the parameters of the law and the norms and the standards of accepted law in Australia.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Audit Report No. 22 of 1991-92, Report on Ministerial Portfolios—Autumn Sittings 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Audit Report No. 23 of 1991-92, Aggregate and Departmental Financial Statements 1990-91.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the documents.

Both of the Auditor-General's reports Nos. 22 and 23, which you have just tabled, Mr Acting Deputy President, are important documents. In the limited amount of time available prior to the reports being tabled, it was not possible to analyse them in depth. However, there are some comments I would like to make in relation to Audit Report No. 23, Aggregate and Departmental Financial Statements 1990-91, which I think is the more important of the two reports, although they are both important.

This report emanates from the requirements of the Audit Act. Section 50A(b) of the Audit Act 1901 requires the Minister for Finance to prepare an aggregate financial statement showing total receipts and expenditures of the Consolidated Revenue Fund, the Loan Fund and the Trust Fund. Section 50 of the Act requires the Secretary of each department to prepare a financial statement showing departmental receipts and expenditures and such other information as is required by financial statement guidelines issued by the Minister for Finance. Both types of statement are audited by the Auditor-General under section 51 of the Act. It is in relation to that that the Auditor-General has produced this report.

It is important to note that, of the 55 departmental financial statements which have been audited, and which are the subject of this report, 14 of them were qualified in respect of inadequate accounts and records, or breaches of financial statement guidelines of Commonwealth laws. The Auditor-General says on page 4 of his report:

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General's Audit Report No. 22 1990-91 on the 1989-90 financial statements prepared by the Minister for Finance and the related accounts and records of departments drew attention to the high incidence of non-observance of, and breakdowns in, basic controls and procedures, including detailed legislative requirements. The matters raised in 1990-91, and the errors disclosed, did not have a material effect on the financial statements but the ANAO considers that the need for compliance with laws and for proper financial management requires improvement in the accounts and records.

In other words, the Auditor-General is saying that many departments need to lift their game in terms of their proper financial management. In particular, this requires an improvement in departmental accounts and records. That is of particular interest, since the Government has attempted to put some organisations—and I will come to this a little later in my remarks—outside the ambit of the Australian National Audit Office and has also slowed down the proposed wide-ranging changes to the Audit Act. There are grounds for concern on both of those counts. I hope that the Government will address those concerns in this chamber and elsewhere before too long.

PARA.TAB: It is extraordinary that the proposed fundamental review and rewrite of the Audit Act has taken so long and has been so long delayed. It is having a considerably detrimental effect on the operations, activities and approach of the Australian National Audit Office. I repeat: 14 out of 55 departmental statements have been qualified.

Many weaknesses and deficiencies were noted in last year's report, as I have said. The Auditor-General is really saying that no substantive action appears to have been taken in the last year to remedy the deficiencies that were the subject of comment a year ago. Indeed, the Auditor-General points out that in some cases the situation is even worse now than it was. For example, again on page 4, in paragraph 1.3.4 the Auditor-General says:

SPEECH.PARA: The audit examination of the accounts and records maintained by the 55 departments during 1990-91 did not reveal any general improvement compared with previous years. The audits in a number of departments disclosed deficiencies of a more serious nature in particular areas of financial management. . . The number of individual matters raised, based on audit review of systems and sample checking of transactions, remained at a relatively high level.

PARA.TAB: I will pick out a few examples of the more substantive breaches that the Auditor-General has identified. The Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories exceeded its appropriations for the National Film and Archives Centre twice. The same sort of breach occurred recently and was disclosed yesterday in the Advance to the Minister for Finance information for February 1992, which showed that the Department of Administrative Services had overspent its appropriations by a considerable amount before it sought funds to continue its programs. This is another example of the problems and concerns that the Auditor-General has identified and expressed.
In relation to the Department of Defence, the Auditor-General, in paragraph 1.3.14, says:

SPEECH.PARA: The audit report on the Department's financial statement was qualified because up to 7% of claims for payment were paid during the year on the certificate of officers who had not been properly appointed for this purpose, contrary to paragraph 34(2)(b) of the Audit Act.

The Department of Finance itself—the custodian of rectitude, one would hope, in terms of financial practices—also did not escape the attention of the Auditor-General. In relation to that Department, in paragraph 1.3.18, the Auditor-General says:

The practice of the Department of Finance in netting bank fees and interest charges against interest paid by the Reserve Bank was in breach of the Constitution. Failure to maintain separate records for the old and new superannuation schemes was in breach of the Audit Act.

Those charges—particularly the one in relation to the netting of bank fees and interest charges against interest paid by the Reserve Bank, which is in breach of the Constitution—are very serious. It is quite extraordinary that the Department of Finance could have made that mistake. This is unfortunate, given the role model that in many respects that Department has and certainly should have so far as the correct procedures for other departments are concerned.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General found that unidentified amounts in excess of $100,000 were included in the trust fund balance of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. As I understand it, that is, again, a breach of the provisions of the Audit Act.
In paragraph 1.3.28, the Auditor-General had this to say about the Department of Primary Industries and Energy:

SPEECH.PARA: The audit of the Department's accounts and records disclosed that the Department did not make arrangements in sufficient time to waive repayments of advances of $7.838 million and had incomplete records of loans of $6.54 billion guaranteed by the Commonwealth.

That is a huge amount of money for which the Commonwealth has a contingent liability in the form of a guarantee. It is a matter of very serious concern, I believe, if the Department of Primary Industries and Energy had incomplete records of loans totalling that amount.

PARA.TAB: There are numerous other examples but I will not go into them all. I think it is fair to say, after reading this report quickly, that the general feeling from the report is that the Government has not taken the steps that the Auditor-General has identified in the past to improve the financial recordings and financial statements of government departments and agencies. That is exemplified, as I have said earlier, by the fact that the Government is taking so long to get its act together in relation to a major revision of the Audit Act.

Although discussing the role of the Auditor-General and the role of the Audit Act can often seem a pretty dry and arid affair, it is—and it should be remembered that it is—a fundamentally important function of government because the Auditor-General and the Audit Office, through the Audit Act, really are the custodians, in many respects, of the finances of our nation. The Audit Office verifies that the accounts of government are being properly maintained and that the financial transactions of government are being properly carried out. So the Audit Office has a fundamental role. I am concerned, and I know that many others are concerned, about an apparent lack of urgency on the Government's part in respect of the need to ensure that the resources of the Audit Office and the legislative framework under which it operates are sufficient and adequate to fulfil the very necessary role that it plays.

As I have said before—and we have debated this matter in this place and other places—on at least two occasions now in the last year we have seen the Government quite deliberately refuse, or wish to refuse, to give the Audit Office an essential role to play in relation to the auditing of the accounts of agencies. Two in particular that come to mind are the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and the National Rail Corporation. The Government quite deliberately took away or weakened the specific authority that the Auditor-General and the Audit Office had in respect of auditing the accounts of those authorities. Fortunately, that was changed as a result of amendments moved by the coalition and supported by the Democrats.

I think it is very important that the Government make a statement to the Parliament very soon as to what it expects of the Audit Office; and what it is proposing to do in relation to the role, the mandate and the general legislative framework of the Audit Office and the Auditor-General. While the continuing uncertainty remains, there is a risk that the auditing of the finances of the Commonwealth—that is, the finances of the Australian taxpayers—is not going to be carried out as efficiently as I am sure we would all want it to be.

I congratulate the Auditor-General on this report. It is a very timely report and I hope it will lead to an improvement in the practices and operations of those departments of which it is critical. I hope that the Government will make a statement soon to the Parliament about some of the matters to which I have referred today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Select Committee on Superannuation, I present a letter written by me to the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) concerning the superannuation entitlements of employees who were made redundant following the winding up of Byrnwood Ltd, WA, together with the Hansard transcript of evidence relating to this matter. PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: SENATOR NICK SHERRY
SENATOR FOR TASMANIA
The Hon John Dawkins, MP
Treasurer
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
My Dear Treasurer

On behalf of the Senator Select Committee on Superannuation, I am writing to draw your attention to the Byrnwood case which was discussed in evidence given to the Senator Select Committee on Superannuation at its public hearings in Perth. I also seek your support and cooperation in ensuring that the former employees of Byrnwood are given every consideration when decisions are made in respect of taxation applicable to payments that they secure in lieu of their superannuation entitlements.

Briefly, the directors of Byrnwood Pty Ltd., which traded as Peter's Bakeries and Swan Lake Natural Foods, were also the trustees of the Byrnwood Superannuation Fund. Byrnwood went into liquidation in 1990 and the receiver-manager found a great number of irregularities in the conduct of the superannuation affairs of the company, including non-payment of the 3% productivity award superannuation contribution, breaching of the in-house asset rule, and `confiscation' of employees own contributions into the company superannuation fund. Full details of the case are outlined in the attached Hansard.
The Committee understands that the former employees of the company have or are about to receive approximately $10,000 each from three sources:
.payments from the receiver-manager in respect of the 3% award super;
.payments from the receiver-manager in respect of the employees own contributions; and
.an out-of-court settlement from one of the directors of Byrnwood equivalent to 72% of the amount that would have been the employees' entitlement at November 1990.

Press reports (see attached) indicate that the payments received by the former employees may be taxed at marginal rates because the moneys were not paid from a superannuation fund. I understand that the matter is still under investigation by the Perth office of the Taxation Office and a decision has not yet been made on whether the moneys will be regarded as assessable income and hence subject to taxation. Should the Australian Taxation Office not be in a position to apply superannuation rates of taxation to these moneys, then it would be entirely appropriate for the Parliament to legislate to address this anomaly.

Clearly, the Committee has no wish to interfere with the statutory responsibilities of the Commissioner of Taxation but we wish to highlight some deficiencies in current regulations which fall within your portfolio.

Firstly, the high cost of civil court action and the uncertainty of the result effectively precludes members of a fund from taking action against former trustees. In the Byrnwood case, as one of the former trustees was a declared bankrupt and another was domiciled in Hong Kong, it seems likely that legal costs would exceed any settlement determined by the courts if the action by the members were successful. If the ISC had powers similar to the Trade Practices Commission to institute civil proceedings against individuals or companies alleged to be in breach of the law, the members may have been able to take some action against the trustees. As matters currently stand, they virtually have no hope of recourse through the legal system.

Secondly, the Byrnwood case highlights the need for arms' length relationships between employers and trustees of corporate superannuation funds. There is clear potential for conflict of interest when the directors of the company are also the sole trustees of the corporate superannuation fund. It is clearly unacceptable that the employer and trustee of the fund are one and the same entity as occurred in the Byrnwood case.

Thirdly, whilst there seems to be some confusion over whether the Byrnwood fund was a complying fund, if it was a complying fund it breached the `in-house' asset rule. This raises the question of what can be done to improve ISC audit procedures to pick-up such flagrant breaches of regulations and what penalties can be imposed on trustees.

I would welcome the opportunity to discuss the Byrnwood case with you further and I reiterate the Committee's concern that the Byrnwood employees should be given fair and equitable treatment in the taxation of benefits due to them following the winding up of their employer.
Yours sincerely
Nick Sherry
Chairman
Senate Select Committee on Superannuation
