TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will recall that in June last year the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation was established with the responsibility of reporting on 17 terms of reference by the last sitting day in May 1992. The procedural resolution which accompanied the Committee's terms of reference stated that it should have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit. This speech, therefore, is inter alia an interim report of the inquiry by the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation.

PARA.TAB: The Committee has endeavoured to use all possible mechanisms and opportunities to ensure that its work is at the forefront of public debate on superannuation in Australia. To this end, last December the Committee tabled a background discussion paper entitled Super Systems Survey—a survey of superannuation which subsequently proved to be a much sought after document with over 600 copies being distributed on request to individuals and organisations interested in superannuation.

Since that time, the Committee has embarked on an ambitious and fairly arduous round of public hearings—so far totalling 14 days—during which more than 100 witnesses have been examined and almost 1,800 pages of publicly available Hansard have been produced. The Committee has adopted a policy whereby nearly all of the submissions have been published on receipt. This public stance has also been followed by having almost all hearings held in open session. This policy has already paid generous dividends in that we have been able to observe significant changes in attitudes and position, both in the Public Service and industry, about the shape of superannuation in the 1990s and beyond.

The Byrnwood case is very similar to the Maxwell case in England, but in miniature. During one of the hearings in Perth the Committee was given an in-depth briefing on the Byrnwood case. The Byrnwood case, like most of the case studies examined by the Committee, provides some important lessons which I believe should be brought before the Senate today. Before elaborating on the issues arising out of Byrnwood, I would first like to outline the facts of that case.

Byrnwood Pty Ltd traded as Peters Bakeries and Swan Lake Natural Foods and employed 40 to 50 employees. Most of the production workers were members of the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union, many of them from non-English speaking backgrounds. The company ran a defined benefit scheme for employees called the Byrnwood superannuation fund. The last actuarial review of the fund was conducted for the 1988-89 financial year. At that stage the fund was healthy and the actuary recommended in January 1990 that no payments be made by the employer. In addition, the award required the employer to pay 3 per cent superannuation into a nominated industry fund.

On 12 November 1990 Coopers & Lybrand advised suppliers, customers and staff that it had been appointed as receiver-manager to Byrnwood Pty Ltd. On 18 November 1990 the receiver-manager advised the union at a meeting of his concern with respect to the state of the superannuation fund. He appointed three staff to audit the fund. On 18 December 1990 the receiver-manager wrote to all employees advising them that the company did not remit certain superannuation payments, including those payable by the company for occupational superannuation and those deducted from employees' wages, to the relevant superannuation funds, but that all payments would be made to the funds as required by the relevant award or trust deed.

On 20 December 1990 the receiver-manager wrote to the union saying that it had become evident that there were some irregularities in respect of the company's superannuation fund, and that preliminary inquiries had established that, whilst the company had recognised its liability to make contributions under the 3 per cent occupational superannuation requirements, no fund was set up and no payments had been made. It also advised that it appeared that some contributions deducted from employees' wages were not remitted to the employees' contribution fund.

Examination of the trust deed for the Byrnwood superannuation fund, which was dated as recently as 29 May 1987, revealed that the deed was an agreement between Byrnwood Pty Ltd as the employer of the one part and Byrnwood Pty Ltd as trustee of the other part. The receiver-manager advised the union that he was only acting in the capacity of employer and was, therefore, not in a position to act as trustee of the superannuation fund.

However, since the trust deed provided for the principal employer to appoint and remove trustees, the receiver-manager indicated that he would give consideration to appointing a nominee of the members as a trustee. In view of concerns with respect to the question of the liabilities of the trustees, this invitation was not accepted. It is not clear whether the receiver-manager, acting as the principal employer, ever exercised the right to remove the existing trustees, or whether they actually resigned their position as trustee.

After a number of meetings and conferences in the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission the following became clear—the trustees of the fund were the same people as the directors of Byrnwood Pty Ltd. According to the NCSC return for the year ended 30 June 1988, these were: Richard Hutchison Baird of 16 Grant St, Cottesloe, WA; and David James Humann of Apartment 11a, Piccadilly Mansion, 6 Po Shan Road, Hong Kong. Mr Baird was also recorded as the principal executive officer and the company secretary.

However, Mr Humann, also a senior partner in Price Waterhouse, indicated that he had submitted a written resignation as director in mid-1990, as a result of which a further search was made of ASC records on 6 June 1991. Although they recorded the appointment of an additional director, William Francis Cawley, of 82A Collins St, West Perth, WA, and that Mr Baird's address had been altered and Mr Humann's address had changed to 16 Grant St, Cottesloe, WA—the previous address for Mr Baird—they had no notification of Mr Humann's resignation. This in itself posed an interesting question as to who exactly were the directors at the time of the appointment of the receiver-manager.

The company had $6.7m of secured debts, mainly to ANZ and Standard Chartered Finance. In addition, approximately 90 per cent of the superannuation fund's assets, or $435,105, had been lent as an unsecured loan from the superannuation fund to Byrnwood and was an unsecured debt which the receiver indicated there was no chance of recovering. In fact, as at November 1990, the superannuation fund only had $30,000 left in assets. An actuarial assessment conducted by Jacques Martin Industry in August 1991, concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. While the actuary to the fund has calculated that the liability of the superannuation fund was $262,471.64, the assets of the fund at the time should have been $461,206.
2. The directors of Byrnwood Pty Ltd, in the capacity as trustee for the Byrnwood superannuation fund, had a legal responsibility to:
.recover from the employer unpaid contributions deducted from employees' wages and not remitted to the fund;
.recover from the employer contributions due to the superannuation fund up to 18 January 1990 when actuarial advice was received that no further company contributions were required; and
.invest the trust monies in such a manner as would be seen to be prudent to a reasonable person charged with investing someone else's money.
The investments should have been monitored by the Trustee and immediate action taken if doubts existed about the suitability of the investments.

3. The chart of accounts provided show the company holding a liability, to the Byrnwood Superannuation Fund, on the books at $435,105.04, at the end of October 1990. If an interest return of, say 14 per cent had been applied, this would have accumulated to $485,310 at the end of August 1991.
Likewise, if the minimum actuarial liability was increased with interest, the amount would be $293,965 at the end of August 1991.

The trust deed provided that in the event of the superannuation fund being wound up, the assets be equitably distributed amongst the members. Clearly, had the directors of the trustee company acted properly, the benefits available for distribution to the members of the trust would have been significantly greater than the minimum actuarial liability calculated by the actuary to the fund.

In effect, the trustees, in direct breach of their trust to members of the fund, had knowingly invested members' funds in the company with very little prospect of a reasonable return. Despite inquiries of the police, there appeared to be little interest in pursuing those trustees or directors for their actions which, at the very least, were a breach of trust but could quite properly be seen as theft.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the ASC should examine Byrnwood with a view to ensuring that the said directors are not given another opportunity to squander employee superannuation funds, either in their current or future capacities as director trustees. Surely the conduct of the trustees, if it is sustained to be of the standard alleged in evidence, is sufficient to exclude them from sitting on any company board. In addition, the fact that the employer actually made deductions from employees' wages and did not remit them to the superannuation fund but retained them within the employer company, is surely prima facie evidence of theft.

The extraordinary fact of the matter was that the employees had virtually no avenue through which to pursue recovery of their rightful entitlements from the superannuation fund. Advice was received that, while a common law action could be taken, it would be likely to take several years and would prove to be extremely costly—in the vicinity of $50,000 to $100,000-plus, with no-one in a position to fund it—and there was no guarantee of success, particularly as the only director domiciled in Australia no longer had any assets.

As it transpired, a settlement was eventually reached with one of the directors, Mr Humann, to settle for a total of $200,000, or approximately 76 per cent of the minimum actuarial liability assessed as at November 1990, or 43 per cent of what should have been the fund's assets at that date, to be paid in instalments by mid-1992.

I should now like to give some attention to the lessons to be learnt from the Byrnwood case. Firstly, there is the matter of trust deeds. The Byrnwood trust deed, which was clearly provided by a firm of solicitors and was not particularly old, purports to be an agreement between Byrnwood Pty Limited, hereinafter called the principal employer, of the one part and Byrnwood Pty Limited, hereinafter called the trustee, of the other part. This becomes quite farcical when one considers that there are a number of provisions within the trust deed which require the trustee and the principal employer to agree: changes in the review date, which could quite possibly postpone indefinitely the declaration of an interest rate; or amendment of the trust deed without reference to the members, subject only to ratification by an actuary.

In addition, the deed provides for all the trustees to be nominated by the principal employer. Such a provision can be used to ensure apparent compliance with OSS guidelines on joint trusteeship without reference to the members or their union. This highlights the need for arm's length relationships between employers and the trustees of corporate superannuation funds. There is clear potential for conflict of interest when the directors of the company are also the sole trustees of the corporate superannuation fund. In practice, I maintain that there is absolutely no difference between the two except a legal fiction. It is clearly unacceptable that the employer and trustee of the fund are one and the same entity, as occurred in the Byrnwood case.

Secondly, the high cost of civil court action and the uncertainty of the result effectively precludes members of a fund, particularly members who have just been made redundant and who have no money, from taking action against former trustees. In the Byrnwood case, as one of the former trustees was a declared bankrupt and another was domiciled in Hong Kong, it seems likely that legal costs would exceed any settlement determined by the courts if the action by the members were successful. If the ASC had powers similar to the Trade Practices Commission to institute civil proceedings against individuals or companies alleged to be in breach of the law, the members may have been able to take some action against the trustees. As matters currently stand, they have virtually no hope of recourse through the legal system.

Finally, whilst there seems to be some confusion over whether the Byrnwood fund was a complying fund, if it was a complying fund it breached the in-house asset rule. This raises the question of what can be done to improve ASC audit procedures to pick up such flagrant breaches of regulations and what penalties can be imposed on trustees. The in-house asset rule sets at a maximum of 10 per cent the amount of moneys that can be invested from a superannuation fund in the employer. In this case, 90 per cent of the moneys were taken from the superannuation fund and invested with the employer. Again, it clearly seems to be a prima facie breach of the law.

In conclusion, having due regard to the interests of Byrnwood's former employees, the Committee believes that payments which have been made by the former trustee director—who I emphasise was a partner in Price Waterhouse—should not be taxed at marginal rates or under the capital gains provisions of the tax Act. Instead, the payment should be taxed as an eligible termination payment so that the pre-1983 benefit would be subject to an effective tax rate of 2 per cent to 3 per cent or less and the post-1983 benefit subject to the same taxation arrangements as other superannuation benefits. To this end, the Treasurer has received the letter which I have just tabled from this Committee requesting that he consider referring our request to the Australian Taxation Office and to allow it to exercise discretion in this matter.

Surely these ex-employees, who had to endure the shock of being retrenched and then suffer the indignity of not being able to receive their superannuation funds because they were stolen, should be given every consideration in this matter. Should the Tax Commissioner not have the legal power to act in the way described, the Government has an obligation to change the existing legislation to ensure that the Byrnwood employees and others who in the future might be similarly aggrieved are treated with absolute fairness and equity.

The circumstances of the Byrnwood case, as well as the potential for other funds to suffer a similar demise, place an onus on the Committee in its report, which will be presented at the end of the autumn sittings, to make particular recommendations to ensure that in future the scope for such maladministration and fraudulent theft and behaviour is eliminated. The facts in the Byrnwood case bear remarkable similarity to the recent case in the United Kingdom, the Maxwell case—which I will be speaking on at another time in another forum—except that in the Maxwell case some hundreds of millions of pounds were fraudulently taken by the employer from the principal superannuation fund.
I commend the documents to the Senate and thank honourable senators for allowing the Committee to report on this matter today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The principal purpose of the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1992 is to reduce the rate of sales tax payable on certain motor vehicles from 20 to 15 per cent. That is achieved by reducing the sales tax rate applicable to vehicles covered by the fifth schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act from 20 to 15 per cent. However, in effecting the changes contained in the Bill, an amendment has also been proposed to the formula contained in item 61 in the second schedule to the Act. It is that formula that has previously been used to ensure that only those vehicles priced at retail above the income tax depreciation limit contained in section 57AF of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 attracted the so-called luxury tax—that is, sales tax at the rate of 30 per cent. The item 61 formula does not now refer to the rate of tax applicable to fifth schedule vehicles—that is, 15 per cent. Rather, the formula refers simply to 20 per cent, without any specific reference to the derivation of the 20 per cent.

PARA.TAB: If the Bill is passed as currently drafted, it will effectively reduce the luxury car tax threshold from its previous level of $45,462 to $43,937. That reduction is the result of maintaining the historical wholesale value threshold of $30,505 but reducing the tax rate for vehicles priced at or below the wholesale threshold from 20 per cent to 15 per cent. From a policy point of view, the implication is that the policy formulated in 1986, and maintained since then, of setting the income tax depreciation limit and the luxury car tax threshold at the same level will be discontinued. Under the Bill, it will now be theoretically possible for a motor vehicle to be priced at retail below the depreciation limit but above the luxury car tax threshold that would apply to vehicles priced at retail between $43,937 and $45,462. That is a black hole, if you like, of something like $1,500.

Clearly, that is contrary to the policy adopted in 1986, when the linkage between the two concepts—namely, the depreciation limit and the luxury car tax threshold limit—was legislated for. It would be a change quite contrary to the policy that was adopted then. More significantly, it also appears to conflict with the Government's intentions in its economic statement of 26 February. I quote from page 197 of that statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The 15 per cent WST rate will apply to all new passenger motor vehicles (whether domestic or imported) that are priced below the luxury motor vehicle threshold (which for 1991-92 is a sale value for WST purposes of $30,505, equivalent to a retail price of $45,462).

In other words, in the economic statement of 26 February the Government was saying that the retail price to which the changes in the sales tax rate would apply is $45,462, not the $43,937 which will be the result of the formula now contained in the Bill.

PARA.TAB: That gap has some significant effects. First, it is highly confusing. It is illogical because it has always been seen as desirable and logical to have the depreciation limit value set at the same level, in effect, as the retail price level for the application of the luxury car tax of 30 per cent. As a result of this Bill, we now have a gap opening between the two. The practical effect, as I understand it, is that it becomes virtually impossible to price a car at retail in that range of $43,937 to $45,462 because of the very large amount of extra sales tax that has to be paid once the retail price of $43,937 is exceeded. Although the depreciation limit remains at $45,462, this black hole effect—for want of a better description, and I think it is an accurate description—means that cars will not be priced at that level. Instead, the retail threshold of $43,937 will become the de facto depreciation limit, and that represents in practical terms a lowering of the depreciation limit by stealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't understand it.

—I bet I am doing better than Senator Cook. Because the statement of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, refers to the $45,462 figure, with which we agree, and because, as I understand it, the Bill separates the depreciation limit from the retail price limit for the application of the luxury tax rate, we believe that it would make commonsense and remove a lot of the confusion to bring the Bill into line with what would seem to have been everyone's intentions. Hence, on behalf of the Opposition, I have circulated an amendment to clause 4—and there are consequential amendments to clauses 5 and 6—that would have the effect of removing the gap that has opened up as a result of this Bill between the $43,937 figure and the depreciation limit figure of $45,462.

PARA.TAB: I hope the amendments will have the support of the Government and the Democrats. It seems to me that, so far as the Government is concerned, this would amend the Bill to make it accord with what appears quite clearly to have been the intention of the Government as outlined in its 26 February economic statement. I seek leave to move the three amendments together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the amendments moved by my colleague Senator Short. The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) seeks to achieve the admirable objective of reducing the rate of sales tax on certain motor vehicles from 20 to 15 per cent. Unfortunately, I believe that this has created a number of unintended consequences. It is to overcome those unintended consequences that we have placed the amendments before the Committee.

PARA.TAB: As my colleague has explained, the Government's Bill unintentionally creates an unnecessary anomaly in that it results in a retail price threshold for sales tax purposes of $43,936, yet it retains an income tax depreciation limit of $45,462. We believe that these amendments, which have the support of industry, will overcome this problem by ensuring that the retail threshold price at which the tax rate increase is triggered—I think they are the operative words—would remain tied to the income depreciation limit. I think those words are important. In achieving this result, the amendments do no more than reinstate a policy of the Australian Labor Party adopted by the Government when in 1986 it introduced what I referred to last night as a highly discriminatory luxury car tax.

Unfortunately, as a result of the wording in this Bill—which as a consequence has created what I do not believe to be its intention—the Government has now abandoned this nexus policy without any sound reason or explanation. A tremendous amount of confusion and detriment will be caused to the industry—detriment that I believe was never intended—as a result of the intention to lower this tax from 20 per cent to 15 per cent.

Logic actually dictates that the luxury car tax threshold should not fall below the income tax depreciation limit. Indeed, to do otherwise under these circumstances would mean that there would be a reduction by stealth in the income tax depreciation limit as it now applies to new motor vehicles. When we consider that the substantial tax penalty applied under the Government's Bill would lead to an increase in the retail price of a new vehicle from $43,935 to $48,462, we see that the practical impact of that on the industry would be that no new vehicles would be priced within this range. As a result, in practical terms, the depreciation limit for new vehicles would fall from $45,462 to $43,936. We may say that is desirable inasmuch as that would tend to force down the prices of new vehicles. In fact, this has not been publicly announced by the Government.

There does seem to be confusion. The One Nation statement, which my colleague Senator Short has referred to, gives reference to the Government's intention in this issue. What we are really attempting to do is to give credence or support to what the Government is seeking to achieve in the One Nation statement, but which this Bill unintentionally would take away. But, unfortunately, the action is unintentionally discriminatory in that distributors of cars which were previously priced below the $42,000 level will not be subject to the effective retail price fixing imposed on cars previously priced between $44,000 and $45,462.

There is another unintended impact. As a result of this problem, the distributors of such vehicles will be given no opportunity or incentive to put within their vehicles added safety features; perhaps these might be withdrawn in order to get the price down. I think this is an unintended effect of this Bill. Ultimately, we believe that the prices should not be forced down through government legislation; market forces should dictate whether or not prices fall in response to tax rate reductions and whether or not distributors choose to reintroduce safety measures to such vehicles.

Given the very minor differences in revenue terms that these amendments are going to achieve if passed by the Government, I believe that the Government—in the interests of consistency of policy, of achieving harmony within industry, of seeking to achieve the objectives which are sought by this Bill—should agree to these amendments.

Some of my colleagues have previously indicated that already the depreciation limit is out of kilter with what was set during the 1970s when a luxury tax depreciation threshold was set relating to, I think, a Ford LTD. Unfortunately, as a result of improvements in car design, the ABS in its statistics, in trying to relate modern cars back to this concept of, say, a Ford LTD in the 1970s, has had to severely discount modern features, including power steering and a lot of safety equipment. The result is that we now have a luxury car tax threshold which is far below the market price for such cars. This, indeed, is unfortunate.

The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, has acknowledged this problem and, without putting too much emphasis on it, has indicated that further consideration will be given to this particular problem. Mr Chairman, it is for your interpretation as well as mine just what `further consideration' of this matter actually means. But I generally believe that Senator Button has acknowledged that a problem does exist and that, as a result of the manner in which the Australian Bureau of Statistics has calculated the updating of this limit, the limit is now out of kilter with reality and needs fixing. So I believe it would be, indeed, unfortunate if the Government rejected the amendments and then within a few weeks turned around and sought to adjust the problem, as it would cause further confusion in the interim period.

I am concerned that a consequence of the complexity and the difficulty of calculation of this so-called determined area, which will increase as a result of the consequence of this change—because the void that I referred to will extend the range from $43,937 to $48,156—will be a completely unacceptable mathematical situation which really is adverse to the industry.

As a further consequence, there will be distortions and the distributors will certainly be discouraged from adding needed safety equipment and other equipment accepted as being necessary in modern day cars nowadays. Of course, it will cause distortions because imported cars in particular are automatically fitted with some of this equipment. It may, in effect, work to the detriment of certain Australian cars where those features are regarded as optional extras. I believe there is a lot of support for the amendments.

There is also the problem as to the relevance of the depreciation limit which is set by section 57AF of the Act. I drew attention to this during my second reading speech last night. Rather than traverse this particular area again, I direct the Minister's attention to my remarks, which were reported on page 979 of Hansard. I look forward to the Government's support for the amendments which are designed to overcome what I regard as an important unintended consequence of the Government's legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not in the chamber when the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1992 first went into Committee, but I understand that the Bill has been taken as a whole. I am also fully aware that my colleague Senator Short has moved amendments. However, I wish to ask a specific question of the Minister on the Bill as a whole.

PARA.TAB: Incidentally, I fully support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Short and so well explained by him and by Senator Watson not only today but also yesterday evening. I am sure that the consequence of the wording of the Bill, as my colleague Senator Short said, was unintended and that the Government probably never even thought about until now. These things do happen. I certainly support Senator Watson's remarks: this problem should be fixed now so as not to leave confusion for the next two or three weeks, or whatever the case might be.

I would like to ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) a specific question, which he might be able to address later on. He may remember a section of the Bill that positively excludes utilities, trucks, vans, four-wheel drives and dual cabs from being classed as passenger vehicles. The question I would like to ask is: what criteria have been used to exclude and remove completely the dual cab type of vehicle from this category? I know that the four-wheel drive, the utility and the dual cab have been excluded.

Generally, there are two variations in all models of the dual cab. Firstly, there is the high model four-wheel drive. A differential is fitted to the front of these vehicles which means that the chassis has to be raised. This is classed as an off-road vehicle. Generally, it is a diesel powered vehicle—not that that matters very much. Secondly, there is a two-wheel drive version which is lower, because there is no front differential to cover, and is generally petrol powered. This vehicle normally has two bucket seats in the front with a full bench seat in the back. There is a certain amount of room in the rear that can be used to carry a minimal amount of goods. Because this space is beyond the back axle, it is unsafe to overload the vehicle. In order to improve its looks, this space can be fitted with a fibreglass cover. So that is the sort of configuration we finish up with. Goods cannot really be carted in such a vehicle which is generally used only for carrying passengers. Local governments, which do not pay sales tax, and other enterprises use such vehicles as a personnel carrier. They carry passengers to and from work.

Of course, dual cabs remain taxed at a rate of 20 per cent, just like the other vehicles which have been excluded. I have my reasons for saying that, in line with the new legislation, all of the other vehicles should be taxed at 15 per cent. I cannot understand why a two-wheel drive dual cab with two bench seats or even a full bench seat in the front, and a full bench seat at the back—I believe Nissan may produce such a vehicle—is not classed as a passenger vehicle, and thus attract a 15 per cent tax.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I might respond to the comments made by Senator Short and Senator Watson. I will give my response to the amendments at this stage and I will catch up with Senator Panizza's comments at the conclusion of what I have to say. One could go into a welter of technicality on this matter. I will try to boil it down to only two or three basic points. Senator Watson was right in one regard: at the end of the day, this is not one of the major tax issues of the nation. It is neither big in revenue terms, nor in terms of the range of goods affected. It is a question of how one best deals with things which fall at the margin when one has money limits affecting tax rates and a gap emerges.

PARA.TAB: Essentially, the confusion is that there are two gaps. There has always been one gap. There has always been a gap within the retail pricing range—that is, when we get to what Senator Short was referring to as a black hole. Whether at the threshold we go from 20 to 30 per cent or 15 to 30 per cent, an effective—as Senator Short calls it—retail pricing black hole is created. It is marginally larger now because we are talking about 15 to 30 per cent instead of 20 to 30 per cent. But that is of itself no significance as a conceptual matter; nor does it change the fundamental nature of the legislation.

But there seems to be some cause for concern. The mischief that this legislation is likely to cause, which is not immediately apparent to me, relates to concern about the distinction between the depreciation rate, the depreciation cut-off and the retail price. There is talk of the depreciation level being reduced by stealth. I have to say that that is just not right.
Let us get into perspective the figure of $45,462 and its impact on depreciation. If one buys a car for $90,000, one can depreciate it as if it was bought for $45,462. That is absolutely unchanged.

TALK.START.PARA: —That still remains.

—That is right. I am saying that the effective depreciation is unchanged. If one buys a car under these circumstances for $43,000-plus—we say $43,936 and those opposite say $43,937; let us not argue about the decimal point—whatever the limit is, all one can depreciate it for is the price of the car. If one paid only $43,936, that is all one can depreciate it for. Nobody loses any effective depreciation. If one buys a car, there is no circumstance in which one could now lose a certain value of depreciation. It is true that there is a distinction but the mischief it is supposed to cause escapes me.
—Can I explain that to you?

—I have heard Senator Watson try to do so and at the end of the day I think he is wrong. He is welcome to try again and I will listen again. But I actually do not agree with his argument. I think I understand his argument; it seems quite straightforward. But I just do not agree with it. What I am saying is that the depreciation limit for motor vehicles is not changed at all by this Bill. It remains at $45,462 for depreciation purposes. It is not changed.
—In effect it is.
—I am saying it is not.
—In practical terms.

—There is not a purchase on which it will have the practical effect that Senator Short is concerned about. He is tying himself in knots. I do not see the problem. When we have put that depreciation point to one side, I will enjoy making the subsequent explanation. But I have been through it fairly carefully and I actually think those opposite are wrong.

PARA.TAB: The proposed amendment will create two wholesale threshold values. In the attempt to avoid creating two retail threshold values, those opposite are creating two wholesale threshold values rather than the one we have at present. Vehicles taxed at 20 per cent will have one threshold level and those taxed at 15 per cent will have another. It seems to me that this is not achieving the Opposition's purpose of simplifying the manner in which this legislation is administered. After all, this Bill does not set retail prices.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does in effect.

—The retailers set that. I am not saying it has no effect. Obviously, if we change the tax on something, we are likely to have—we are hoping to have, and the experience is that we are having—an impact on its retail price. I am not pretending that this is irrelevant. I am saying: let us not try to fiddle around with what the retail price should be; certainly not in the manner that I think is proposed.

PARA.TAB: I think the Opposition is wrong in proposing that the wholesale threshold be raised because the benefit of the reduction in wholesale sales tax rates will flow almost certainly to the wholesaler, not to the customer. That is not what we want to achieve. We have set out to try to reduce the price of motor cars and Senator Short's amendment counteracts that. It will mean that the retail price will stay the same and someone's profit margin will go up. The benefit of the tax reduction will not flow to the consumer. None of us wants to elevate this to a form of high art; we are talking about a fairly arcane and minor matter. Nevertheless, it warrants pursuit.

On balance, the course of action that the Opposition is proposing does not improve the situation. My understanding of the situation is that the industry's concern is less as time goes on and it can look at it in more detail. The Opposition initially reacted in a very startled manner because it thought it had some consequences which it does not have. I think that the problem is much less than the Opposition imagines and that its solution defeats the purpose of the Bill. Therefore, we will not be agreeing to the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have liked to have spoken before the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), nevertheless, I will still canvass some of the remarks I would have made. I listened carefully to what the Parliamentary Secretary said and I preface my remarks by saying that this is one of the most complex pieces of amending legislation that I have had to deal with.

PARA.TAB: If we look at the actual effect of what Senator Short claims is the non-alignment between the luxury car threshold and the depreciation limit, it is true to say that prior to this Bill any luxury car could be fully depreciated by an Australian business; subsequent to this Bill being passed all non-luxury cars will still be fully depreciable but the luxury car threshold in retail prices will be approximately $1,600 less than the depreciation limit.

Senator Short is arguing that that is bad for business; that this creates this `black hole'. However, I think there is another way to look at it. Many businesses would want to purchase a non-luxury car—not all businesses purchase the most expensive cars—and they might still be able to add some depreciable items, such as communications systems and intercoms. Under the current regime an add-on such as that would not be depreciable where a non-luxury car was priced right on that luxury tax threshold. So it is not really all bad for business, as the honourable senator said.

The really important point to make is that the alignment between these two levels has been broken purely because the level of the wholesale sales tax is being lowered. If one allows the retail price to remain static, then, as the Parliamentary Secretary said, it is right to say that one is really delivering the tax cut to the retailers instead of the consumers—

TALK.START.PARA: —To the wholesalers.

—To the wholesalers instead of the consumers, and that is not what the Democrats would want to do. I am not entirely sure that it is what the Opposition would want to do either. The Bill does not in any way alter the wholesale sales tax liability of any luxury cars. I think that is an important point.

PARA.TAB: Although Senator Watson talked about the problem with respect to some optional safety features having to be dropped so that the price can stay under the luxury tax threshold, there is another way of solving that problem. I talked about that in my speech at the second reading stage last night. We said that the way to do this is to identify those particular items and then exclude them from the sales value on which the wholesale sales tax is levied. We could do that. We could all work together to do that.

Senator Watson also raised last night the concern that the methodology used by the Bureau of Statistics in compiling the index by which the luxury car tax threshold is adjusted may be flawed. We need to look at that as well. Having said all that, I do not think that the anomaly that Senator Watson points out with respect to the safety features is addressed by the Opposition's amendment. I am also not sure that the confusion that Senator Short speaks about is of massive importance or consequence. I will listen to the Minister's answers to Senator Watson's further questions but I think it is unlikely at this stage that the Democrats would support this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before matters go any further, I overlooked responding to Senator Panizza. I am sorry about that. I had it written on a separate piece of paper and I put it to one side. I am sorry.

PARA.TAB: The distinction is actually quite simple. The definition that is driving the distinction is the definition in the Customs Act. All the vehicles referred to by Senator Panizza—including the dual cab vehicles—are under one classification in the Customs Act and subject to a tariff rate of 15 per cent, whereas those which we are dealing with as passenger motor vehicles are in a different classification in the Customs Act and have a 35 per cent tariff. We are not introducing a new classification; we are just taking the prevailing classification and transferring it to the tax Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —One aspect that has not been referred to in the committee stage of the debate is that the problem that the Government has got itself into is as a direct consequence of the complexities of the wholesale sales tax regime. Under the GST proposal this sort of problem would not have arisen. This is quite pertinent because it demonstrates the difficulties that any government inevitably gets into with a wholesale sales tax by pursuing an increase in revenue, or even changing the definitional basis.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition amendment is seeking to circumvent what we regard as an unintended consequence or minor mischief. We have never indicated that it is a matter of great moment, either for the industry or in terms of lost revenue. Our amendment demonstrates that, in order to ensure a continuity of Government policy under a sales tax regime, the amendment, unfortunately, has to be dreadfully complex again. That sort of thing does not assist in the tax simplification exercise upon which the Government is embarking, not only in terms of sales tax, but also in terms of income tax when, in such situations, one has sales tax elements tied to income tax elements and vice versa. This is always a problem where one tries to align two sets of revenue raising matters. I acknowledge that it is a problem. The Opposition seeks to draw attention to the problem and to provide a solution to what we believe to be an unintended consequence.

Let me explain to the chamber what has been colloquially referred to as a `black hole'. I do not think that the term means very much to the listening audience. Perhaps I should explain—and I think I made this point in my speech last night—that there is a substantial sales tax penalty in this Government's Bill because of an increase in the retail price of a new vehicle from $43,835 to $45,462. We have debated the fact that, basically, it will be difficult for retailers to price vehicles within this range.

The rationale behind that is that a $1 retail price increase above a $43,936 threshold would bring about a doubling of the quantum of sales tax payable from $4,575.72 to $9,151.44. This is the implication of an apparently simple change to the sales tax legislation.

Our amendment seeks to bring back or narrow what has unintentionally been increased by increasing the quantum of the penalty regime, and, because of the penalty regime, the effective market price of cars. It is true that, technically, it will not change from the $45,000, but in practical terms, because of the establishment of this lower wholesale tax price, people will not price their cars at that limit because of the sales tax implication. So in a sense, it is correct to say that the limit of $45,462 really does not change. However, the practical effect on pricing policies, because of the sales tax implications, will result in a pricing policy that will cause those detrimental problems.

The Opposition acknowledges that in these circumstances, as a result of our amendment, there will be an impact on the profit to the wholesaler. There is no doubt about that; we have never walked away from that. But we maintain, as an Opposition, that price should be determined by the market rather than by fiat or sales tax legislative decree sanctioned by this Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask Senator McMullan a couple of questions. I was going to make the same point about GST that my colleague Senator Watson made. The problem that we have with the wholesale sales tax regime is that it is very complicated, there is a whole mixture of rates and it is because of these different rates that we have this problem. If we had a uniform rate, particularly in the form of a value added tax, these problems would not arise. It is a classic example of the virtues of a value added tax over the ramshackle wholesale sales tax regime that we have.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan said that he did not understand why this is, in fact, a reduction by stealth in the depreciation element. The answer to that is that because of the additional tax impost for prices over the $43,937 limit, there will not be cars priced between that limit and $45,462. Therefore, in practical terms it means that the figure of $45,462 will cease to have relevance and the relevant figure will, in fact, be $43,937. There will be no cars in that intervening hole because of the tax applied.

I have two questions to ask Senator McMullan. Firstly, does he agree that page 197 of the Government's One Nation statement implies that the Government was aiming to have a figure of $45,462 as the retail price? Secondly, I am advised that at the motor show in Melbourne on 10 March, or thereabouts—it was reported in the press of 12 March—Senator Button said that the Government recognised the problem that we are now talking about and that it was looking at making the necessary changes. Is that the case? Did Senator Button say that? If so, why has the Government now apparently backed away from what appears to have been the Government's intention, as voiced by Senator Button at the motor show in Melbourne before the whole of the motor industry?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, I will primarily answer Senator Short's questions but those opposite cannot expect me to resist the temptation of responding to their other comments and I will not disappoint them. Firstly, I will deal with what is, in my view, a technicality, before I turn to the substance of it.

PARA.TAB: The complexity with which we are dealing—which I acknowledge—is not a product of whether we are taxing at the wholesale level or the retail level, it is a product of the fact that we are taxing at different rates. Of course, we could have a GST at different rates or a wholesale sales tax at one rate. The complexity arises from the decision which the Government makes consciously, and defends and advocates, to have the capacity within our indirect tax system to discriminate and say, `We wish to tax this at a different level from that'. Although it is true that at the margin one inevitably pays a price of complexity, there are great administrative problems with the GST—in my view, worse—but that is another argument.

I am saying that there is a socially and economically desirable case for retaining the capacity, effectively, to discriminate. Of course, the Opposition does too, because under the GST it has those things which are exempt and those things which are zero rated. We are talking about how much we discriminate, about what and by what criteria. I make no apology for the fact that the Government discriminates on a greater range of criteria on different products, and I will continue to advocate that we should. I do not apologise for the fact that the Government believes that it is appropriate and socially desirable as an equitable revenue measure to distinguish between the rate of tax one applies on cars bought by Australians in the normal course of their daily lives and luxury cars. I do not apologise for that one bit. There is a minor price we pay, which is a price of complexity.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not in question.

—Senator Watson raised this issue, I did not—I am only responding to the fact that he raised it. We pay a minor price of complexity. It is not because we have a wholesale sales tax instead of a retail tax or a value added tax; it is because we choose to discriminate. I defend and, in fact, advocate that discrimination and I will continue to argue to maintain it.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the argument about depreciation and then I will respond to Senator Short's specific questions. I appreciate that it is very unlikely that there will be a car priced at $45,462. I accept that, but it has nothing to do with the argument. No car will be less depreciable after this change than before it, except for those whose prices will fall. Of course, they will then still be fully depreciable. This was Senator Kernot's question. A car which is currently depreciated at $45,462, because of the retail price being X and the tax price being Y will still be fully depreciable, it will just cost less.

No car that is sold will be less depreciable than it was previously. There is no problem. There is no transaction which will be adversely affected by the issue raised. The problem does not exist. I accept that it would be a better world if it was not so complicated, but it is a price we pay for a distinction which, in my view, is a socially responsible distinction. That is my response to the broader questions.

I have no idea what page 197 of the One Nation statement says. I do not have one before me and I have no serious intention of running off to get one. In my view, the legislation implements the intention of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). He certainly thinks it does and I am happy to confirm that it does. We can quibble about the words later.

The more serious question is that concerning statements by Senator Button. I do not know whether they are absolutely as Senator Short said, but I do acknowledge reports, which I understand Senator Button has broadly indicated are true, that he said that the industry raised concerns with him and that he undertook to at least consider them. I think those were the words that Senator Watson used; Senator Short used slightly different words. I am not sure exactly what the words were, but there was a statement to that very general effect, and there has been discussion between the industry and Senator Button about that.

I am not a spokesman for Senator Button and far less for the industry so I do not want to comment in any way which purports to say that this has been the outcome of those negotiations. But as a result of those discussions between the industry and Senator Button, and then between Senator Button and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), it is an agreed position between Senator Button and the Treasurer that we should not agree with this amendment. That much I can say. I have an understanding of the outcome of the discussions between the industry and the Minister but I was not a party to them and it is not for me to comment on that. They are both capable of advocating their own cause. So that is the response to the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that there will be no statutory change to the depreciation limit of $45,000-odd that is on the record. But the consequence of this change in the setting of the wholesale price because of the extra quantum of sales tax that will be payable is a de facto lowering of the retail price, which will result in a diminution of the limit.
—That is only because the car will be cheaper.
—That is because the car will be cheaper, but the effect of this—
—How can you depreciate a $43,000 car to $45,000? Of course you can't.

—As a result of a fiat, because of the sales tax implications of what the Government is doing, it is true that cars will not be priced at that range. The Government is trying to force on industry a price reduction that will have the implication of a de facto lowering of that price. While we acknowledge that there will be no change in the absolute figure, the practical effect in market terms because of the implications of sales tax will be to lower that price because it will not be worth, in monetary terms, a reward to price it at that level.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two amendments to move and I shall call divisions on both of them. It might be helpful if I speak to both of them and we have the short break between the divisions. The first amendment I shall move is a straightforward one; I mentioned it last night in my speech on the second reading. It boils down to quarantining the effect of the proposed reduction in the sales tax rate from 20 per cent to 15 per cent to Australian made cars only. I would argue that we ought to make a distinction between Australian made and imported cars. The Australian car market is experiencing an increased rate of import penetration. The trend is a long term one and it is intensifying because of the tariff cuts we have in progress. I have a table showing the proportion of imported vehicles in the Australian new car market for the last 30 years which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —The table shows that locally produced vehicles now account for 70 per cent of new car sales, and this 70 per cent figure is down from 80 per cent a decade ago and 90 per cent 20 years ago. I am told that the French are seeking to address the dilemma of raising to 2 per cent the number of Japanese cars imported into France. Would that we were facing such a dilemma!

PARA.TAB: The Government's legislation is supposed to stimulate the currently depressed car market, and it will stimulate both the domestic and the imported segments of the market. Even if the relative share of imports remains unchanged, this will still guarantee more imported cars. We say yet again that it is time the Government and the Opposition rejected this level playing field argument, particularly until there is some improvement in the unemployment rate. By all means, we should be assisting the local car industry, but we should not also be assisting imports.

In our first amendment we are not proposing some reactionary, backward looking view. We are saying that the first priority of this Government and this Parliament should be to assist the local community not to persist with an increasingly discredited economic theory. Yesterday we heard Senator MacGibbon talking about the disgraceful conduct of the Civil Aviation Authority when purchasing the new radar system. He made a point of saying that it is wrong to ignore completely local firms and local industry opportunities. Yet when it comes to cars we do not hear the same level of support from the Opposition. There is nothing wrong with advocating preference for Australian jobs, especially during the current circumstances. It is unbelievable that neither the Government nor the Opposition will support us in this very small step. I seek leave to move the two amendments together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: 1.Clause 6, page 2, paragraph (a), proposed sub-item (2), lines 18 and 19, omit the sub-item.
2.Schedule, page 3, insertion of proposed paragraph 4(aa), after "15%", add:
where:

TAB.TAB: (i)c = fuel consumption in litres per 100 kms, and
v = volume of the vehicle in cubic metres; and
(ii)c and v are certified by the Australian Standards Commission".

SPEECH.PARA: The second amendment deals with sustainable development and how fuel efficiency is a fundamental part of the total sustainable development. Last night Senator O'Chee sought to ridicule this issue. He could not see that this is the most important question facing this country, in fact the world. This issue will not go away. Other countries are doing something about it while we continue to do nothing. The ecologically sustainable working group on transport has recommended that fuel efficient vehicles be taxed at a preferential rate relative to less fuel efficient ones. It is not a revenue raising measure but a measure that is designed to influence the behaviour of purchasers.

PARA.TAB: The reason that we have to start doing something about this is absolutely obvious; most people know it but we need to provide some incentives. We have to start to reverse the air pollution that is engulfing our cities. Just a few weeks ago we had the really alarming and quite scandalous situation in Sydney where the New South Wales health authorities had to advise asthma sufferers, allergy sufferers and people with other respiratory complaints to stay indoors on some days because of the level of air pollution—a level that is primarily generated by motor vehicles.

It is simply negligent of this Government to ignore these problems. All we need is some basic planning. We need to provide members of the community with incentives to change their behaviour in order to limit the amount of damage we do to our cities and to look quite closely at the amount of energy we import and squander. At a recent conference Brian Dawson, who is an oil export from the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, which the Opposition likes to quote quite often, predicted that crude oil imports will rise sharply over the next two years. He predicted that by the year 1994-95 imports would jump by a staggering 38 per cent from this financial year. This means that we will be importing $US6.5m worth of oil per day, which will give us an annual oil import bill of approximately $3.1 billion.

Amendment No. 2 is merely one of the measures that need to be implemented. It proposes to introduce a formula into the sales tax regime which varies the tax payable on new passenger motor vehicles on the basis of fuel efficiency and the volume of the car. Senator Panizza said yesterday, when speaking against this proposal, that one should compare apples with apples. That is exactly what this proposal does. The sales tax is calculated by a formula which balances the fuel consumption of the vehicle against the volume of the vehicle. The amendment seeks to promote efficient motor vehicles, whatever their size, so as to improve the efficiency of the Australian motor vehicle fleet.

The same measure should be used in respect of commercial vehicles, especially the vehicles used in the road transport industry. Let me quote from a recent study on the potential to improve the fuel economy of passenger vehicles which was prepared by Nelson English, Loxton and Andrews Pty Ltd for the Federal Government. At page 123, in respect of taxation measures that would help reduce fuel consumption by taxing the vehicle, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Effectiveness requires operating on purchase price, and those vehicle attributes which cause high fuel consumption, so as to encourage individuals and companies to buy fuel-efficient cars.
The more relevant and easily accessible vehicle attributes are fuel usage, interior volume, weight and specific power output.
It is time we stopped worrying about design and colour and started taking seriously the whole question of fuel efficiency.

PARA.TAB: Amendment No. 2 applies a formula which uses figures which would be provided by the Australian Standards Commission in respect of fuel efficiency, that is, the number of litres of fuel used per 100 kilometres and the volume of the vehicle. Under our formula, this component is then multiplied by the 15 per cent tax proposed by this Bill to arrive at the actual sales tax payable.

This is one measure that will help to provide a better quality of life in our urban environment, which is where the concentration of passenger cars is found. It is not the case, as Senator O'Chee seems to suggest, that we should just concentrate on the movement of freight. We are talking about pollution generated by a concentration of cars in urban areas. This problem will come to the Government's attention alarmingly in the near future. It is a problem that the community needs to address urgently. I commend these amendments to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just examined the amendments proposed by the Democrats. I am surprised that the impact of these amendments falls so heavily on the cheaper vehicles. I would have thought that, with a view to consistency, these amendments should also include those vehicles that have a sales tax rating of 30 per cent—the luxury vehicles—because these vehicles are perhaps more pollutant than some of the lighter vehicles that would come under Senator Kernot's classification of 15 per cent. It is a little unfortunate that she has not acknowledged this in her amendments. She is seeking to achieve something very desirable, but unfortunately she is directing her amendments at the wrong end of the market. Basically, the honourable senator's amendments are directed at the more fuel efficient vehicles which are less polluting. For the purpose of consistency, the honourable senator may wish to examine her amendments and resubmit them. In any event, the Opposition would have some concern about the unnecessary discrimination involved and the extra problems that would be created for the industry.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not agree with either amendment. I am advised that the first amendment, which discriminates against imported vehicles, is in breach of our GATT obligations. We are not entitled to discriminate in our tax system between domestically produced and imported vehicles. Australia is not prone to breaching its international obligations and it will not start now. It is a back door protection method and I do not think it is appropriate or desirable, as either industry policy or tax policy.

PARA.TAB: If the Democrats want protection for the motor vehicle industry, they can do it through their protection policy directly. I do not actually agree with doing that, but if that is what they want to do, they should do so and not go through the back door. In any event, Australia would not wish to act in breach of its GATT obligations. That is sufficient argument on that. I do not want to take up the chamber's time.

The other amendment contains a more worthy proposal, but I do not think it is either the best way to do it or the right place to do it. There is a great enthusiasm to tack onto tax policy all one's policy objectives to make the tax system drive one's environment policy, one's industry policy and other elements of policy. To some extent that is appropriate. The purists would say that one should never do that, and in this instance I am not trying to score a partisan point. That is one of the arguments the Opposition would put forward about the GST—it does not wish to make those distinctions through the tax system. Many purists would agree with that, whether they agree with a goods and services based tax or some other form of tax. They would apply the same argument to income tax.

I certainly do not take it that far. Ten minutes ago in this chamber I argued that there are circumstances in which it is appropriate to distinguish within one's tax policy to achieve economic and social objectives. I am not saying that this is verboten and that I would not contemplate it, but it is something that one ought do fairly cautiously, carefully and rarely, or else one winds up with the worst of all possible worlds. The tax system is very complex and one winds up with the different objectives being pursued conflicting with each other. Perhaps the tax policy already has the problem of having the three fundamental objectives which drive it sometimes coming into conflict.

Simplicity, efficiency and equity are not always reconcilable. Sometimes to achieve equity one has to put in some complexity. For example, if one wants to protect a group of people, one might put in a special clause to protect them. The Senate does that often. We start adding extra elements in order to pursue our environment or industry policy through it, and the various elements start conflicting with each other. One starts driving oneself out backwards.

Some parts of the sales tax regime are specifically designed with environmental consciousness in mind. For example, the exemptions for solar panels and recycled paper are the sorts of exemptions that distinguish the wholesale sales tax from the goods and services tax. For that reason, they are welcome. However, this amendment adds an extra layer of complexity, and I am not yet convinced it will achieve its objective. It sounds wonderful. In fact, the environmental argument is one of the reasons why the Government was persuaded to go to the reduction of 15 per cent in the first place. It will upgrade the quality of the car fleet, reduce fuel emissions and increase the percentage of the fleet using unleaded fuel, et cetera.

On balance, we are going in the right direction with the proposed policy. The Government is not persuaded that these amendments—worthy as their objectives are—are appropriate to include in the tax legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to address Senator Kernot's second amendment and to point out how patently stupid it is. If the formula that is provided there is used and 15 per cent is put where the X is, the result encourages people to have a bigger vehicle with a smaller motor. When looking at it from the safety angle, one will see that the power to weight ratio drops. For example, whatever the volume of a standard vehicle in cubic metres, when a smaller motor than the standard is put in, v comes down and c comes down. Of course, if that comes down, the sales tax will come down. That is the stupid part about it.

PARA.TAB: Although the sales tax comes down, safety is thrown out. The bigger vehicle will not be stopped but safety is thrown out the door. With a big vehicle with a smaller motor, the power to weight ratio is thrown right out. The vehicle is longer on the road and it is a bigger traffic hazard. If the car is on the road longer, it uses more fuel. So the whole lot is patently stupid. It is a reflection of the Democrats' policy on the run, because they think they might grab a few votes while we are on air.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The assumption in what has just been said is quite remarkable because it is totally at variance with the facts. The facts do not show that large vehicles which have smaller motors, and are therefore slower, are involved in more accidents. It is quite the other way. It is the smaller high-powered vehicles that zip in and out and have the sort of acceleration implied by Senator Panizza that are the ones involved in more of the accidents. So, in fact, the argument really runs the other way.

PARA.TAB: Let us pick up the arguments that have been put forward so far. First of all, in relation to what Senator Watson was saying about the classes of vehicles and the fact that more expensive vehicles would not be involved in this, we of course are able in this legislation to pick up only in this particular category because this is the category to which the Government has directed our attention. This principle, of course, could be extended to more expensive vehicles at some later stage. But that opportunity is not presented to us here.

In relation to the GATT agreement, I am really surprised at just how often the Government trots out this sort of argument. How many other nations are following GATT to the detriment of their industries as slavishly as we are? There are precious few, if any, countries that are following GATT to the letter of the law. At a time when we have such high unemployment, it would seem to me self-evident that a government that is elected by the Australian people has a responsibility primarily to the Australian people, rather than to some abstract document that is not observed by most other nations. For that reason, I think the Government needs to rethink its attitude to our first amendment.

The second amendment, the fuel efficiency amendment, has arisen out of the consideration of fuel efficiency. But we should bear in mind that some people for a variety of reasons—they may have large families; they may have the need to carry goods in their cars; they may have an association with family needs and so on—find it necessary to buy a larger vehicle. So it was felt that simply putting in a factor which related to fuel efficiency in terms of litres per hundred kilometres would unfairly disadvantage those people who, for quite legitimate reasons, found it necessary to buy a larger vehicle.

This formula relates the fuel efficiency to the size of the vehicle so that a large vehicle which is, nonetheless, fuel efficient can still attract a low rate of tax and a small vehicle, which may in turn be less fuel efficient in terms of the consumption for the size of the vehicle, would attract a higher rate of tax. Therefore, there is a pressure on manufacturers to manufacture in every class vehicles that achieve the maximum fuel efficiency.

I am sorry that Senator Panizza has left the chamber. I am sure that in the past I have heard him support Ralph Sarich from his own State of Western Australia and the development of his motor. That motor has now been placed in a General Motors vehicle of moderate size and came in with a fuel consumption, if I remember the figure correctly, of 2.8 litres per hundred kilometres. A vehicle like that would not suffer from any of the disadvantages to which Senator Panizza incorrectly referred, but would attract under this formula probably a tax rate of 7 1/2 per cent, as it should. So it should move us towards greater fuel efficiency.

Coming to the substantial argument that the Government has raised, economists have been telling us for a very long time that if we are going to address the very many social and environmental problems which beset us, we need, in their jargon, to `internalise the externalities' so that the cost of goods and services properly reflects their true costs; not just the cost to the manufacturer, the cost to the producer, but the cost to the community in terms of externalities. These would be things like deaths on the road, air pollution in our cities leading to a great amount of ill health, air pollution leading to the decay of city buildings and so on. These costs should be properly registered against the use of those things which are causing these costs to be borne. That is the proper way of costing these things.

I simply ask the Government whether it accepts in principle the internalisation of those externalities. If it does, there is no other way in which that can be done other than through the tax system. Rather than make the tax system more complex, it really simplifies the tax system because what the tax system seeks to do then is to internalise those externalities. There is a unitary principle which runs across the whole tax system and it is simply a matter of estimating what those externalities are and putting them into the tax structure so that people are given the correct price signals when they make choices, in this case about motor vehicles and, hopefully, about a whole lot of other things.

Senator McMullan correctly identifies one of the reasons we object so strongly to the Fightback package is that the single rate of 15 per cent denies us as a community, denies the Government, the opportunity to vary that rate, as it should be for those external costs to be internalised. He has come part of the way, but I wonder why he does not go the whole way and recognise that the tax structure is the only way in which externalities can be internalised as they should be in terms of fuel efficiency.

Senator Kernot has stressed that figure of $3.1 billion, which is the import bill. Senator Panizza interjected, `How about our exports?'. That is totally irrelevant. We can reduce that import bill of $3.1 billion to zero by improving the fuel efficiency of our motor vehicles, as most of our fuel is used in road transport. We could improve our overall economic performance by $3.1 billion. If we still continue to export, so much the better. But it seems to me that the only instrument that is available to us through market systems, the virtues of which are much extolled by both the Government and the Opposition, is to internalise those externalities.

The only way we can internalise those externalities is by the Government measuring those externalities and internalising them through the use of the tax structure. Therefore, I think the amendment that Senator Kernot moved has a great deal to commend it. Just as with our amendment in respect of sales tax on recycled paper, which the Government, together with the Opposition, rejected on a number of occasions and then finally made its own, this one also will eventually, as it must, be picked up by the Government and be supported.
