TALK.START.PARA: —The objects of the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991 are, in cooperation with the States, firstly, to identify and facilitate the protection and conservation of forest areas of significant environmental, cultural and heritage value; and, secondly, to facilitate investment by enterprises in major wood processing projects for the production of value-added products for export, import replacement or both. These objects will be achieved by, firstly, establishing the procedures and conditions for granting resource security to a wood processing project. This would include completion by the Commonwealth and one or more of the States concerned of a comprehensive, integrated assessment process involving consideration of the environmental, cultural, heritage, social and economic impacts of the project. Secondly, they will be achieved by preventing the exercise of Commonwealth decision-making powers in relation to the project, except in the exceptional circumstances provided for in this Bill.

PARA.TAB: Despite these appealing objectives, the Bill in its current form fails to deliver in all respects. The Bill in this form gives the timber industry no resource guarantees whatsoever. It simply exposes major timber industry projects to legislated ministerial intervention and Labor Party politics. The Bill does not provide the industry with the capability to pursue innovative business plans which could rejuvenate the industry, particularly its widely dispersed sawmilling sectors. The Bill shuts out this sector of the industry.

The Liberal and National parties, after very detailed consideration of the legislation and consultation with all aspects of industry, believe that the legislation we have before us will not provide genuine resource security and, therefore, in its present form cannot be supported. Therefore, I move the following amendment on behalf of the coalition:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of motion add", but the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill should be withdrawn and introduced in an amended form so that it offers genuine resource security to forest development projects that encourage investment, no matter how small, in enterprises that add value to Australian timber by:

PARA.TAB: (a) providing legislative backing to State or regional forest strategies drawn up according to Commonwealth-approved procedures;

(b) providing project-specific legislative backing for agreements between a State and proponents of large scale projects such as pulp mills which satisfy Commonwealth environmental and other requirements; and
(c) minimising duplication of Commonwealth and State administration.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment appeals to the Government to take note of what the coalition has been saying in relation to amending this legislation in order to take into account the particular concerns that we have.

PARA.TAB: As far back as November of last year, the Opposition expressed its preferred position on resource security legislation. The Government has not responded to this unambiguous request to reconsider the legislation. It has shown no desire to build into the legislation equity of support for small and large projects, nor has it shown the political determination to build real guarantees of resource security into the legislation. It has persisted in the fiction that it is doing something important to spur along investment in the timber industry when it has done nothing whatsoever.

The amendment represents an avenue by which the Government can overcome the Bill's weaknesses. Simply, the coalition wants to extend resource guarantees to small and large timber projects. We wish to see resource projects assessed on a case by case, project by project basis. We do not want the assessment bogged down in duplicated State and Federal environmental and other impact studies. We want an efficient assessment process that, whilst meeting the community's genuine environmental concerns, gives the industry confidence so that it can continue to invest and develop in this country. The Liberal and National parties believe that regional based approaches provide the best practical alternative.

I want to make it absolutely clear that the Liberal and National parties totally support the need for resource security and totally support the development of a pulp mill in northern Tasmania and Maryvale in Victoria, given that they satisfy appropriate environmental guidelines. We were, and still are, willing to work with the Government and industry to draft appropriate pieces of resource security legislation for these projects. We are willing to co-operate with the industry and Government in drafting an appropriate and suitably eligible package to offer resource security to the remainder of the industry. We emphasise that we believe the need for resource security legislation has only arisen as a result of the Government's appalling and cynical manipulation of resource development issues, and we do not believe that industry will need or seek resource security legislation under a Hewson Government.

The Liberal and National parties are totally committed to facilitating development which satisfies strict environmental guidelines. The Opposition supports the framework that has been put in place in Tasmania which will allow a pulp mill to be developed in that State. We support that pulp mill having legislative resource security under State law. Similarly, we support development in other States on the same basis, including extension of the existing project at Maryvale in Victoria.

The concern of the Opposition with this piece of legislation is that the objective is not achieved. As Senator Walsh pointed out in his Cassandra column in the Australian Financial Review of 12 November 1991, in examining the impact of this legislation and the five loose exemptions from resource security which are contained at clause 17:

SPEECH.PARA: If words mean what they say, this seems to permit closing down a project at any time by ministerial fiat. "Resource security" takes on a distinctly Orwellian flavour.

I quote this because the analysis of the Bill by Senator Walsh is the very same analysis of this proposal that was given to the industry by the Opposition from the time the broad proposal was made public by the Government and from the time the working papers which related to the development of this legislation came into our hands. The five exemptions that are listed under clause 17 are a way in which a project can be thwarted down the track. It became quite obvious to the coalition that this was not a formula for resource security but for continued uncertainty in the industry.

PARA.TAB: It is very interesting to look at various papers that have been distributed. In particular, I refer to an information paper that was distributed by the Minister for Resources, Mr Alan Griffiths, on 19 February 1991. It is a very important document that covers many of the issues that relate to this area. On page 5, under the heading `Can resource security be provided by non-legislative means?', it states:

SPEECH.PARA: In the past, the Government has adopted non-legislative, intergovernmental forest agreements as a means to resolve forest disputes and encourage investment in Tasmania and East Gippsland in Victoria. These have not worked and, in turn, have resulted in a serious lack of investor confidence and an absence of much needed investment in value-adding activities. Given this background, it is extremely unlikely that non-legislative instruments will work in the future.
This is an important statement issued by the Minister which merely demonstrates much of the hypocrisy that we have all come to know and expect from the Labor Government.

PARA.TAB: The Bill in its current form gives no security to the timber industry. We should consider for a moment the mechanics of the legislation. The Commonwealth declares that it will not intervene to disrupt a project. But under clause 17 of the Bill it has retained the power to act on a major and unforeseen environmental or cultural impact not identified at the time of initial access; that is, if it is an unforeseen threat to fauna or flora in the project area, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, can intervene. This provision gives the Minister considerable latitude, and there is no qualification in the Bill which explains how rigorously defined this unforeseen event has to be before the Minister will intervene.

How secure will a potential investor feel within this legislative framework? There is no guarantee that a Minister driven in search of Green and Democrat preferences at an election will not again overturn a project. There is no legal remedy to projects in case of breach of undertakings for the State and Federal governments, a matter which poorly reflects on the faith the Government has put in its own guarantees. The Government will not put its money where its mouth is.

The coalition believes that the Bill is fundamentally flawed. As an umbrella Bill, it duplicates State processes, provides no real guarantee of resource security, and opens the door for phenomenal interventions and abuse for a veritable host of reasons. The Bill has obvious shortcomings. It does not provide resource security. It is wide open for intervention by those who oppose any commercial use of native forests because of the vague provisions under which the Commonwealth may withdraw resource security, including ill-defined biodiversity criteria. The extreme Greens will have yet another legislative weapon in their armoury if the Bill is passed. For them it is a dice heavily loaded in their favour, both in the two-year assessment process and in the subsequent avenues for Commonwealth intervention.

The explicit exclusion of any payment of compensation by the Commonwealth is totally unsatisfactory. The Bill does not consider the small sawmill operators—1200 Australia-wide—and the small rural towns that draw their livelihood from them. The Bill gives only an illusion of security to large timber industry projects above an investment level of $100m. The Government is indifferent to the smaller rural-based timber industries and it is indifferent to the commercial prospects in regard to value-added strategies that they are well placed to adopt.

The Government can still use such mechanisms as the Foreign Investment Review Board requirements to intervene in such projects, as it did in the past in the Wesley Vale project. It involves the Commonwealth in detailed planning in areas where it has no special expertise and creates undesirable and time consuming duplication of approval processes. Instead of duplicating approval processes, the Commonwealth should simply lay down criteria to be met for large and small scale resource projects at the outset and allow these to be met by interaction between the State government and the relevant companies. Once these standards are met, the Commonwealth should then legislate to endorse the agreement between the States and the enterprise. This would cut down on duplicating administration and would enable effective fast-tracking of projects, which is not possible under existing arrangements.

This legislation is a hopelessly compromised attempt to please everyone which has succeeded in pleasing no-one. The National Association of Forest Industries in its submission to the Government in December 1990 made it very clear that the commercial sector of the industry accepts that there are important issues that have to be dealt with in a responsible and detailed way. I have to mention the five-stage process that the National Association of Forest Industries set out in its December submission. This represents a very reasonable assessment of the task which governments face as a prelude to making decisions in relation to secure access to resources and proper conservation values, both of which are important.

I seek leave to table an exchange of correspondence between the shadow Minister for primary industries, Bruce Lloyd, and the Minister for Resources, Alan Griffiths. I did seek Minister Cook's endorsement to do so.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The industry's submission has made quite clear to the Government what needs to be done regarding the agreement between the State and the industry. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: (1). . . an area of forest should be identified under a wood supply agreement as being suitable for long-term investment.
(2)The State Government would then put a proposal to the Commonwealth seeking federal endorsement to the arrangement.

(3)The State and Commonwealth would provide a detailed assessment of the region, looking at conservation values and economic and social issues. It is expected that the Australian Heritage Commission would have a major role in advising the Commonwealth on the conservation values of such a region.
(4)When the studies were completed the forest areas of high conservation value would be reserved under national park, State park, forest reserve, or some similar agreement.

(5)The remaining area would be designed under the legislation as multiple use forest. Under the Commonwealth/State agreement, multiple use forest would be available for production forestry in the long term.

This is the industry viewpoint—not just a simple grabbing of a piece of land and a grabbing of a volume of resource, but a careful assessment of what needs to be preserved, what needs to be conserved and what is available for exploitation.

PARA.TAB: This issue is naturally attracting a lot of attention—from governments, from industry, from individuals and from the media. It is very interesting to reflect on some of the representations and the points that have been made. I have just mentioned that I have tabled the exchange of correspondence, which includes the major submission with regard to what industry sees as the desirable amendments that are so very necessary and which the Liberal and National parties will endorse.
Let me also give some other examples. In a letter of 24 March 1992 from the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Ray Groom, to Mr Keating, the Prime Minister, Mr Groom says:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Association of Forest Industries has now proposed a number of amendments to the Forest Conservation and Development Bill. The Federal Opposition supports those amendments and I urge the Government to support them too in order to ensure the industry gets the resource security it needs.
Then there is a letter dated 28 February 1992 from Australian Paper Manufacturers to Mr Griffiths, which states:
AMCOR Ltd announced on 27 February capital expenditure at Maryvale on increased capacity including plantation development of $154m to be spent over the next four years.
The letter continues:
I would urge you to consider appropriate amendments as suggested by NAFI. It was pleasing to note some foreshadowing of regional security in the economic statement in the CALM-AHC process.
From the Forest Protection Society of New South Wales comes a press release of 24 March 1992 which states:

Mrs O'Neil went on to say that New South Wales FPS members were urging the Government to accept amendments to the legislation to cover forestry activities in this State, notably the saw milling sector. Without such amendments, the legislation will leave New South Wales industry out in the cold.
There is an important press release—that of the National Association of Forest Industries Ltd itself—attributed to the Director of that Association, Dr Robert Bain. It states:

Dr Bain said in the past 24 hours the Federal Opposition and the Tasmanian Government had confirmed their support for a package of amendments presented to the Government last Friday. The amendments will make the legislation genuinely workable. They will enable State governments to put forward properly accredited forest management and development plans with Commonwealth legislation which will provide for the long term conservation and management of forests.
It continues:
The amendments bring this legislation largely into line with an information paper on resource security issued by the Minister for Resources last year.

I have already reflected on the hypocrisy of the Minister's stance in that information paper and what the industry and the community can now rightfully expect the Government's action to be. I refer to a press release of the Forest Industries Federation of Western Australian in which that Association has called on the Western Australian Premier, Carmen Lawrence, to intervene. It states:

The letter to the Premier says that without the amendments the legislation does not offer long term security or the confidence for industry to invest in projects throughout the south west. A spokesman for the industry said the potential for industry investment in the next 10 years exceeds $4 billion and offers thousands of new jobs.
Part of the statement from the Forest Protection Society of Queensland reads:
This legislation needs to be passed by the Senate but only after it has been amended to encompass State and regional timber strategies rather than just individual projects.
In a press release entitled `Resource security needed for private plantations too', the Australian Forest Growers states:
Australia's private tree plantation owners today joined calls for the Federal Government to adopt proposed amendments to its resource security legislation as a matter of urgency.
The Forest Protection Society of Western Australian states:
The CALM-AHC agreement on forests will be strongly opposed if industry amendments are not included in resource security legislation to be debated in the Federal Senate tomorrow.
The New South Wales Forest Industries in a press release states:

The Executive Director of the New South Wales Forest Products Association Doctor Bill Hurditch said today that the recent introduction of State based legislation giving interim protection to the New South Wales industry would be jeopardised by Commonwealth intervention unless the amendments were adopted in the Senate.

I could go on. Other press releases and statements that I have include those from the Pulp and Paper Manufacturers Federation of Australia, the Victorian Association of Forest Industries, the Australian logging council and, of course, many others interested in this particular area.

PARA.TAB: All of these reinforce and state the important point: investment in the hardwood industry is drying up from all sources. It is drying up because hardly anyone believes that the political system in this country—at either State or Federal level—will ever be able to muster the firmness of will and the sheer determination needed to break the monopoly of the urban interest groups over the timber industry.

I wish to direct the attention of the Senate to the joint statement put out by my colleagues the shadow Minister for primary industry, Mr Bruce Lloyd, and the shadow Minister for the environment, the Hon. Fred Chaney, on 5 November 1991, soon after they had seen a draft form of the legislation. In that statement my colleagues made it quite clear that the coalition would support the resource security legislation if it were to accord with the patterns we believe would work, and not produce the difficulties that this legislation will certainly produce.

The fact of the matter is that this piece of legislation has been born out of cheap politicking. The Labor Government has played games with Australia's basic welfare and with the welfare of Australia's fundamentally important and competitive industries in order to purchase votes and purchase preferences.

Mr Chaney and Mr Lloyd have more recently reinforced the position. They have talked about the stance that we will take with regard to this legislation today and the amendment I have moved to the second reading. In the next few days we will present to the Senate committee that will consider this Bill after considerations here today and tomorrow, all of the amendments that we have drafted with regard to those amendments that have been put forward by the industry. I am pleased to note that Senator Burns is Chairman and Senator Brownhill is Deputy Chairman of that committee, and I am sure there will be many other honourable senators participating as we invite the representatives of industries and other groups to make their submissions.
I come back to the statement made last evening of Mr Lloyd and Mr Chaney in which they said:

SPEECH.PARA: The future of the resource security legislation rests with the Government.
If it accepts and moves the amendments proposed by the National Association of Forest Industries, the amended legislation will be supported by the Federal Opposition.
If not, the legislation is doomed.

The amendments will make bad legislation more acceptable, and provide some degree of resource security for this important national industry to invest up to $8 billion in timber as well as pulp and paper projects.

The amendments seek three fundamental and important changes. They extend eligibility for resource security to projects that are to be conducted under duly accredited State forest industry development plans; allow for alternative resource to be provided in the event that the area previously secured is lost for some unforeseen circumstance; and remove the clause which says no compensation will be payable in the event of the resource being removed.

PARA.TAB: If the Bill fails, it will be because the Government does not want it and has refused to include these amendments which the coalition, the unions, the National Association of Forest Industries, and the rest of the timber industry believe are basic to providing the type of security which will allow investment. The future of the Forest Conservation and Development Bill is therefore fairly and squarely with the Government.

The coalition asks for the withdrawal of this legislation and for genuine resource security legislation to be introduced for the endorsement of approved regional strategies, or for the endorsement of agreements on the development of major projects such as the pulp mill. The legislation is not in a form that is satisfactory. Whilst we will vote that we proceed to the second reading of the Bill after we have moved the amendment that I have already mentioned, we could not pass and move to the third reading stage because of the complexity. It is essential that this matter be given the comprehensive Senate committee consideration that is so very necessary. This is an important issue. It will certainly tax the Senate, but our proposals are certainly being presented in the good interests of Australia. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate is of the opinion that the bill should be withdrawn and introduced in an amended form so that it offers genuine resource security to forest development projects that encourage investment, no matter how small, in enterprises that add value to Australian timber by:
(a)providing legislative backing to State or regional forest strategies drawn up according to Commonwealth-approved procedures;

(b)providing project-specific legislative backing for agreements between a State and proponents of large scale projects such as pulp mills which satisfy Commonwealth environmental and other requirements; and
(c)minimising duplication of Commonwealth and State administration".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Tambling was saying that the Forest Conservation and Development Bill ought to be withdrawn, I was looking at clause 3 of the Bill. The withdrawal of the Bill would, of course, include the withdrawal of clause 3, which sets out the objects of the Act. It may be worth reading out the objects of the Act as set out in the Bill to see what it is that the Opposition wants to have withdrawn. Clause 3(1)(a) states the first object of the Act, which is to:

SPEECH.PARA: identify, and facilitate the protection and conservation of, forest areas of significant environmental, cultural or heritage value;

From what Senator Tambling has been saying, I take it that he certainly does not approve of that. I can understand that the coalition takes the position that development at a great rate with very little restraint is what is wanted. But the Government says that there must be a balance, as in all things, between development and conservation. That is what this Bill is all about.

PARA.TAB: If the Opposition is saying what I take it to be saying, namely, that no regard ought to be given to significant environmental, cultural or heritage values, then it should come out openly and say it. If it does not say that, why is it that it wants the Bill withdrawn rather than amended?
Clause 3(1)(b) says that the second object of the Act is, in co-operation with the States, to:

SPEECH.PARA: facilitate investment by enterprises in major wood processing projects for the production of value-added products for export, import replacement or both.
From what Senator Tambling has been saying, I take it that the Opposition does not oppose that particular object of the Act. It is rather clause 3(1)(a) that has it concerned.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter is to speak after me and I will be listening with my usual interest to his address. I take it that his objection to the Bill is to clause 3(1)(b), that is, the object of the Act which is to facilitate investment by enterprises in major wood processing projects for the production of value-added products for export, import replacement or both. If that is what Senator Coulter says, I can understand that. The Democrats say that we should preserve the forests at all costs and that the value of life is not measured by bread alone, but that there are other issues we have to look at, such as the quality of life and the environment in which we move. I presume that Senator Coulter is going to talk about that. I can understand that position; it is a position that he will put forward well. But it is nowhere near the difficult position that the Government faces.

The Opposition says, `Let's develop with very few restraints. Let's develop the forests, no matter what. Of course, we have to have some sort of regulation, but that is pretty incidental'. The Democrats say, `We have to preserve all these forests'. The Government says that there has to be regulation. We do not want unfettered licence, as the Opposition would have. We do not want prohibition, as the Democrats seem to want. We want proper regulation so that the delicate balance between development and preservation for future generations is preserved. The decision as to where that fulcrum is to go is the difficult problem that the Government has to face. The Opposition has not faced these difficulties for many years now.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not know how to do it.

—The Opposition does not know how to do it, as Senator West said. The Democrats are quite up front in what they say; they want preservation. We can clearly understand their position. But I think that the people of Australia generally want a compromise between those two positions. In the end, life is mainly about compromises, about giving forests their due, but at the same time giving industry its due. That is what this legislation is all about.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tambling read out many quotes which he put forward as evidence that the industry wants this Bill withdrawn. I have discussed this Bill with Mr Shane Gilbert from the office of the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths). I must confess that he has convinced me that this Bill ought to be supported. He was able to put before me quotes from the industry which show that the quotes put forward by Senator Tambling have to be seen in context. I will take a little of the Senate's time to read out these quotes. North Broken Hill, the company which would build the Wesley Vale Mill, recently issued a press statement urging the Opposition to support the passage of this legislation through Parliament because, and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: This would be a significant step forward in the advancement of this nationally important project.
That is, it would be a step forward in the building of the Wesley Vale Mill, which would be done with proper regulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —No guarantees, Senator.

—All the Government can do is put in place proper regulation. It can never guarantee; it can never ensure. But any matter in life is subject to some risk. The purpose of government is to scale down that risk to the greatest possible extent, and that is what this legislation does.

PARA.TAB: As is set out in clause 12(1) of the Bill, one of the conditions that must be met for any project to go ahead is that the designated Ministers—that term is defined in the Bill—must be satisfied that the Commonwealth has completed an appropriate assessment process that examined the environmental, cultural, heritage, social and economic issues that might reasonably be expected to arise from conducting the project. That is a very comprehensive brief for anybody to go through before Government gives permission for a project to proceed.
It is also interesting to see what the Opposition says about this. Page 63 of Fightback! states:

SPEECH.PARA: We will. . . not hinder any pulp mill proposal which meets the current pulp mill pollution guidelines and which satisfies relevant heritage, social and economic requirements.

However, the terms of the legislation itself, if it is passed, provide for the same thing. So the Opposition, in opposing this Bill, is going against the very criteria it sets out itself in its tax package.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that Senator Tambling quoted the National Association of Forest Industries—NAFI—which in March of last year said:

SPEECH.PARA: The role of the Federal Opposition in this debate has been a bit ambivalent.
It went on to say:
The Opposition has been very quick to castigate the Government for the things it has done to the industry in the past but has been slow in putting its own cards on the table.
NAFI then said:

NAFI met with Dr Hewson and had numerous discussions with Opposition parliamentarians. It is considered most unlikely that they would oppose legislation when it was put forward by the Government in the House.
Clearly, the Opposition has done that. It has not just said, `We will make certain amendments to this Bill'; it has thrown the whole thing out. It wants the Bill withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: On 25 February this year North Broken Hill wrote to the Government—and, I believe, to the Opposition as well—and said this:

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the proposed resource security legislation—
that is the Bill which we are debating today—

. . . we would urge that this legislation progress as rapidly as possible as it is our opinion that this will provide an immediate signal to potential partners of the willingness of the Federal Government to create the necessary environment to allow the development of this nationally important project.

That is an entirely different picture from the one that Senator Tambling was putting forward—that the industry was opposed to this Bill. Indeed, I would have thought that Senator Tambling, coming from the Northern Territory as he does, would not be as concerned as his fellow senators from Tasmania because, if there is to be development in Tasmania, this is the very Bill that will get it going.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tambling, either explicitly or at least implicitly, said that the Commonwealth was moving in here and making all the decisions. However, before a project can go ahead, the second condition states:

SPEECH.PARA: The designated Ministers must be satisfied that the Commonwealth has completed an appropriate assessment process that was conducted in cooperation with one or more States in which it is proposed to conduct the wood processing project.

As again emphasised in clause 3, the process set up by this legislation is one that goes forward in cooperation with the industry, with the States in which the industry will develop a particular resource, and with the Commonwealth itself. It is an act of cooperation.

PARA.TAB: What Senator Tambling is saying, and what the Opposition's position seems to be, is that the only body to make a decision is the State concerned. What he says is, `Well, if the States come up with a project, the Commonwealth ought to approve it.' In my view, if that were done it would be an abdication by the Commonwealth of its duty not only to see that industries develop but also to protect the resources of this country in a balanced way, and to use its facilities to investigate these things to the best of its ability.

Mr Acting Deputy President—I see there is a new Acting Deputy President in the chair, Senator Crichton-Browne, and certainly there is none better—one of the issues raised by Senator Tambling in leading the debate on behalf of the Opposition was that the Government is not interested in small projects; that this legislation is aimed only at those big projects in which more than $100m is involved. Certainly, the legislation deals with investments where at least $100m is put forward to finance the project. However, it is incorrect for the Opposition, through its leading speaker, to say that the Government does not turn its mind to the other issues.

The proposition put forward by the Opposition, that smaller concerns will not be dealt with by the Government in an appropriate manner, is not correct because the Government fully appreciates the important role which the sawmilling sector plays in the industry and its concern to have secure access to forest resources. The Commonwealth will provide a legislative level of resource security for the sawmilling sector provided that that sector can form an enterprise to meet the eligibility criteria specified in clauses 5 and 11 of the Bill.

Clause 5 is headed `Wood Processing Projects', and deals with that issue. Clause 11, which is headed `Characteristics of the Wood Processing Project', sets out five conditions which must be met before a project can proceed. In addition to the legislation for the sawmilling sector, the Government intends to provide resource security on a non-legislative basis for investments that do not meet the $100m threshold.

The arrangements to be offered by the Commonwealth through formal Commonwealth-State agreements are similar to the provisions in the legislation in that they include comprehensive up-front assessment and provisions to accommodate changing circumstances of an exceptional nature. The type of project which the Government envisages could well use these arrangements is the hardwood sawmilling industry in the south-east forests of New South Wales, which at this stage cannot meet the $100m eligibility threshold.

In such an instance the Commonwealth would require a number of provisions: firstly, that the enterprise must be willing to commit either to value-adding investment or to industry restructuring; secondly, that the relevant State government must be prepared to offer a longer term contractually based supply licence for sawlogs to enable the investment to proceed, as has been the case in Victoria and Western Australia; and, thirdly, that the woodchip export company must have invested or be prepared to invest in other value-adding activities in Australia, either in sawmilling enterprises or commercial plantations, and agree that domestic value-adding of the woodchips has priority over their use for export.

To the extent that the Commonwealth is involved in export licensing in the region concerned, it will offer a longer term export licence up to the year 2000, and thereafter on a case by case basis on the understanding that if the woodchips are required for domestic use then, subject to market consideration, they should be directed to that end. This should not detract from the Commonwealth's firm desire to achieve maximum domestic processing of woodchips by the year 2000 or soon thereafter.

Senator Tambling spent some time on the issue of compensation. It should be said in relation to compensation that the Government believes that there are adequate provisions in the approaches outlined in the Bill to ensure that, even in the unlikely event of resource withdrawal, adequate resources would remain available to projects. These provisions are outlined in clause 9 of the Bill, which authorises the Commonwealth to enter into agreement with a State concerning the provision of resource security for a wood processing project. Clause 9 states:
9(1)The Commonwealth may enter into an agreement, with one or more States, concerning the provision of resource security for a wood processing project.
(2)The agreement is legally binding, but neither the Commonwealth nor any State is liable to pay damages for any breach.

SPEECH.PARA: While the Bill explicitly rules out, as I have just quoted, liability by the Commonwealth or a State to pay financial compensation, it does not prevent the provision of structural adjustment assistance, such as the Government has provided in the past in cases involving World Heritage listings of the forests of south-west Tasmania, the north Queensland rainforests and, most recently, in response to the cessation of logging on Fraser Island.

PARA.TAB: So the Government's record in the area of compensation is good. The Government is entitled to rest on its record with respect to compensation. The issues raised by the Opposition in this regard have been most ungenerous, given the history of the Government's actions in this area until now. Furthermore, there is nothing in the legislation which would preclude a State agreeing to make available alternative resources of equivalent quantity, quality and price in the event of the withdrawal of resources due to unforeseen circumstances.

It is difficult to understand why the Opposition would want to withdraw this Bill. I am instructed that when the Government was introducing this legislation it wrote to the relevant Opposition shadow Ministers informing them that while the objects of the legislation were straightforward—and that is made clear by what I have already quoted—the Bill itself was quite complex. Because of this, the Government extended an invitation for Opposition spokesmen to meet and discuss the legislation prior to the second reading debate. Unfortunately, that invitation was not accepted.

The Government has a basis for feeling a little chagrined that the speaker who is leading for the Opposition in this debate should come forward and demand that the Government withdraw this well thought out Bill which takes the middle course between unfettered licence and prohibition. It strikes a happy balance between the need for conservation of our forests and the need to see that proper development takes place. But the Opposition has demanded that this legislation be withdrawn.

This legislation, as I have demonstrated by the quotes that I have given, has met the approval of the industry. The people who develop the forests, who determine the way in which they are used and who are responsible for operating the mills which turn this raw resource into paper, want this Bill passed.

The question arises as to why Senator Tambling and the Opposition have taken the approach they have. I think they have done so because they do not understand the Bill. I suppose that there are difficulties in reading Bills. But I would suggest that those opposite see whether they can find someone on their side of the chamber with the ability of Shane Gilbert, the adviser to the Minister on this side. They need someone to take them through the Bill and tell them what it is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about some jobs?

—I think Senator Tambling's comment is very pertinent—it is the sort of question that should be asked in this chamber. It is a fair question to put to this side. Of course, this Bill by providing resource security gives security for the environment, security for development and security for jobs. The Opposition's approach may give security for development, but it certainly does not give security for the environment. I think Senator Coulter's approach—I hope I do not do him wrong—will be to give security for the environment, but not security for development. I think honourable senators would acknowledge that jobs can be obtained through giving security for the environment.

PARA.TAB: I have heard the Democrats put the argument forward in the chamber again and again that more jobs can be created by the preservation of resources, by locking up the environment completely, than by development. That might be a perception that the Democrats have but it is certainly not the perception that the industry or the unions have. They want jobs and they see jobs being produced through the development of these resources. That seems to be the community's approach to this as well.

The Government says, `Look, the legitimate demands of people for development, the legitimate demands of people for jobs, must be met, but they must be met in the context of the legitimate demands for the environment'. It is not doing the cause of the environment a great deal of good if the approach taken is that there should be no development of any resources, anywhere, at any time. That is not what the community wants. Indeed, it is not what the community needs and it is not the reward that the community should have for the great effort that it has put into developing this country.

What we must have—and I finish as I started—is balance, reason and proper judgment. This Bill exhibits the exercise of all of those things. The objects of the Bill are stated in clause 3(1); the way in which those objects are to be achieved is set out in clause 3(2). If those objects are followed, that happy state that we all search for—of people having jobs, of development, of having an industry and at the same time preserving people's quality of life—will be obtained.

I conclude by saying that the combination of legislated resource security for large projects, including integrated hardwood sawmilling projects and large-scale plantation programs, together with the framework of enhanced intergovernmental agreements—honourable senators should not forget that this is to be done across the board by all governments, State and Federal—for smaller scale investments in the hardwood sawmilling industry, is an unprecedented package which delivers security and incentive for industry restructuring in an environmentally responsible framework. For all of these reasons, the Government firmly believes that the legislation is sound public policy. The Government urges that all senators support the Bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I might begin by picking up some remarks of Senator Cooney who referred to me a moment ago and drew a totally false dichotomy between, on the one hand, caring for the environment and what he called `development' and what the Forest Conservation and Development Bill misnames `development'. It is a common trick to present the alternatives as though there were only two and then to ask, `Which one do you want?' when there are other alternatives which can meet much better the various criteria.

PARA.TAB: Specifically—and I will refer to this later on—in the area of fibre for paper making, one can achieve four to five times the amount of fibre production per hectare of land area by growing crops other than wood. It was done for some thousands of years before wood became the common method of paper raw material around the turn of the century—the nineteenth century into the twentieth century. Two crops in particular that have been well researched and have enormous capability for addressing that issue in Australia are kenaf in the tropical areas and certain species of cannabis in the more temperate climates.

So we do not need Senator Cooney to go into our old growth forests for woodchipping for paper manufacture. Also in the area of sawn timber for house construction, for high value adding furniture manufacture, there are better opportunities out of the forests and into plantations. Indeed, in north Queensland, where I was just a short time ago, a number of the councils around the Cairns region, recognising that tropical rainforest timbers have become unavailable for high quality furniture manufacture, have embarked on an extensive program of growing plantation tropical rainforest timbers. Some of those are able to be cut and sawn within 10 years and produced as very high quality furniture—something which is much better achieved in that way than going into old growth forests.

I bear for a moment on this word `development', which both previous speakers used. Development is something that one observes when a child grows. It is a process of the gradual evolving of a potential within an individual, an organism, or in a whole system. It proceeds apace; it produces something which is beautiful, finished and complete and then that development ceases. That is the natural process of development.

What we have in the case of forest development very often is clear-felling for woodchips. How Senator Cooney or Senator Tambling can use the word `development' in relation to that is something which really begs a great question mark.

Senator Cooney also mentioned the possibility of investments following the passage of this legislation. As I will develop in my speech, there is no guarantee whatsoever that the one proposal which has been held out, namely, the pulp mill possibly to be built by North Broken Hill, will be built even if this legislation is passed. Specifically, North Broken Hill has given no guarantee whatsoever.

In terms of guarantees, one can remember the early days. I am old enough and have been in the conservation movement long enough to remember when woodchipping began in this country. It was said that woodchipping would involve only the scraps and leftovers from the sawlog processes that were going on in the forests, and that there would be a more efficient use of those things. As I understand it, Daishowa specifically gave a guarantee that it would build a pulp mill based on chipping in the forests of New South Wales. We have seen what has happened to both those guarantees. Chipping is now far more extensive than simply using the waste from sawlogs and Daishowa has not built a pulp mill in New South Wales.

Indeed, how can any newly emerging company enter the market post the passage of this legislation and undertake to spend $100m on something which involved chipping? How would that fit in with the former Prime Minister's undertaking that there would be no more woodchipping in Australia after the year 2000? Again, this begs credibility, because nobody invests that sort of money over such a short timeframe and expects to get the sort of return that would allow woodchipping to be phased out within that timeframe.

The Forest Conservation and Development Bill is a complete misnomer. Indeed, we are debating one of the most bizarre, dishonest and potentially destructive pieces of legislation to have come before this chamber. This Bill has a title which is unmatched in its Orwellian dishonesty by any that I can recall. The Forest Conservation and Development Bill would not promote forest conservation, but rather forest destruction. Far from encouraging forest development, whatever that may mean—I have referred to the word `development' already—it would entrench an outdated and unsustainable mode of economic development. If either the Government or the Opposition really understood the term `ecologically sustainable development' they would understand that if sustainable development were put in place, legislation such as this corrupt Bill—which is masquerading under the title of the Forest Conservation and Development Bill—would not be needed.

It is well known—and Senator Cooney has referred to this—that the Democrats are categorically opposed to this Bill and that there is absolutely no way it could be amended to change our view. This Bill is the wrong solution to a problem which has been wilfully misinterpreted and exaggerated. We have heard that said this afternoon. For years, the forestry and forests products industry has complained that it does not have secure access to native forests for logging. It has complained that new national parks and conservation reserves have eaten into the resource available for logging. It has complained about the periodic involvement of the Australian Heritage Commission in Commonwealth decisions on applications to log new areas. It has claimed also that billions of dollars of further investment in wood processing projects will not occur until so-called resource security is provided. In short, the industry has identified federal and State environment approval procedures as the source of all its woes and has made it quite clear that it would dearly love to clear-fell the environmental approval procedures from the legal landscape.
One of the remarkable aspects of the resource security debate is the Government's

SPEECH.PARA: apparent failure to seriously challenge the industry's grievances and false claims. The Government's intention to proceed with resource security legislation was announced by the former Prime Minister in his industry statement in March last year. In that statement he accepted that the protection of native forests had been partly to blame for a contraction of the forest resource available to industry.

PARA.TAB: Only four months later, the Resource Assessment Commission, in the most comprehensive assessment of timber availability done to that point, identified the real cause of resource contraction as the over-cutting of forests. In the draft report of its forest and timber inquiry, the Commission concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: An important consequence of the prolonged period of overcutting is an impending shortage in the supply of hardwood sawlogs. This coincides with, and is caused by, the cutting out of most of the unreserved old growth well before significant numbers of regrowth sawlogs reach harvestable size.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 16 September 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will a recent move by the New Zealand Government to abolish the non-resident withholding tax imposed on money borrowed offshore divert business away from Australian banks.
(2) Will Australian companies with subsidiaries in New Zealand find it cheaper to borrow money offshore via their subsidiary rather than from their head office.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

PARA.TAB: (1) The net effect on the volume of New Zealand business of Australian banks of the recent move by the New Zealand Government to effectively abolish its non-resident withholding tax on the interest income of non-resident lenders is not clear.

Under the move, announced in the 1991 New Zealand Budget, borrowers are now able to apply to the New Zealand Commissioner of Inland Revenue to become Approved Issuers able to pay tax-free interest to non-resident lenders in relation to registered securities. A tax-deductible charge equivalent to 2 per cent of the exempt interest actually paid to non-residents is now levied on Approved Issuers. The abolition of the tax for Approved Issuers is likely in some cases to make it more attractive than previously for firms operating in New Zealand to borrow offshore. As a result there may be some diversion of business away from Australian banks operating in New Zealand. However, some of this New Zealand borrowing may be diverted to banks and other lenders operating in Australia. Also, Australian banks operating in New Zealand may benefit should they borrow offshore.

A large number of different factors including, but not limited to, the taxation regime in New Zealand and other countries affect the supply of and demand for funds in capital markets. Even apart from the difficulties that arise in trying to separate the effects of these other factors from those of changes to New Zealand's withholding tax regime, any response by borrowers and lenders to the withholding tax changes will be influenced by the particular tax and other circumstances which each faces.

(2) Companies operating in New Zealand (including subsidiaries or branches of Australian companies) may, in some cases, be able to borrow offshore on cheaper terms relative to what would have been the case had the New Zealand withholding tax regime been maintained.

However, whether those funds are available more cheaply in absolute terms than funds acquired from elsewhere, including borrowings by the parent Australian company from within Australia or offshore, depends on a number of factors which can affect financial markets as well as the particular circumstances of the company concerned.

(2) Article 18(1) of the Agreement provides that pensions paid by Italy to a resident of Australia are taxable only in Australia.
Where the Italian Government withholds tax at source on the pension, Article 28 provides that Italy will refund that amount at the request of the resident taxpayer or of our Government.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the concept of a `lease' as referred to in Division 5 of Part IIIA of the Income Tax Assessment Act unclear.
(2) Does the concept refer only to `leases of land', the traditional concept, or does it extend to `leases of chattels', the commercial financing concept of more recent times.
(3) Does the concept extend to `leases' of the many forms of incorporeal property known as `choses in action'.

(4) Insofar as the concept relates to claims to interests in land, is the traditional distinction of the law to be observed between `leases' as conferring an `interest' in land and `agreements for lease' as conferring only a contractual entitlement to have a `lease' and thereby to become a lessee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The meaning of the term `lease' in Division 5 of Part IIIA of the Income Tax Assessment Act is given its common law meaning. There is no special definition of the term for the purposes of the Division other than that the term expressly includes a sub-lease.

(2) Except for those provisions of Division 5 of Part IIIA that specifically refer to lease of land, for example sections 160ZSA and 160ZW, Division 5 applies to both leases of land and leases of chattels.

(3) The concept of a lease does not extend to a chose in action. Leases relate only to tangible property over which a right of exclusive possession can be granted. A chose in action relates to personal rights in property which can only be claimed or enforced by court action, and not by taking physical possession.

(4) In relation to land the traditional legal distinction between a `lease' and an `agreement to lease' is maintained in Part IIIA. The concept of a `lease' in Division 5 does not encompass a mere agreement to lease (which creates no legal estate).

However, the description of an instrument as an agreement to lease does not mean that the agreement does not constitute a real `lease'; an instrument (in proper form) by which the conditions of a contract of letting are finally ascertained and which is intended to vest the right of exclusive possession in the lessee, either at once if the term is to commence immediately, or at a future date if the term is to commence subsequently, is construed as a lease.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 27 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the issuing of the approval number by the Therapeutic Goods Administration, for the cancer fighting drug `Honvan' been delayed for over two months, merely because the previous packaging of the drug, for which there was an approval number, has been changed.
(2) Are there a number of cancer patients who have been prescribed this drug and cannot receive treatment.
(3) Why has this hold-up occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (2) Honvan is a drug approved for use only in prostate cancer. At the present time, any patient that has been prescribed Honvan for prostate cancer can receive treatment under the Special Access Scheme.

(3) Honvan has been available in Australia for the treatment of prostate cancer for some years. However, a recent application from the company to change the pack size has drawn the attention of the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) to an unapproved change in the tablet's formulation. Potentially this change could affect the way in which the tablets are absorbed and therefore their effectiveness.

The Commonwealth has a duty of care to ensure that medications made generally available to the Australian public are safe, effective and of high quality. As a result of the unapproved formulation change, the Commonwealth was no longer in a position to give such assurances in relation to Honvan. The unapproved tablet was therefore withdrawn from the general market. Its withdrawal was not related to a delay in issuing any approval number but rather to serious concerns regarding the quality and efficacy of the product.
While this situation is being resolved, the drug will be available to patients under the TGA's Special Access Scheme, whereby access to unapproved therapies is given under special circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Question Time on 19 December 1991, Senator Campbell asked me, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate, a series of questions without notice about the wholesale sales tax treatment of road transport:

PARA.TAB: (1) From what source were the figures quoted in answer to a question from Senator Walsh on 5 December 1991 derived?
(2) Do I consider that the cascading effect of the high incidence of sales tax and fuel excise on road transport is one example of Australia's uncompetitive business tax system?
(3) Do I agree that the distortion between road, rail, sea and air places a disproportionate burden on the cost of grocery items, because most of them are transported on large articulated vehicles?
(4) Is the Government currently considering specific proposals to reform these inequities in the wholesale sales tax treatment of road transport, or is the policy the same as usual?

(5) Was I aware of a Treasury paper prepared for the Caucus economic industrial relations committee on 26 November 1991, which showed that a figure I quoted in answer to Senator Walsh's question on 5 December was incorrect?
The Prime Minister has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:
(1) The figures quoted on 5 December 1991 in answer to a question from Senator Walsh were derived from a Press Release issued on 1 December 1991 by the then Treasurer, Mr Kerin.
(2) The wholesale sales tax (WST) and petroleum fuel excises apply to some business inputs and thus have some cascading effect through the production chain.

I do not, however, accept that this cascading effect leads to an uncompetitive business tax system. Nor do I accept that Australia's business tax structure is uncompetitive. Under this Government, the corporate tax rate at the investor level has been reduced to a relatively low level compared with other OECD countries and, in addition to other measures, the competitiveness of Australian business will be further enhanced by the accelerated depreciation measures announced on 26 February by the Prime Minister.

(3) I cannot agree with the honourable senator that the differential impact of the WST system on road, rail, sea and air places a disproportionate burden on the cost of groceries. The WST system as a whole adds only an estimated 1.37 percentage points to the gross industry costs of food, beverages and tobacco. An estimate of the contribution of the sales tax on road freight transport, compared with other forms of transport, to this cost is not available.
I note that under the Opposition's GST that all groceries including food will be subject to a 15 per cent tax on their retail price (including the costs of distribution).

(4) It is not the Government's intention to change the wholesale sales tax (WST) treatment of road transport. The WST is a tax on goods and is not directly levied on services such as transport. However, in lieu of a tax on output, the inputs to services are generally taxed. Thus, while goods producers are able to claim exemption on most of their inputs, which limits the cascading of tax through the production chain, service providers (including the road transport industry) pay tax on their inputs.

(5) The honourable senator has stated that in answer to Senator Walsh's question I suggested that the WST system adds about 2 percentage points to the cost of road transport. In fact I stated that the cost was 2.8 percentage points.

The 2.8 per cent figure is the average gross cost of the WST system on the road transport industry. It includes both the direct effect of WST paid on goods purchased by the industry and the indirect effects through the production chain. The road transport industry definition covers passenger and freight road transport. The gross costs include materials used, capital costs, wages salaries and supplements and net commodity and indirect taxes.

The Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics has, in a separate study, calculated some indicative figures to show that the WST adds 2 per cent to the cost of operating a two axle rigid truck, around 3.8 per cent to a large articulated truck and up to 4.5 per cent for a triple road train. These figures are calculated on a different basis to the ones above. They cover the direct effect of tax paid by the road freight industry on their inputs and in the depreciation of capital items and are expressed as proportion of operating net gross costs.
